title: Archie v. Howie
text:
SCREENING MEMORANDUM

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ex Parte:  Nettie Archie d/b/a Archie Bail Bonding Co., Inc. and Accredited 
        Surety and Casualty Co., Inc.,
Of Whom Nettie Archie is the       
Appellant,
In Re:
The
State,        Respondent.
Madeline Ann Howie       
Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-355
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Nettie M. Archie, of Chester, pro se. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Charles H. Richardson, Harold M. Coombs, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Archie contends the trial court 
  made several mistakes with regards to the Estreatment Hearing. We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Ellie, 
  Inc. v. Miccichi, ___ S.C. ___, ___ 594 S.E.2d 485, 496 (Ct. App. 2004); 
  (stating that pursuant to Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR, the brief shall be divided 
  into as many parts as there are issues to be argued.Â  â€œAt the head of each part, 
  the particular issue to be addressed shall be set forth in distinctive type, 
  followed by discussion and citations of authorityâ€); Glasscock Inc., v. United 
  States Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (finding where an issue is not argued within the body of the brief but 
  is only a short conclusory statement, the issue is abandoned on appeal); State 
  v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 265, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 n.5 (2003) (finding a pro 
  se litigant has full responsibility for complying with substantive and procedural 
  requirements of the law); Goodson v. American Bankers Ins. Co. of Fla., 
  295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (â€œLack of familiarity with legal proceedings 
  is unacceptable and the court will not hold a layman to any lesser standard 
  that is applied to an attorney.â€); State v. Lytchfield, 230 S.C. 405, 
  ___, 95 S.E.2d 857, 859 (1957) (â€œThe granting or refusal of a motion for continuance 
  is within the discretion of the trial judge and his disposition of such a motion 
  will not be reversed on appeal unless it is shown that there was an abuse of 
  discretion to the prejudice of appellant.â€). 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Century 21-Grimes & Associates, Inc.,       
Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John E. Benford,       
Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The Lachicotte Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-356
Heard May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed June 4, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Benjamin H. Culbertson, of Georgetown, for Appellant-Respondent.
Ellis R. Lesemann and Amy Y. Jenkins, both of Charleston, 
  for Respondent.
Charles T. Smith, of Georgetown, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Century 21 Grimes & Associates, 
  Inc. commenced this action against John E. Benford alleging breach of contract 
  and seeking a real estate commission in the amount of $18,500.Â  The trial court 
  granted judgment to Century 21 in the amount of $9,250.Â  From this ruling, Century 
  21 and Benford appeal.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
This cause of action arises out of the sale of 
  a 160-acre tract in Williamsburg County owned by Benford.Â  On January 28, 2000, 
  Benford published the following advertisement in the Georgetown Times:

HUNTING PARADISE for sale.Â  160 acres with hunting 
  road, deer stand, duck pond and an abundance of wild turkey, quail and rabbits.Â  
  12x65 trailer ready for hunting or very serene living.Â  Shown by appointment 
  only or one time listing for all Real Estate agents.Â  $200,000.

After reading the notice, Truitt Owens, a real 
  estate broker for Century 21, met with Benford and had Benford sign a one-time 
  showing agreement that identified six prospective purchasers for the property.Â  
  Stuart Ballard was listed as one of the prospective purchasers.Â  The showing 
  agreement stated in part:

Â [I]n consideration of the revelation of the identity of 
  said purchasers and the efforts of Century 21 Grimes & Associates, Inc., 
  to bring about a sale of said property, the undersigned does hereby acknowledge 
  an obligation to pay Century 21 Grimes & Associates, Inc. a commission equal 
  to 10% of the sales price upon consummation of a sale of the described property 
  to the prospective purchasers referred to herein.Â  It is further acknowledged 
  that the aforesaid commission obligation shall be binding upon [Benford] with 
  respect to any sale made to, or on behalf of, said purchasers during the period 
  of 360 days from the date hereof.Â  

Although Benford entered into the 
  showing agreement, he refused to sign an exclusive listing agreement with Owens 
  or any other broker or realtor because he wished to retain the right to sell 
  the property himself.Â  Benford told Owens he would pay a 10% commission to the 
  realtor who brought him the ultimate purchaser.Â  
Ballard, who had been looking for property like 
  Benfordâ€™s for over a year, also noticed Benfordâ€™s advertisement and placed a 
  call to his real estate agent, Chip Lachicotte of the Lachicotte Company, to 
  obtain more information on the property.Â  Ballard had a long-standing relationship 
  with Lachicotte and the Lachicotte Company.Â  Lachicotte had worked closely with 
  Ballard on several prior occasions, providing him with fact sheets, plats, and 
  other information on potential properties, as well as walking certain properties 
  with Ballard.Â  Ballard was unable to reach Lachicotte when he called him, as 
  Lachicotte was en route to Ballardâ€™s office.Â  At the suggestion of one of Ballardâ€™s 
  friends, he then called Owens to gather some information on the property.Â  Owens 
  did not have the information Ballard sought; however, Lachicotte arrived at 
  Ballardâ€™s office moments later and provided Ballard with the information.Â  Lachicotte 
  obtained plats and other information on the property for Ballard.Â  
During this process, Les Oâ€™Hara, another agent 
  in Lachicotteâ€™s office, was working with another individual interested in the 
  property, Robert Norris.Â  Norris, who was not listed as a prospective purchaser 
  on Owensâ€™s listing agreement, eventually offered to purchase the property.Â  
  Benford accepted and notified Owens of Norrisâ€™s offer.Â  Upon learning of Norrisâ€™s 
  offer, Owens ceased marketing the property.Â  The contract with Norris fell through 
  before closing.Â  Benford did not immediately notify Owens that the closing did 
  not occur.Â  
Lachicotte continued to work with Ballard on pursuing 
  the property, including thoroughly walking the property and wading through knee-deep 
  water on the tract.Â  Ballard made an offer on the property through the Lachicotte 
  Company for $185,000.00, and Benford accepted.Â  The Lachicotte Company drafted 
  and presented the contract of sale and held and delivered the earnest money 
  to Benford.Â  The contract of sale provided that Benford would pay the Lachicotte 
  Company a commission on the sale of the property.Â  On April 13, 2000, Benford 
  conveyed the property to Ballard for the contract price.Â  He paid the Lachicotte 
  Company a 10% commission of $18,500.Â  
On May 18, 2000, Owensâ€™ employer, Century 21, brought 
  this action against Benford seeking $18,500 plus prejudgment interest for breach 
  of contract to pay a real estate commission.Â  Benford answered and brought a 
  third party claim against the Lachicotte Company for reimbursement of the real 
  estate commission he paid to them.Â  The trial court ruled in favor of Century 
  21 in the amount of $9,250 based upon a 5% real estate commission and denied 
  Benfordâ€™s reimbursement request.Â  Benford and Century 21 appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for a real estate brokerâ€™s commission 
  is an action at law.Â  See United Farm Agency v. Malanuk, 284 S.C. 
  382, 383, 325 S.E.2d 544, 545 (1985).Â  In an action at law, tried without a 
  jury, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  no evidence exists which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings or the 
  decision is controlled by an error of law.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City 
  of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85-86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Benford argues the trial court erred in finding him 
  liable for breach of contract for refusing to pay a sales commission to Owens.Â  
  We agree.
A broker suing to recover his commission has the burden 
  of proving all the conditions precedent to his right to performance have occurred.Â  
  Chambers v. Pingree, 351 S.C. 442, 451, 570 S.E.2d 528, 532 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  In this case, the showing agreement specifically stated that Century 
  21 was entitled to a commission in consideration of (1) the revelation of the 
  identity of the purchasers and (2) the efforts of Century 21 in bringing about 
  the sale of the property.Â  The agreementâ€™s second condition precedent is consistent 
  with South Carolina case law, which provides a real estate broker generally 
  earns a commission when the broker acts during his agency as the efficient or 
  procuring cause of a sale.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 487, 486 
  S.E.2d 771, 775 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Although the actual agreement for the sale 
  may be made by the owner without the aid of the broker, the broker will be regarded 
  as the procuring cause if his intervention is the foundation upon which the 
  negotiation resulting in the sale is begun.Â  Id.Â  
There is no evidence in the record that supports 
  a conclusion that Owens was the procuring cause of the sale or that he was successful 
  in any efforts he made toward the sale. Owens admitted that Ballard was never 
  his client.Â  He stated he had spoken with Ballard over the years and knew he 
  was interested in property similar to Benfordâ€™s.Â  Owens testified that he called 
  Ballard after signing the agreement with Benford and told him about the property.Â  
  He related that although Ballard seemed very excited during that first call, 
  his enthusiasm had cooled by a second call and during the third call Ballard 
  â€œbrushed him off.â€Â  Owens acknowledged that he did nothing with Ballard other 
  than make those telephone calls.Â  He stated he never took Ballard to the property, 
  never took any offers from Ballard, and never held any earnest money.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  

Owensâ€™ slight contact with Ballard was in no way 
  the foundation upon which the negotiations began between Ballard and Benford.Â  
  While Owens merely had a telephone conversation with Ballard, Lachicotte provided 
  Ballard with plats and other written information on the property, walked the 
  property with Ballard, drafted and proposed the contract, and held and delivered 
  the earnest money.Â  Clearly, Lachicotte was intimately involved in pursuing 
  the property and closing on the sale.Â  It was Lachicotteâ€™s diligent and continuous 
  efforts that ultimately brought about the sale between Benford and Ballard.Â  
  Lachicotte, not Owens, was the procuring cause of the sale.Â  
Century 21 contends Owens did market the 
  property by contacting the prospective purchasers listed on the one-time showing 
  agreement, identifying and contacting additional prospective purchasers, and 
  taking prospective purchasers to the property.Â  We find these actions Owens 
  took in marketing the property to other potential purchasers did not entitle 
  Century 21 to a commission.Â  

A broker is never entitled to commissions for unsuccessful 
  efforts.Â  The risk of failure is wholly his.Â  The reward comes only with his 
  success.Â  That is the plain contract and contemplation of the parties.Â  The 
  broker may devote his time and labor, and expend his money with ever so much 
  devotion to the interests of his employer, and yet if he fails, if without effecting 
  an agreement or accomplishing a bargain, he abandons the effort, or his authority 
  is fairly and in good faith terminated, he gains no right to commissions.Â  He 
  loses the labor and effort which was staked upon success.Â  And in such event 
  it matters not that after his failure and the termination of his agency, what 
  he has done proves of use and benefit of the principal.

Swanson v. Stratos, 350 S.C. 116, 122, 564 
  S.E.2d 117, 120 (Ct. App. 2002).
The actions Century 21 took in marketing the property 
  to others does not alter the fact that it was not the procuring cause of the 
  sale of the property to Ballard.Â  As Century 21 was not the procuring cause 
  of the sale between Benford and Ballard, it was not entitled to a commission.Â  
  Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in finding Benford was liable for 
  breach of contract and awarding Century 21 a 5% commission.Â  Accordingly, the 
  judgment in favor of Century 21 for breach of contract is
 REVERSED. 
  [1]   
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1]  Because we find Benford is not 
    liable for breach of contract, we do not address the remaining issues on appeal.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John A. Hall,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Public Safety,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-357
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Francis L. Bell, Jr., of Lancaster, for Appellant.
Patrick M. Teague, of Blythewood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John A. Hall appeals a circuit 
  court ruling upholding the South Carolina Department of Public Safetyâ€™s order 
  suspending his driverâ€™s license for driving under the influence.Â  We affirm.
In November 2000, Hall was detained at a license 
  checkpoint conducted by the South Carolina Highway Patrol after a patrolman 
  detected the smell of alcohol in his car.Â  After Hall failed a field sobriety 
  test, he was placed under arrest and taken to the Lancaster Detention Center.Â  
  Once there, Hall took a breathalyzer test which indicated an alcohol concentration 
  of 0.18 percent.Â  Because Hall registered an alcohol concentration in excess 
  of 0.15 percent, his driverâ€™s license was immediately suspended. Â Hall 
  subsequently challenged the suspension in an administrative hearing but the 
  hearing officer sustained the suspension.Â  On its appellate review, the circuit 
  court likewise found no error and affirmed the suspension.Â Â  
Hall asserts the following errors: 1) the circuit court 
  should have remanded the case for further determination by the Hearing Officer 
  on the issue of the reliability and admissibility of the breathalyzer results; 
  2) the Hearing Officer erred by failing to dismiss the charges because the Department 
  did not introduce into evidence the videotapes of Hall at the site where he 
  was initially arrested or at the breathalyzer site; and 3) the Department erred 
  by failing to enter individual findings for each of the factual considerations 
  South Carolina Code section 56-5-2951 lists as being within the scope of an 
  administrative hearing for a person whose license was suspended for DUI.
We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following 
  authorities:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003) (limiting appellate 
  modification of agency decisions to those causing prejudice to substantial rights); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(A) (Supp. 2003) (â€œThe Department of Motor Vehicles 
  must suspend the driver's license â€¦ [of] a person who drives a motor vehicle 
  and â€¦ has an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent 
  or more.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(F) (Supp. 2003) (stating that the scope 
  of the administrative hearings on license suspension â€œmust be limited toâ€ several 
  specific topics); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(A) (Supp. 2003) (allowing any party 
  to the action to admit incident site or breath test site videotapes); Cooper 
  v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002) (holding that when 
  the terms of a statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according 
  to their literal meaning); State v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 6, 562 S.E.2d 
  472, 474 (2002) (holding breathalyzer results were admissible absent a showing 
  by the defendant of prejudice resulting from the use of the wrong concentration, 
  because â€œ[e]vidence the simulator test was not run in conformity with Act 434 
  goes to the weight, not the admissibility, of Huntleyâ€™s breathalyzer results.â€); 
  Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 369, 468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996) (holding 
  that words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting 
  to forced construction which limits or expands the statuteâ€™s operation); Worsley 
  Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 
  103, 567 S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding issue presented on appeal 
  was not preserved for review where appellant failed to raise the argument at 
  the trial level).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 

 
   [1]  Â We affirm this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Brown

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brandon Leandre Brown,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-358
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile of SC Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, forÂ  Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor E.L. Clements, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brandon Leandre Brown appeals 
  from his conviction and sentences for first-degree criminal sexual conduct with 
  a minor and for transmitting a sexual disease. 1Â  

1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s 
  refusal to direct a verdict of acquittal on the indictment charging Brown with 
  transmitting a sexual disease.Â  When reviewing the denial of a directed verdict 
  motion, the court of appeals must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 
  359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any 
  substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of 
  the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to 
  the jury.Â  State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 
  1999).Â  The evidence supported the finding that the victim in this case contracted 
  gonorrhea from Brown.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We need not address the issue of whether 
  the trial court erred in admitting Brownâ€™s second statement in evidence because 
  the police did not repeat the Miranda warnings to Brown prior to his 
  giving the statement.Â  The issue is not preserved for appellate review because 
  Brown never specifically raised the issue to the trial court and never received 
  an explicit ruling upon it.2Â  See State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 
  120, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997) (â€œ[An] exception is not preserved for review 
  because appellant simply made a general objection during the expertsâ€™ testimony 
  without giving the specific ground.Â  An issue may not be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved 
  for appellate review.â€); see also Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 
  56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991) (holding that where the circuit court did not explicitly 
  rule on an argument the issue was not properly before the court of appeals and 
  should not have been addressed by it). 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
  1 
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

 
  2Â Â  Although we do not address the 
    issue of whether the interrogating officer should have repeated to Brown the 
    Miranda warnings given him three hours and thirty-nine minutes before 
    he gave the second statement, other courts have held that repeated warnings 
    are not necessary to a finding that a defendant knowingly and intelligently 
    waived them in similar instances.Â  See United States v. Frankson, 
    83 F.3d 79 (4th Cir. 1996) (two and one-half hours); Jarrell v. Balkcom, 
    735 F.2d 1242 (11th Cir. 1984) (three hours); Commonwealth v. Silanskas, 
    746 N.E.2d 445 (Mass. 2001) (two hours); Bush v. State, 461 So. 2d 
    936 (Fla. 1984) (eleven hours); Fagan v. State, 412 So. 2d 1282 (Ala. 
    Crim. App. 1982) (three and one-half hours).Â  We also note that here the officer 
    reminded Brown of his rights before obtaining a second statement from him 
    and Brown appeared to have an understanding of his rights at that time.Â  See 
    State v. Smith, 259 S.C. 496, 192 S.E.2d 870 (1972) (wherein the supreme 
    court held the question of whether Miranda warnings should be repeated 
    at a later stage of interrogation after having been once given must be determined 
    on the basis of the facts and circumstances surrounding each case).

title: State v. Hart
text:

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jabbar Hart,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-359
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jabbar Hart (Appellant) appeals 
  his conviction for two counts of distribution of cocaine, contending the trial 
  court erred in admitting the cocaine into evidence due to alleged flaws in the 
  chain of custody.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following 
  authorities:Â  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 544 S.E.2d 835 (2001) (holding 
  evidence concerning the chain of custody should establish the chain as far as 
  practicable, but need not negate all evidence of tampering as long as the chain 
  is complete; in applying this rule, courts have found the evidence inadmissible 
  only where there is a missing link because the identity of those who handled 
  the specimen was not established as far as practicable; however, if the identity 
  of those who handled the specimen is established, evidence regarding its care 
  goes only to the weight of the evidence, not its admissibility); State v. 
  Singleton, 319 S.C. 312, 317, 460 S.E.2d 573, 576 (1995) (â€œThe party offering 
  evidence must trace possession of the substance and what was done with it from 
  the time it was taken until final analysis.â€); State v. Williams, 297 
  S.C. 290, 376 S.E.2d 773 (1989) (stating the admission of evidence requiring 
  a chain of custody is discretionary with the trial judge and will not be reversed 
  absent an abuse of that discretion).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Bell v. Boyd
text:

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Richard T. Bell,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gayle Meacher Boyd and
Robert Willis Bell,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Gayle Meacher Boyd is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
F.P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-360
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Cynthia B. Castengera, of Newland, NC and D. Dusty Rhoades, 
  of Charleston, for Appellant. 
Sally King-Gilreath of Mt.Â  Pleasant, and J. Mark Taylor, 
  of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Gayle Boyd appeals the family court 
  order requiring her to reimburse Robert Bell for post majority support payments.Â  
  Bell made payments to Boyd in the amount of $7,725.00, even though the partiesâ€™ 
  son, Robert, failed to attend college as was required for Bell to continue the 
  agreed-upon support obligation.Â  The court also awarded Bell attorneyâ€™s fees 
  in the aggregate sum of $15,269.44 at the rate $1,000 per month.Â  We affirm.
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The family court did not err in awarding 
  Bell reimbursement of overpayment of child support, even though the mediated 
  agreement did not call for reimbursement. The family court has authority to 
  order reimbursement of child support expenses. LaFitte v. LaFitte, 280 
  S.C. 473, 477, 313 S.E.2d 41, 44 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œThe question of child support 
  is largely within the discretion of the trial judge whose decision will not 
  be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€ Hopkins v. 
  Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 305, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The evidence 
  presented showed not only that Bellâ€™s support obligation should have ended, 
  but also that Boyd was aware, but attempted to deceive Bell to continue receiving 
  support payments.Â  Under the circumstances, the family court did not abuse its 
  discretion in ordering reimbursement of the child support overpayment.
2.Â  Â Â Â Â  The family court 
  did not err in requiring Boyd to pay attorneyâ€™s fees. â€œThe award of attorney 
  fees is within the discretion of the court.â€Â  Pendergast v. Pendergast, 
  354 S.C. 32, 39, 579 S.E.2d 530, 533 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Boyd has shown no abuse 
  of discretion.Â  In determining whether to award attorney fees, the court should 
  consider each party's ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results 
  obtained by the attorney, the parties' respective financial conditions, and 
  the effect of the fee on each party's standard of living. Wooten v. Wooten, 
  354 S.C. 242, 254â€“255, 580 S.E.2d 265, 771 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In determining 
  the amount of attorney fees to award, the court should consider the nature, 
  extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted 
  to the case, counsel's professional standing, the contingency of compensation, 
  the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services. 
  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
  Bell and Boyd stipulated that the attorneys would not have to testify regarding 
  fees. The family court reviewed the attorney affidavits and the itemized bills, 
  and made the requisite findings relating whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  the reasonable amount of fees.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
  [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Amadou Diabate,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
MUSC,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-361
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Amadou Diabate, of North Charleston, Pro se.
Robert H. Hood, Robert H. Hood, Jr., Roy P. Maybank, and 
  Deborah Harrison Sheffield, all of Charleston, for Respondent.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Diabate appeals the trial courtâ€™s 
  grant of summary judgment based on Diabateâ€™s failure to provide expert testimony.Â  
  We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 
  220, SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Sheppard v. Kimbrough, 282 
  S.C. 348, 356. 318 S.E.2d 573, 579 (Ct. App. 1984) (stating on a defendantâ€™s 
  motion for summary judgment, there is usually no genuine issue of material fact 
  unless the plaintiff presents expert testimony on the standard of care and its 
  breach by the defendant); Henson v. International Paper Co., ___ S.C. 
  ___, ___, 594 S.E.2d 499, 503 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œRule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR requires 
  an appellantâ€™s initial brief to contain a statement of each of the issues presented 
  for review.â€); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 
  (2003) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement 
  of issues on appeal."); Glasscock Inc., v. United States Fid. & 
  Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding 
  where an issue is not argued within the body of the brief but is only a short 
  conclusory statement, the issue is abandoned on appeal);Â  Fields v. Melrose 
  Ltd. Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (stating issues on appeal which are not argued in the brief are deemed abandoned 
  and will not be considered by the appellate court); State v. Burton, 
  356 S.C. 259, 265, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 n.5 (2003) (finding a pro se litigant 
  has full responsibility for complying with substantive and procedural requirements 
  of the law); Goodson v. American Bankers Ins. Co. of Fla., 295 S.C. 400, 
  403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (â€œLack of familiarity with legal proceedings is unacceptable 
  and the court will not hold a layman to any lesser standard than is applied 
  to an attorney.â€). 
 AFFIRMED.
HOWARD, BEATTY, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THIS
OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT
SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS
PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
David W. Goldman and Emilie E. Goldman,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
RBC, Inc.,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-362
Submitted May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  4, 2004

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Edward Bell, III, of Sumter, for Appellant.
Kristi F. Curtis, of Sumter, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  RBC, Inc. appeals the trial courtâ€™s 
  grant of summary judgment to David and Emily Goldman in this action to quiet 
  title to a railroad track adjacent to the Goldmansâ€™ property. RBC contends that 
  its predecessor in interest acquired a fee simple in the property because the 
  owners did not apply for an assessment or compensation within ten years of the 
  railroadâ€™s completion. 
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following 
  authorities:Â  Faulkenberry v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co., 349 S.C. 318, 325, 
  563 S.E.2d 644, 648 (2002) (â€œWe adhere to the wealth of authority in this state 
  and hold that [the statutory grants] created only an easement in the [r]ailroads.â€); 
  Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 503 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 
  1998) (holding that a railroadâ€™s interest acquired through a statutory presumption 
  of grant is a mere easementÂ  under South Carolina law). 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â

title: SCDSS v. Hamlin
text:
<!--

	{text-align:justify;

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Carlos L. Hamlin,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-363
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Carlos L. Hamlin, Pro Se, for Appellant.
Harry O. Shaw, III, of the South Carolina Department of Social 
  Services, Child Support Enforcement Division, Charleston, S.C., for Respondents.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM: Â The family court ordered 
  $6,330 held by the Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department as proceeds from the 
  collection of a civil judgment in favor of Carlos L. Hamlin to be applied to 
  Hamlinâ€™s four overdue child support obligations, three of which had been reduced 
  to child support judgments.Â  Hamlin appeals. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL 
  BACKGROUND
Hamlin fathered five children raised in four separate 
  custodial families. Each time, the custodial parent received assistance from 
  SCDSS and assigned child support rights to SCDSS.Â  SCDSS brought actions for 
  support and Hamlin was ordered to pay support for each child by the family court. 

Subsequently, one custodial parent terminated subsistence 
  through SCDSS, and an order was entered by the family court on February 9, 1999, 
  determining the amount still owed in support for that child up to that time. 
  Thereafter, Hamlin began receiving Supplemental Social Security, and Hamlin 
  and SCDSS entered into a consent order on August 8, 2001, terminating the support 
  obligations as to the remaining custodial households.Â  In this consent order, 
  the court determined the amount of unpaid support for each case due and owing 
  by Hamlin, reducing those amounts to judgments. No appeal was taken from either 
  order.
On October 7, 2002, SCDSS learned from the sheriffâ€™s 
  department that Hamlin would be receiving $6,330 in payment of a civil judgment 
  on October 10, 2002. SCDSS applied to the family court and obtained an order 
  requiring the funds to be paid to the clerk of the family court pending any 
  objection by Hamlin. The order recited the amount of each unpaid child support 
  obligation, and gave Hamlin ten days in which to file any objection he had to 
  applying the funds to those overdue obligations.
Hamlin received a copy of the order from the Sheriffâ€™s Office 
  and thereafter objected. A hearing was held before Judge Armstrong pursuant 
  to notice. At the hearing, Hamlin appeared and argued he had not received notice 
  prior to the issuance of the initial order. He further argued one of the overdue 
  obligations had not been reduced to a judgment. 
Concluding Hamlin failed to give any reasons why the funds 
  should not be paid to the custodial families in partial satisfaction of the 
  debts, the court ordered payment to the custodial families on a pro-rata basis. 

DISCUSSION
  I.      Notice 
   
Hamlin first argues he did not receive notice as required 
  under S.C. Code Ann. section 20-7-1295 (2003).Â  We disagree.Â  
The initial notice requirements of section 20-7-1295 
  deal with notice to the child support obligor of past due child support. See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1295 (B) (â€œWhen the division determines that child support 
  is unpaid in an amount equal to or greater than one thousand dollars, it shall 
  send written notice to the obligor by first-class mail to the obligor's last 
  known address, as filed with the tribunal pursuant to Section 20-7-854.â€).Â  
  However, this notice is not necessary here because the child support as to three 
  of the obligations was already reduced to a judgment by consent order on August 
  8, 2001.Â  As to the fourth obligation, it was reduced to a sum certain 
  by previous final order. Therefore, Hamlin had actual notice of the amounts 
  equal to or exceeding one thousand dollars claimed in unpaid child support.
Hamlin also argues notice was required in accordance 
  with section 20-7-1295 (C).Â Â  He specifically argues this was necessary to perfect 
  a lien against real property.Â  However, there is nothing in the record to suggest 
  a lien was obtained against real property owned by Hamlin.Â  Furthermore, this 
  issue was not raised to or ruled on by the family court. Bakala v. Bakala, 
  352 S.C. 612, 576 S.E.2d 156 (2003)(ruling an issue not raised and ruled upon 
  by the family court will not be addressed on appeal).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In any event, subsection (C) deals with the manner 
  of perfecting liens by filing the requisite notice in the correct office responsible 
  for recording and maintaining liens in respect to the type of property involved.Â  
  It does not add a notice requirement to the obligor.
The other pertinent notice provision in Â§ 20-7-1295 
  states:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

(H) The division shall send timely written notice 
  to the obligor by first-class mail of any action taken to perfect a lien, execute 
  a levy, or seize any property.Â  The notice shall specify the amount due, the 
  steps to be followed to release the property so placed under lien, levied, or 
  seized, and the time period within which to respond to the notice and shall 
  include the name of the court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction 
  which entered the child support order.

Clearly this provision is designed to 
  give the obligor notice of â€œany action takenâ€ to perfect a lien or execute a 
  levy, and to provide an opportunity to be heard.Â  Here, the court provided that 
  notice and Hamlin was afforded an opportunity to be heard. Therefore, this argument 
  is without merit.
Finally, Hamlin argues the lack of proper notice 
  constituted a Due Process violation.Â  However, Hamlin provided no analysis or 
  authority for this argument.Â  Issues are deemed abandoned and thus not presented 
  for appellate review where they are argued using only short, conclusory statements, 
  without supporting authority.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. United States Fid. & 
  Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001); see 
  also First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 
  514 (1994) (holding appellant was deemed to have abandoned issues on appeal, 
  where he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority); R & 
  G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 437, 540 
  S.E.2d 113, 120 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding where no authority is cited and argument 
  is brief and conclusory, issue is deemed abandoned).Â  Therefore, we deem this 
  issued abandoned.
  II.     Notice Under Family Court Rule 17(a) 
   
Hamlin next argues SCDSS failed to comply with Rule 17, SCRFC.Â  
  However, this rule is clearly inapplicable, as it deals with notice to a non-answering 
  defendant of the time and date of the hearing on the merits.Â  In any event, 
  as stated previously, Hamlin received notice and attended the hearing.Â  Therefore, 
  this issue is manifestly without merit.
III.Â     Jurisdiction
Hamlin couches his last argument 
  as jurisdictional, claiming the family court did not have jurisdiction to â€œsupercedeâ€ 
  a prior court order directing a judgment â€œwithout due process.â€Â  However, his 
  argument does not pertain to the stated exception.Â  Instead, Hamlin alludes 
  to the fact that the applicant was SCDSS as opposed to the individual obliges.Â  
  He then repeats his assertion that no timely notices were afforded him, thereby 
  violating Due Process.Â  Lastly, he argues the initial order seizing the funds 
  â€œgot the cart before the horseâ€ because no determination had been made that 
  he was the obligor and that the money seized was his.
We conclude Hamlin presents no discernable argument 
  and no authority for his position.Â  Issues are deemed abandoned and thus not 
  presented for appellate review where they are argued using only short, conclusory 
  statements, without supporting authority.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. United States 
  Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001); 
  see also First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 
  513, 514 (1994) (holding appellant was deemed to have abandoned issues on appeal, 
  where he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority); R & 
  G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 437, 540 
  S.E.2d 113, 120 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding where no authority is cited and argument 
  is brief and conclusory, issue is deemed abandoned).Â  Therefore, these issues 
  are deemed abandoned on appeal.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order 
  of the family court is
AFFIRMED.  [1]  
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving any issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

title: Maples v. Myers
text:

.MsoSubtitle
	{text-align:center;

	font-family:Arial;
	color:black;
	font-weight:bold;}

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michael Andrew Maples,       
Appellant.
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Donald V. Myers and Samuel R. Hubbard, III and Wayne Wilson,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-364
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael A. Maples, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
Lake E. Summers and Thomas C. R. Legare, Jr., both of Columbia; 
  and Vinton DeVane Lide, of Lexington, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Andrew Maples (â€œAppellantâ€) 
  appeals a circuit court order granting summary judgment in favor of Donald V. 
  Myers, Samuel R. Hubbard, III, and Wayne Wilson (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€) 
  dismissing all of Appellantâ€™s claims against them.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
This matter arises from the seizure of Appellantâ€™s 
  1988 Pontiac Firebird and a number of weapons in connection with his arrest 
  on multiple charges including â€œTrafficking in Marijuanaâ€ and â€œTrafficking in 
  Marijuana Within Proximity of a School.â€
On April 22, 1995, respondent Wayne Wilson, then 
  Chief of Police for the town of South Congaree, was informed a citizen had discovered 
  a number of small cups containing plants which he believed were marijuana while 
  walking in a wooded area within town limits.Â  Later that day, a South Carolina 
  Law Enforcement Division (â€œSLEDâ€) agent accompanied Wilson to the site.Â  On 
  April 25, SLED agents set up a motion activated video camera at the grow site.Â  
  During this period of video surveillance, Appellant visited the area several 
  times and tended to the marijuana plants.Â  On June 7, one hundred and ninety-four 
  (194) marijuana plants were confiscated from the grow site.Â  During the search 
  of the area, an army duffel bag was found containing an M-1 rifle and ammunition.
Following the seizure of the marijuana crop, SLED 
  agents arrested Appellant in West Columbia and transported him to the South 
  Congaree Police Department.Â  After the arrest, other SLED agents took custody 
  of Appellantâ€™s personal vehicle, a 1988 Pontiac Firebird, at his place of work 
  in Richland County and towed it to the South Congaree Police Department. 
  [1] Â  
While in custody and after being advised of his rights, 
  Appellant voluntarily executed a detailed written statement.Â  In the statement, 
  Appellant admits he germinated marijuana seeds and hauled the germinated seeds, 
  plant food, and potting soil to the grow site in his Pontiac Firebird.Â  He told 
  Wilson he germinated the marijuana seeds in his bedroom.Â  Appellant also admitted 
  his involvement in three earlier shooting incidents, one in which Appellant 
  fired the weapon found at the grow site seven times into an occupied mobile 
  home.Â  Following the statement, Appellant gave Wilson written consent to search 
  his padlocked bedroom in his motherâ€™s home.Â  In the course of this search, seven 
  loaded weapons were found and seized.Â  On June 8, 1995, Wilson filed an â€œInitial 
  Report of Seizureâ€ covering the property seized from Appellantâ€™s bedroom.Â  On 
  June 14, he filed a similar report concerning Appellantâ€™s vehicle.Â  The solicitorâ€™s 
  office, however, did not file a final forfeiture complaint against any of this 
  property until May 2000, almost five years after the propertyâ€™s seizure.Â  
Appellant was indicted by the grand jury for â€œManufacturing 
  and Possession of Marijuana With Intent to Distribute Within Proximity of a 
  Schoolâ€ and â€œTrafficking in Marijuanaâ€ in violation of South Carolina Code section 
  44-53-370(e)(1)(b).Â  Although Appellant pled guilty to the proximity charge, 
  the trafficking charge was pled down to â€œManufacturing in Marijuana 2nd.â€Â  
  For these offenses, Appellant was sentenced to a total of seven years imprisonment. 
  He later pled guilty to discharging a firearm into a dwelling and three counts 
  of assault with intent to kill, for which he received two consecutive ten-year 
  prison terms.
In 1998, Appellant brought a civil action against Wilson, 
  both individually and in his official capacity as chief of the South Congaree 
  Police Department, alleging unlawful conversion of the above mentioned seized 
  property.Â  After several amendments to his original complaint, Appellant served 
  Respondents with the final version of the underlying lawsuit in June 2000.Â  
  The final complaint, among other claims, added Respondents Donald V. Myers, 
  circuit solicitor, and his assistant, Samuel R. Hubbard, III, as new defendants 
  under a theory of civil conspiracy.Â  The thrust of Appellantâ€™s lawsuit appeared 
  to be that Wilson improperly seized his vehicle and weapons, and, by failing 
  to comply with the forfeiture statutes in a timely manner, Respondents conspired 
  to deprive Appellant of his property and are liable for conversion.
In November 2000, Wilson moved for summary judgment 
  on all causes of action.Â  Following a grant of this motion, Appellant filed 
  a motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  In June 2001, while Appellantâ€™s motion 
  was pending, Myers and Hubbard filed their own motion for summary judgment.Â  
  Wilson joined this motion, as it pertained to issues raised against him in Appellantâ€™s 
  pending motion to alter or amend.Â  Following a combined hearing on both motions, 
  summary judgment was granted to Myers and Hubbard and Appellantâ€™s motion to 
  alter or amend was dismissed.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the 
  disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins 
  v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); George v. Fabri, 
  345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  When reviewing the grant of 
  a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs 
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists, P.A. 
  v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 108-9, 584 S.E.2d 375, 
  377 (2003); Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  
  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all 
  factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light most favorable to 
  the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Public Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 
  354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003); Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 
  353 S.C. 449, 455-56, 578 S.E.2d 711, 714 (2003).Â  
DISCUSSION
Appellant raises several issues on 
  appeal, all ostensibly pertaining to his underlying claims against Respondents 
  for the illegal conversion of the above mentioned seized property, allegedly 
  perpetuated by civil conspiracy.Â  Conversion is an unlawful act defined as â€œthe 
  unauthorized assumption and exercise of the rights of ownership over 
  goods or personal chattels belonging to another . . . to the exclusion of the 
  ownerâ€™s rights.â€Â  Powell v. A.K. Brown Motor Co., 200 S.C. 75, 78, 20 
  S.E.2d 636, 637 (1942); Green v. Waidner, 284 S.C. 35, 37, 324 S.E.2d 
  331, 333 (Ct. App. 1984) (emphasis added).Â  The tort of conversion, therefore, 
  â€œcannot spring from the exercise of a legal right.â€Â  Steele v. Victory Sav. 
  Bank, 295 S.C. 290, 296, 368 S.E.2d 91, 94 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Appellant asserts, 
  due to several alleged statutory violations, the seizure and subsequent forfeiture 
  of his property was not a proper exercise of Respondentsâ€™ legal rights, and 
  therefore, each is personally liable for the conversion of his property.Â  We 
  disagree.
I. Â Â Â Â Â  Civil Conspiracy
Appellant seems to contend that each respondent 
  is individually liable for the acts of the other respondents under a theory 
  of civil conspiracy.Â  We find this theory of imputation without merit.
In South Carolina a civil conspiracy requires: (1) 
  a combination of two or more persons; (2) for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff; 
  (3) which cause the plaintiff special damages.Â  Vaught v. Waites, 300 
  S.C. 201, 208, 387 S.E.2d 91, 95 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œ[I]n order to establish 
  a conspiracy, evidence, direct or circumstantial, must be produced from which 
  a party may reasonably infer the joint assent of the minds of two or more parties.â€Â  
  Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 601, 358 S.E.2d 150, 153 
  (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
Appellant failed to provide any evidence from which 
  one could infer a meeting of the minds between Respondents.Â  In fact, the only 
  alleged communication of any kind between Wilson and the Solicitorâ€™s Office 
  is the statutorily required seizure notice.Â  Notwithstanding this courtâ€™s standard 
  of review, an argument based on mere suggestion and speculation should not survive 
  a motion for summary judgment when no evidence is presented which creates a 
  material issue of fact on the issue.Â  See Rule 56(e), SCRCP.Â  We therefore 
  agree with the trial court in that, as a matter of law, the conspiracy claim 
  must fail.Â  As such, we address the possible personal liability of Myers and 
  Hubbard (circuit solicitor and assistant solicitor who commenced final forfeiture 
  proceedings against Appellantâ€™s property) separately from that of Wilson (sheriff 
  who initially seized the property).
II. Â Â Â Â  Personal Liability of Myers and Hubbard
Appellant contends that Myers and 
  Hubbard are personally liable for the value of his seized property because 
  the final proceedings for forfeiture were commenced in an untimely fashion.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
There is no need to address the merits of Appellantâ€™s 
  various assertions that the proper statutory forfeiture procedures were not 
  followed to the letter.Â  It is uncontested that section 44-53-530 grants the 
  solicitorâ€™s office the power to petition the circuit court for the forfeiture 
  of property seized under 44-53-520.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-530 (2002) (â€œ(a) 
  Forfeiture of property defined in Section 44-53-520 must be accomplished by 
  petition of . . . the circuit solicitor or his designeeâ€). As such, Myers and 
  Hubbard, when commencing the final forfeiture proceedings, were acting solely 
  in their official, not personal, capacities.
Even assuming the efficacy of the alleged 
  statutory violations (namely that Myers and Hubbard purposefully delayed in 
  commencing final forfeiture proceedings against Appellantâ€™s property in violation 
  of section 44-53-520 and various statutes of limitation 
  [2] ), because Myers and Hubbard acted in no way outside their official 
  capacities as prosecutorial agents of the State, they enjoy an absolute immunity 
  from civil suits.Â  See Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 553 S.E.2d 
  496 (Ct. App. 2001) (discussing in great length the history, policy and modern 
  application of prosecutorial immunity from civil liability).Â  While we do not 
  in any way condone the solicitorâ€™s officeâ€™s undue delay in bringing final forfeiture 
  proceedings following the propertyâ€™s seizure, Appellant states no plausible 
  grounds in his pleadings for Myers or Hubbardâ€™s personal liability for the value 
  of Appellantâ€™s property.
Appellant seems to assert on appeal, albeit 
  vaguely, that he is statutorily provided a remedy by South Carolina section 
  44-56-586, which reads as follows:

(a) Any innocent owner . . . may apply to court of 
  common pleas for the return of any item seized under the provisions of Â§ 44-53-520.

* * * * *

(b) The court may return any seized item to the owner 
  if the owner demonstrates to the court by a preponderance of the evidence:
(1) in the case of an innocent owner, that the person 
  or entity was not a consenting party to, or privy to, or did not have knowledge 
  of, the use of the property which made it subject to seizure and forfeiture.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-586 (2002). 
Section 44-53-586 lends Appellant no support.Â  
  First, it would border on frivolity to suggest Appellant qualifies as an â€œinnocent 
  owner.â€Â  Second, nothing in this section grants an owner a civil cause of action 
  for damages against state agents for carrying out the forfeiture proceedings 
  on behalf of the State.Â  As such, we conclude the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary 
  judgment to respondents Myers and Hubbard was proper. [3] 
III. Â Â  Personal Liability of Wilson
We first make note that none of Appellantâ€™s 
  issues concerning the final forfeiture proceedings against his property properly 
  apply to Wilson.Â  It is specifically provided in the first sentence of section 
  44-53-530 that forfeiture proceedings â€œmust be accomplished by petition of the 
  Attorney General or his designee or the circuit solicitor or his designee.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-530 (2002). Accordingly, because Wilson did not have 
  authority to institute forfeiture proceedings, he could not have any duty to 
  do so nor any liability to Appellant for failure to do so in a timely manner.
However, as Appellant, again rather vaguely, appears 
  to argue Wilson is liable for conversion and concomitant damages arising from 
  the unlawful seizure of his property, we address legality of that seizure.Â  
  See Steele, 295 S.C. atÂ  296, 368 S.E.2d at 94 (Ct. App. 1988)(holding 
  that conversion cannot arise from the exercise of a legal right).
Appellant contends that the initial seizure of his 
  property was unlawful because: 1) no finding was made as to the weight of the 
  marijuana; 2) there was no probable cause to seize the weapons found in his 
  bedroom; and 3) his vehicle was towed from a location outside of respondent 
  Wilsonâ€™s jurisdiction.

A. Â Â Â Â  Weight of Marijuana

Appellant argues that his vehicle 
  was unlawfully seized because the State failed make a finding as to the weight 
  of the marijuana found at the grow site prior to the vehicleâ€™s seizure.Â  Appellantâ€™s 
  property was seized pursuant to South Carolina Code section 44-53-520(b), which 
  reads:
Any property subject to forfeiture under this article 
  may be seized . . . Seizure without process may be made if . . . (4) the department 
  has probable cause to believe that the property was used or is intended to be 
  used in violation of this article.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-520(b) (2002).Â  Appellant contends 
  Wilson had no probable cause to seize the vehicle because, without a determination 
  of the marijuanaâ€™s weight, the property was not determinatively â€œused . . . 
  in violation of [the] article.â€Â  
Appellant erroneously bases this argument on the following 
  language of section 44-53-520, the statute which makes certain property subject 
  to forfeiture to the State when used to facilitate the â€œproduction, manufacturing, 
  distribution, sale, importation, exportation, or traffickingâ€ of controlled 
  substances:
No motor vehicle may be forfeited to the State under 
  this item unless it is used, intended for use, or in any manner facilitates 
  a violation of Section 44-53-370(a), involving at least one pound or more of 
  marijuana . . .
S.C. Code Ann. 44-53-520 (2002).Â  Appellant, however, 
  overlooks the fact that this statute, continues to read â€œ . . . or unless 
  it is used . . . or in any manner facilitates a violation of Section 44-53-370(e).â€Â  
  Id. (emphasis added)
Section 44-53-370(e) defines the offense 
  of â€œtrafficking in marijuanaâ€ as the cultivation of â€œone hundred to one thousand 
  marijuana plants regardless of weight.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 44-53-370(e)(1)(b) (2002).Â  
  In his written statement, Appellant confessed to the cultivation of approximately 
  200 marijuana plants and the specific use of his vehicle in facilitating such.Â  
  A signed written statement confessing to a charged offense as well as specifically 
  outlining the use of certain property in facilitating that offense certainly 
  provided the police with section 44-53-520â€™s requisite probable cause for the 
  propertyâ€™s seizure.Â  Because Appellantâ€™s vehicle was seized pursuant to the 
  forfeiture statuteâ€™s reference to 44-53-370(e)(1)(b) and not 370(a) (which is 
  limited to only those offenses involving at least one pound of marijuana), a 
  finding of the plantâ€™s actual weight was unnecessary. 

B. Â Â Â Â  Probable Cause to Seize the Weapons Found 
  in Appellantâ€™s Bedroom

Appellant argues that the seizure 
  of the weapons and other items from his bedroom was unlawful because Wilson 
  lacked probable cause to seize the items.Â  Again, Appellantâ€™s own confession 
  went beyond the threshold of probable cause in regard to the propertyâ€™s use 
  in facilitating a violation of 44-53-370(e).
Appellant admitted in writing to cultivating 
  the marijuana found at the grow site.Â  He stated to Wilson that the germination 
  of the crop, mentioned in the written statement, took place in his bedroom.Â  
  He also admitted to involvement in three shooting incidents involving firearms 
  located in the bedroom.Â  Furthermore, Appellant agreed in writing to allow a 
  search of the padlocked bedroom (located in his parentâ€™s home).Â  â€œThe mere probability 
  that a crime is being committed [or, as here, that property is being used in 
  furtherance of a crime], rather than a prima facie showing of criminal [use], 
  is the standard probable cause.â€Â  State v. Dean, 282 S.C. 136, 139, 317 
  S.E.2d 744, 745 (1984).Â  The above confession and the location of the weapons 
  in such close proximity to the admitted germinating area of the marijuana crop 
  provided Wilson with requisite probable cause that the items were subject to 
  forfeiture under section 44-53-520, thus, their seizure was proper.

C. Â Â Â Â  The Towing of the Vehicle

Appellant also argues Wilson personally 
  towed Appellantâ€™s vehicle from an area outside of Wilsonâ€™s jurisdiction, thus, 
  he is liable in an individual capacity for the conversion of Appellantâ€™s vehicle.Â  
  We find this argument without merit.Â  
According to Wilson, SLED agents towed Appellantâ€™s 
  vehicle to the South Congaree Police Department, where Wilson later executed 
  a seizure report.Â  Appellant submitted no evidence at the hearing to refute 
  Wilsonâ€™s account of the towing.Â  His assertions as to Wilsonâ€™s personal actions 
  are, in fact, pure speculation as Appellant was in custody at the time of the 
  towing.Â  Furthermore, Appellantâ€™s argument that Wilsonâ€™s alleged behavior gives 
  rise to personal liability is wholly conclusory, as Appellant cites no authority 
  for this position.Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity & Guar. 
  Co., 348 S.C. 76, 557 S.E.2d 689 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law clearly 
  states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are 
  deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€)Â  Finally, 
  Appellantâ€™s unlawful jurisdiction theory in regard to Wilsonâ€™s alleged towing 
  of the Firebird is raised for the first time on appeal, thus unpreserved for 
  out review.Â  See Fraternal Order of Police v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Revenue, 352 S.C. 420, 435, 574 S.E.2d 717, 725 (2002) (â€œGenerally, claims 
  or defenses not presented in the pleadings will not be considered on appeal.â€)
CONCLUSION
The grant of summary judgment in favor 
  of Respondents is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Appellant asserts that Wilson, not SLED, personally towed 
    the vehicle. 

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-520 (2002) (â€œIn the event of seizure 
    pursuant to subsection (b), proceedings under Â§ 44-53-530 regarding forfeiture 
    and disposition must be instituted within a reasonable timeâ€); see 
    also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-550 (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  As our grounds for affirming the trial court are not precisely 
    those raised by Respondentsâ€™ briefs, we cite Rule 220(c), SCACR, and Iâ€™On, 
    L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420-21, 526 S.E.2d 716, 
    724 (2000), for the proposition that an appellate court any affirm the lower 
    courtâ€™s judgment for any reason appearing in the record.
