THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Janet B. Agnew, Employee,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Spartanburg County School District No. 3, Employer, and South Carolina 
        School Board Insurance Trust, Carrier,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-365
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed June 10, 
  2004

VACATED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Andrew Nathan Safran, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Michael A. Farry, and David A. Wilson, both of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Janet Agnew 
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision affirming the Full Commissionâ€™s ruling 
  that Agnew sustained a compensable injury to her back and was entitled to permanent 
  partial disability of 40%.Â  We vacate and remand.
FACTS
 Janet Agnew worked for Spartanburg County School District No. 3 
  as a teacher for approximately twenty-two years.Â  On September 19, 1995, she 
  sustained injuries while at school after tripping over tape that was stuck to 
  the floor.Â  Initially, Dr. Howard Tiller treated her for pain in her knees, 
  ankle, and shoulder.Â  Subsequently, Dr. Tiller saw her for pain in her lower 
  back. She was prescribed physical therapy, which included the use of a TENS 
  device.Â  It was noted that the TENS device helped relieve some pain.Â  
On September 16, 1996, Dr. Tiller found:Â  1) Agnew continued to have 
  back pain resulting from her September 1995 accident; 2) x-rays revealed degenerative 
  disk disease; 3) she had reached maximum medical improvement (MMI) and suffered 
  a 10% permanent physical impairment to her back; and 4) the TENS unit had helped 
  and was the most appropriate treatment to continue.Â  
Agnew continued seeing Dr. Tiller periodically, and on December 23, 
  1997, received an MRI, which indicated degenerative change. Â In February 
  1998, Dr. Tiller noted Agnew had several lumbar epidurals, which helped considerably 
  with her leg pain.Â  Agnewâ€™s counsel discussed the back injury with Dr. Tiller 
  in February 1998.Â  Dr. Tiller indicated the back pain/injury was related to 
  the September 1995 fall.Â  He further found:Â  the fall probably aggravated a 
  pre-existing degenerative disk disease; Agnewâ€™s treatment had been â€œgeared toward 
  lessening her overall period of disability;â€ and that given her progression 
  of symptoms required further treatment she had not reached MMI and would need 
  a surgical consultation from an orthopaedic spine specialist. 
Agnew was referred to Dr. Gerald Rollins for a surgical opinion as to her lower 
  back.Â  Dr. Rollins found she had moderately severe degenerative disk disease.Â  
  After initially refusing surgery, Agnew underwent a discectomy and a fusion 
  of the L5-S1 disk space.Â  The surgery improved her condition, though she continued 
  having pain and restricted motion. 
In July 1998, Agnew retired from her position as a schoolteacher.Â  She testified 
  that she was not physically able to perform the work.Â  Even though she was offered 
  other positions within the School District, she chose to remain retired.Â  
In January 1999, Dr. Rollins released Agnew from active treatment.Â  He found 
  the fusion should have solidified and indicated she needed medication for pain.Â  
  In June 1999, he found that the use of Ultram for pain was in Agnewâ€™s long-term 
  benefit, determined she had a 12% permanent impairment to her back, and found 
  she had reached MMI.Â  In response to a questionnaire by the School District, 
  Dr. Rollins indicated in September 1999 that Agnew reached MMI in May 1999 and 
  her impairment was 10% to the spine.Â  
On April 7, 2000, Agnew underwent another evaluation, this time by Dr. Glenn 
  Scott.Â  Dr. Scott took Agnewâ€™s history, noted that she relied upon pain medications, 
  and concluded:Â  1) she had reached MMI; 2) she would need to continue on pain 
  medications; and 3) assigned a total impairment to the back of 25%, which he 
  allocated as 20% to the injury and 5% to pre-existing conditions. Â 
Dr. Donald Johnson evaluated Agnew in August 2000.Â  He indicated:Â  1) the surgery 
  had helped to some degree; 2) she had to walk with a cane; and 3) she had extremely 
  limited range of motion.Â  Based on these findings, he concluded: 1) she had 
  reached MMI; 2) she sustained a 25% impairment to the spine; 3) she sustained 
  a 25% impairment to the whole person; and 4) that Agnew would not be able to 
  return to the workplace as a teacher. 
The following day, Agnew met with Dr. William Stewart for a determination of 
  vocational rehabilitation.Â  He noted the significance of her continued pain 
  and reliance upon pain medication.Â  He indicated it would be impossible for 
  her to return as a schoolteacher and that the use of the pain medication and 
  lower back pain made it difficult for her to even do sedentary work.Â  His final 
  conclusion was:Â  

[I]t is concluded that her prognosis for successful vocational rehabilitation 
  to some kind of lighter, alternative work or job has to be considered very poor 
  to nonexistent.Â  That is, Ms. Agnew will most likely remain unable to work and 
  vocationally disabled, as I do not believe a reasonably stable job market exists 
  for the types of services she is physically capable to providing/sustaining, 
  despite her level of education/sophistication.Â  

After receiving temporary total disability compensation in December 
  1998, Agnew filed for permanent total workerâ€™s compensation benefits.Â  The single 
  commissioner held a hearing on October 31, 2000.Â  Agnew testified she continued 
  to experience significant lower back pain and required pain medication.Â  She 
  also testified that she could not sit or stand for long periods of time.Â  While 
  admitting to taking trips to both Hawaii and London, she testified that if she 
  increased her activity, she must take time off to recover.Â  
The single commissioner found Agnew had experienced an injury by 
  accident while employed by the School District, and the injury resulted in a 
  30% permanent partial disability to her back.Â  Agnew appealed this decision 
  to the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Full Commission).Â  
  Her appeal contested many of the factual findings of the single commissioner 
  and asked that she be found more than 50% disabled.Â  
The Full Commission was split in its decision.Â  The majority issued 
  an opinion that found:Â  Agnew sustained a compensable injury by accident; had 
  received proper medical treatment since the accident; and had reached MMI on 
  May 1, 1999.Â  The majority concluded that Agnew was entitled to permanent partial 
  disability of 40%.Â  
The dissenting member of the Full Commission found:Â  the majority 
  overlooked significant evidence; â€œneither sufficiently analyze[d] this evidence 
  nor addresse[d] its impact upon the primary issue in dispute; and . . . disregard[ed] 
  the only reasonable inference which may be gleaned from the evidence contained 
  in the hearing record.â€Â  The dissent articulated her belief that the majority 
  failed to make specific findings of fact as required, and that the implicit 
  findings of fact were insufficient to support their conclusion.Â  The dissent 
  concluded that Agnew was entitled to an award of permanent and total disability 
  compensation.Â  
On appeal to the circuit court, Agnew contended the Full Commission:Â  
  erred in finding she only had a 40% permanent disability to her back; failed 
  to make specific and sufficient findings of fact; and erred in not finding she 
  suffered greater than a 50% disability to her back.Â  The circuit court affirmed 
  the ruling of the Full Commission, finding its decision of 40% disability was 
  supported by substantial evidence and that the findings of fact made by the 
  Full Commission were â€œlegally and sufficiently detailed.â€Â  However, in making 
  its own determination, the circuit court included over three pages of evidence 
  to support its conclusion that was never specifically mentioned by the Full 
  Commissionâ€™s majority order. Agnew filed a motion for reconsideration pursuant 
  to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The circuit court denied this motion.Â  Agnew appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard 
  of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  
  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981). 
  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  
  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  
  In an appeal from the Commission, this Court may not substitute its judgment 
  for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of 
  fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003); Ellis v. Spartan Mills, 
  276 S.C. 216, 217, 277 S.E.2d 590, 591 (1981).Â  We can reverse or modify the 
  Full Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been 
  prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly 
  erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the 
  whole record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003); Adams v. Texfi 
  Indus., 341 S.C. 401, 404, 535 S.E.2d 124, 125 (2000).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence 
  is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such 
  evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds 
  to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. 
  at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
DISCUSSION
I.
Agnew argues the circuit court erred in affirming the decision of 
  the Full Commission given the Commissionâ€™s findings were not sufficiently detailed 
  for a proper review of the ultimate holding.Â  She maintains the Full Commission 
  never explained its determination that Agnew was 40% disabled as compared to 
  the 30% found by the single commissioner or the more than 50% found by the Commissionâ€™s 
  dissenting member.Â  Finally, Agnew contends there was uncontradicted evidence 
  that was neither examined nor explained by the Full Commission.Â  We agree with 
  Agnew that the Commissionâ€™s failure to make specific findings of fact necessitates 
  that we remand this case to the Commission. 
Under the provisions of the Administrative Procedures Act, â€œ[a] final 
  decision shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law, separately stated.Â  
  Findings of fact, if set forth in statutory language, shall be accompanied by 
  a concise and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (1986).Â  Section 42-17-40 of the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act also requires that an award include â€œa statement of the findings of fact, 
  rulings of law, and other matters pertinent to the questions at issue.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-40(A) (Supp. 2003).Â Â 
Although the findings of fact and conclusions of law of an administrative body 
  need not be presented in any particular format, they â€œmust be sufficiently detailed 
  to enable the reviewing court to determine whether the findings are supported 
  by the evidence.â€Â  Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 66, 456 
  S.E.2d 366, 367-68 (1995); Able Communications, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. 
  Serv. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 409, 411, 351 S.E.2d 151, 152 (1986).Â  â€œWithout specific 
  and definite findings upon the evidence, a court on review of the panelâ€™s decision 
  cannot determine whether to uphold the general finding or conclusion . . . .â€Â  
  Baldwin v. James River Corp., 304 S.C. 485, 486, 405 S.E.2d 421, 422 
  (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Implicit findings of fact are not sufficient.Â  Aristizabal 
  v. Woodside-Div. of Dan River, Inc., 268 S.C. 366, 370-71, 234 S.E.2d 21, 
  23 (1977).Â  Where material facts are in dispute, the administrative body must 
  make specific, express findings of fact.Â  Id.Â Â Â 
In Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #7, 341 S.C. 580, 590-91, 535 S.E.2d 
  146, 151 (Ct. App. 2000), this Court explained the procedural necessity of specific 
  findings of fact, stating:

The commission must make specific findings of fact upon which a claimantâ€™s right 
  to compensation are based.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (1986); Shealy 
  v. Algernon Blair, Inc., 250 S.C. 106, 109, 156 S.E.2d 646, 648 (1967); 
  73A C.J.S. Public Administrative Law and Procedure Â§ 144, at 104 (1983) 
  (â€œWhere the requirements as to administrative findings are contained in statutes, 
  the findings must comply therewith.â€).Â  In fact, â€œawards without such specific 
  findings do not comply with the requirements of the [workersâ€™ compensation] 
  act and are illegal.â€Â  Id. at 110, 156 S.E.2d at 648; see also 
  Airco, Inc. v. Hollington, 269 S.C. 152, 160, 236 S.E.2d 804, 808 (1977) 
  (finding that the commission has a statutory duty to make a finding of fact 
  for all â€œessential factual issues.â€).Â  This court cannot make findings of fact 
  when the commission has failed to do so because, in doing so, this court would 
  improperly assume the commissionâ€™s role as factfinder.Â  Fox v. Newberry County 
  Memorial Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 280, 461 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1995).Â  Because 
  the commission did not make specific findings of fact to support its ruling, 
  we must remand the issue to the commission.Â  See, e.g., Parsons v. 
  Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995) (holding an order of 
  the commission that does not include sufficiently detailed findings of fact 
  must be remanded to the commission).

In the instant case, the order issued by the majority of the Full 
  Commission fails to set forth any specific findings of fact related to its determination 
  that Agnew suffered a 40% permanent partial disability to her back as opposed 
  to the 30% rating assigned by the single commissioner.Â  Moreover, the order 
  fails to provide any findings of fact regarding the essential issues of whether 
  Agnew was entitled to a finding of total disability or more than 50% permanent 
  partial disability.Â  The order merely states, â€œThe injury sustained by the Claimant 
  as a result of her accident on September 19, 1995 based on the medical evidence 
  and other evidence presented results in a permanent partial disability of 40% 
  loss of use of her back.â€ Â Thus, the Full Commission implicitly ruled 
  that Agnew did not suffer more than 50% disability and implicitly found against 
  the conclusions of Dr. William Stewart, the vocational rehabilitation examiner, 
  regarding her ability to perform some function.Â  
Furthermore, the Commission did not incorporate by reference the factual findings 
  of the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Thus, the erroneous omission of detailed 
  factual findings in the Commissionâ€™s order was not cured. 
  [1] Â  Cf. Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp., 355 S.C. 
  154, 168, 584 S.E.2d 390, 398 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied (May 13, 
  2004) (finding the Full Commissionâ€™s incorporation of the single commissionerâ€™s 
  findings of fact and conclusions of law by reference provided the circuit court 
  with sufficiently definite and detailed findings to allow the circuit court 
  to ascertain whether the findings by the Commission were supported by the evidence 
  and whether the law was correctly applied).
Additionally, the circuit court, in affirming the Full Commissionâ€™s decision, 
  utilized over three pages to set forth findings of fact detailing the evidence 
  it found supported the Full Commission.Â  However, when the Full Commission failed 
  to set forth findings of fact on its own, the circuit court could not make its 
  own findings of fact without improperly assuming the role of the Full Commission.Â  
  See Nettles, 341 S.C. at 590-91, 535 S.E.2d at 151 (stating an 
  appellate court â€œcannot make findings of fact when the commission has failed 
  to do so because, in doing so, [the appellate] court would improperly assume 
  the commissionâ€™s role as factfinderâ€).
Therefore, we vacate the circuit courtâ€™s order and remand to the 
  Full Commission to make detailed findings of fact.Â  We instruct the Commission 
  to review all of the evidence in the present record when making its factual 
  findings and conclusions as to Agnewâ€™s degree of disability.Â  See Sigmon 
  v. Dayco Corp., 316 S.C. 260, 262-63, 449 S.E.2d 497, 498-99 (Ct. App. 1994) 
  (vacating circuit courtâ€™s order and remanding to Full Commission where Full 
  Commission did not make findings of fact and circuit court improperly made its 
  own findings of fact with regard to claimantâ€™s injury); Baldwin, 304 
  S.C. at 487, 405 S.E.2d at 423 (vacating circuit courtâ€™s order and remanding 
  case to Full Commission to make definite and detailed findings of fact on present 
  record where Full Commissionâ€™s findings of fact were conclusory as to claimantâ€™s 
  award).Â  
II.
As to the merits of her appeal, Agnew asserts there was uncontradicted 
  evidence from Dr. William Stewart indicating she was permanently and totally 
  disabled and would be unable to work.Â  Additionally, she contends her treating 
  physiciansâ€™ directions for her to continue to use prescription medication and 
  to consider chronic pain management are evidence in favor of finding she is 
  more than 50% permanently disabled.Â  Finally, she maintains the only reasonable 
  inference arising from the evidence is that she experienced a 50% loss of use 
  of her back and has been rendered permanently and totally disabled.Â  Thus, the 
  Full Commissionâ€™s decision is not supported by substantial evidence, but rather, 
  is based on an error of law.
In light of our decision to remand this case to the Full Commission, 
  we need not address this issue.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of 
  Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (noting 
  that an appellate court need not address appellantâ€™s remaining issues when its 
  determination of a prior issue is dispositive); Whiteside v. Cherokee County 
  Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating 
  appellate court need not address remaining issues when determination of prior 
  issue is dispositive).
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
 VACATED AND REMANDED.Â Â Â  
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  In contrast to the final order, the Full Commissionâ€™s 
    order that affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s decision to award Agnew temporary 
    total disability benefits specifically incorporated the single commissionerâ€™s 
    order.

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ronnie Armstrong and Tillie Armstrong,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Food Lion, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-366
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Katherine Carruth Link, of Columbia, 
  and Ross Alan Burton, of Winnsboro, for Appellants.
Paul Harrill and Jonathan Milling, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ronnie and Tillie Armstrong 
  appeal a directed verdict in favor of Food Lion on the Armstrongsâ€™ claims of 
  assault, battery, and outrage.Â  We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Hinkle 
  v. Nat. Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003) (noting 
  on appeal from the denial of a directed verdict motion, the evidence and inferences 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, but the 
  trial court will be reversed only when the ruling is without evidentiary support 
  or controlled by an error of law); Wade v. Berkeley County, 330 S.C. 
  311, 318, 498 S.E.2d 684, 688 (Ct. App. 1998) (noting under the doctrine of 
  respondeat superior, an employer is liable for the torts of his employee committed 
  while the employee is acting within the scope of employment); Lane v. Modern 
  Music, Inc., 244 S.C. 299, 304-05, 136 S.E.2d 713, 716 (1964) (holding plaintiff 
  bears burden of proving the employment relationship and that the employee was 
  acting in the scope of his employment); Vereen v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 
  306 S.C. 423, 429, 412 S.E.2d 425, 429 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding whether the 
  employee was furthering his employerâ€™s business is an important factor in determining 
  if he acted within the scope of his employment and, if â€œhe act[ed] for some 
  independent purpose of his own, wholly disconnected from the furtherance of 
  his employerâ€™s business, his conduct f[ell] outside the scope of his employmentâ€); 
  Hamilton v. Davis, 300 S.C. 411, 415-17, 389 S.E.2d 297, 299-300 (Ct. 
  App. 1990) (holding where evidence demonstrates without doubt that assault was 
  personal in nature and no evidence showed it was in furtherance of the employerâ€™s 
  business, the assault was not within the scope of employment); Lane, 
  244 S.C. at 305, 136 S.E.2d at 716 (â€œThe act of a servant done to effect some 
  independent purpose of his own and not with reference to the service in which 
  he is employed, or while he is acting as his own master for the time being, 
  is not within the scope of his employment so as to render the master liable 
  therefor.â€); Holder v. Haynes, 193 S.C. 176, 182-92, 7 S.E.2d 833, 836-39 
  (1940) (finding an auto accident caused by an employee while embarked on a trip 
  wholly unrelated to his employerâ€™s business did not warrant employer liability, 
  notwithstanding the fact the vehicle was provided by the employer).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

title: Hall v. Jones

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ella R. Hall,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
J. Richard Jones, Esquire,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-367
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ella R. Hall, of Hartsville, for Appellant.
Finley B. Clarke, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this legal 
  malpractice action, Ella Hall appeals a circuit court order granting summary 
  judgment in favor of J. Richard Jones, Esquire.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Ella Hall worked as a nurse for Commander Nursing 
  Center.Â  In 1997, she became the subject of an investigation into some missing 
  drugs at the center.Â  The South Carolina Board of Nursing investigated the incident.Â  
  Rebecca Plowden, the nursing home administrator, suspended Hall in July 1997 
  after the investigation indicated Hall was responsible for the missing drugs.Â  
  A complaint against her nursing license was filed with the Board.
Hall originally hired Anne Bell in August 
  1997 as counsel to help with the licensing matter before the Board.Â  She discussed 
  bringing suit against Commander for racial discrimination because she was black 
  and her husband was white, and she felt that contributed to her suspension.Â  
  Hall became dissatisfied with Bellâ€™s representation and terminated the representation 
  in March 1998. 
Thereafter, Hall retained Jones in March 
  1998 to represent her in the Board matter.Â  Additionally, she raised the possibility 
  of bringing suit against multiple parties, including Commander, Plowden, the 
  Board, and its investigator.Â  Jones pursued his representation of Hall on the 
  matter before the Board.Â  In October 1998, Jones and Hall were notified that 
  the complaint against Hallâ€™s license had been dismissed.Â  
In December 1998, Jones ended his representation 
  of Hall.Â  He never filed any actions regarding her racial discrimination or 
  defamation claims.Â  Hall stated that Jones presented her with a list of other 
  counsel to consider for representation.Â  On December 7, 1998, Jones returned 
  Hallâ€™s file to her.Â  He never charged Hall for any of his representation.Â Â Â  

On July 22, 1999, Hall employed David 
  Weeks to file actions for racial discrimination and defamation.Â  Hall subsequently 
  terminated his representation.Â Â Â  
In December 2000, Hall filed separate pro 
  se legal malpractice actions against Bell, Jones, and Weeks.Â  In her 
  complaint against Jones, she alleged breach of contract, breach of fiduciary 
  duty, and negligence.Â  All of her claims centered on his failure to file her 
  action for defamation and racial discrimination.Â  Each cause of action was framed 
  as an action for legal malpractice.Â  Jones filed an answer admitting he represented 
  her regarding her nursing license, but denying he ever agreed to pursue the 
  racial discrimination and defamation claims.Â  He asserted his representation 
  ended on December 7, 1998, when he returned the file to Hall.Â  
Jones filed a motion for summary judgment, along 
  with an affidavit from an expert.Â  The affidavit stated Jones did not breach 
  the standard of care for an attorney.Â  The expert asserted a strategy was required 
  to determine whether to file a lawsuit while the matter before the nursing board 
  was pending, as well as the type of cause of action to file.Â  Hall failed to 
  file an affidavit from an expert in connection with the summary judgment motion.Â  
  The circuit court extended to Hall forty-five days to file an affidavit establishing 
  the standard of care and identifying Jonesâ€™ breach of the standard.Â  Hall never 
  submitted the affidavit of an expert.
In ruling on the summary judgment motion, the circuit 
  court considered Hallâ€™s three causes of action as one action alleging legal 
  malpractice.Â  The court found that she failed to properly establish the standard 
  of care by expert testimony.Â  The court also noted that Hall still had several 
  viable causes of action at the time Jones ended his representation.Â  As such, 
  she did not show how his failure to file certain complaints was the proximate 
  cause of any of her alleged damages.Â  Finally, the court concluded Jones â€œexercised 
  good judgment and did not deviate from the standard of careâ€ and that Hall â€œsuffered 
  no legal prejudice by the fact [Jones] had not filed suit for her prior to December 
  7, 1998.â€Â  Hall did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the 
  judgment to have the court specifically address either her breach of contract 
  or breach of fiduciary duty claims.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary 
  judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; 
  Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-115, 410 
  S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact 
  exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the 
  evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â 
Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 
  54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary 
  judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and 
  inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the 
  non-moving party below.â€Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 
  S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  
DISCUSSION
 Hall raises several issues contesting 
  the grant of summary judgment in favor of Jones.Â  She alleges: 1) there are 
  issues of fact as to whether an attorney-client relationship existed; 
  [1]  2) the court erred in requiring an affidavit or testimony by an expert 
  to establish the standard of care; 3) there are issues of fact related to Hallâ€™s 
  legal malpractice claim; 4) there are issues of fact related to Hallâ€™s claim 
  of breach of contract; [2]  5) there are issues of fact related to Hallâ€™s breach of fiduciary 
  duty claim; [3]  and 6) the affidavit 
  testimony of Jonesâ€™ expert was not uncontradicted.Â  The only issues properly 
  before this court for review are the requirement of expert testimony and affidavit 
  to establish the standard of care, and whether the trial court properly granted 
  summary judgment as to the legal malpractice claim.Â  
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Expert Testimony
Hall contends that expert testimony was 
  not required to establish the standard of care for the legal malpractice action 
  against Jones.Â  She maintains it is common knowledge that an action should be 
  filed before the statute of limitations has run.Â  We find the issue in this 
  case went beyond the common knowledge of laypersons.Â  Hence, an affidavit of 
  an expert was necessary to establish the appropriate standard of care.
In South Carolina, the plaintiff in a legal malpractice suit 
  must prove the following four elements:

(1) the existence of an attorney-client relationship;
(2) a breach of duty by the attorney;
(3) damage to the client;Â  and
(4) proximate cause of the plaintiff's damages by the breach.Â 

McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 342, 499 
  S.E.2d 488, 493-94 (Ct. App. 1998); Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & 
  Geurard, 322 S.C. 433, 435,Â  472 S.E.2d 612, 613 (1996).Â  Additionally, 
  the plaintiff must generally establish the standard of care by expert testimony.Â  
  Smith, 322 S.C. at 435, 472 S.E.2d at 613; Mali v. Odom, 295 S.C. 
  78, 80, 367 S.E.2d 166, 168 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œA plaintiff in a legal malpractice 
  case must ordinarily establish by expert testimony the standard of care, unless 
  the subject matter is of common knowledge to laypersons.â€).
In the instant case, the issue of when 
  to file an action and what type of action to file is more complicated than Hall 
  indicates.Â  As discussed by M.Â  Malissa Burnette, Jonesâ€™ expert and a certified 
  specialist in employment and labor law, Jones needed to consider the ramifications 
  of filing an action while Hallâ€™s nursing license was pending review by the Board.Â  
  Jonesâ€™ predominant interest was in maintaining Hallâ€™s nursing license.Â  
Additionally, Burnette indicated there were several 
  theories under which Hall could proceed in asserting racial discrimination.Â  
  Burnette stated that several theories could only be asserted against certain 
  defendants and that some theories had a cap on the amount of damages Hall could 
  collect.Â  Burnette further stated that the only statute under which Hall could 
  have asserted a claim against all defendants in the amount she desired would 
  have been 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1981, and the statute of limitations on that claim did 
  not run until July 30, 2000.Â  
The combination of considerations in filing 
  a suitâ€”what type of suit to file, when it was most beneficial to file suit, 
  and against whom the suit could be filedâ€”all are beyond the scope of common 
  knowledge held by laypersons.Â  As such, the common knowledge exception is inapplicable.Â  
  We agree with the circuit court and find that the general rule requiring the 
  standard of care be properly established by expert testimony applies in this 
  case.Â  See Smith, 322 S.C. at 435, 472 S.E.2d at 613.Â  
After Jones submitted the affidavit of Burnette, 
  which established a standard of care and stated it was not breached, the court 
  allowed Hall forty-five days in which to file her own affidavit by an expert.Â  
  The circuit court went beyond the requirements of the rule in trying to accommodate 
  a pro se plaintiff.Â  Hall failed to file the requisite affidavit 
  from an expert to establish the standard of care.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Summary Judgment of Legal Malpractice Claim
Hall contends the trial court erred in 
  granting summary judgment on her claim for legal malpractice.Â  She alleges that 
  issues of fact exist relating to the duty required, the breach of that duty 
  by Jones, the damages caused by the breach, and whether Jonesâ€™ actions were 
  the proximate cause of the damages.Â  We disagree.
As discussed above, Hall was required 
  to establish the standard of care by expert testimony to survive summary judgment.Â  
  As she failed to do so, summary judgment by the circuit court was appropriate.Â  
  The motion was properly granted in any event.Â  
Hallâ€™s primary contention is that Jones 
  failed to file a complaint under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 
  as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. Â§2000e-2(a)(1), with the Equal Employment Opportunity 
  Commission.Â  Hall asserts Jones missed the 300-day statute of limitations for 
  filing the claim, and she is now barred. 
First, this issue is not properly preserved 
  for review on appeal.Â  Hall originally charged that Jones missed a 180-day statute 
  of limitations for filing.Â  It was not until after the summary judgment hearing, 
  but before receipt of the final order granting the motion, that she first made 
  the claims regarding the 300-day statute of limitations.Â  As the trial court 
  did not expressly rule on that issue, it is not preserved for our review on 
  appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge 
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Next, Hall fails to demonstrate how she 
  was harmed by Jonesâ€™ failure to file the claim.Â  Hall had several causes of 
  action still available to her after December 7, 1998, including an action under 
  42 U.S.C. Â§ 1981.Â  Section 1981 and other tort actions do not have a cap on 
  the damages Hall could collect.Â  
Jonesâ€™ representation of Hall was terminated 
  in December 1998.Â  In July 1999, Hall engaged Weeks to represent her in her 
  racial discrimination claims.Â  She had almost a year before the statute of limitations 
  ran on her claims pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1981 and her tort claims.Â  As such, 
  Jonesâ€™ failure to file claims on Hallâ€™s behalf would not be the proximate cause 
  of her damages, as she still had viable causes of action available to her.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we concur with the circuit 
  court and hold that the allegation of attorney malpractice required expert testimony 
  as to the standard of care and deviation from such standard.Â  We conclude the 
  circuit court properly granted Jonesâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 
  

 
   
    [1] Â  The trial judge assumed for the purpose of his order that an attorney-client 
    relationship existed.Â  Therefore, there is no reason for this court to address 
    this issue.

 
   
    [2] Â  With regard to the breach of contract issue, the arguments in Hallâ€™s 
    brief are conclusory and fail to cite any supporting authority for the position.Â  
    As such, we find Hall abandoned the issues on appeal.Â  See First 
    Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994); Solomon 
    v. City Realty Co., 262 S.C. 198, 201, 203 S.E.2d 435, 436 (1974).Â  

 
   [3] Â  With regard to the breach of 
    fiduciary duty claim, Hall appears to be arguing the same issues she argued 
    in relation to her legal malpractice claim.Â  As such, the issue will be consolidated 
    with the legal malpractice claim.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jerry Louis Brown,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sylvester R. Harper; and Charleston Police Department,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Special Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-368
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; APPEAL DISMISSED 
  IN PART


  
    
      
Jerry Louis Brown, of Ridgeville, pro se.
Sandra J. Senn, of Charleston and Stephanie Pendarvis McDonald, 
  of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jerry Louis Brown appeals the 
  dismissal of his action for damages allegedly resulting from a police investigation 
  and the service of arrest warrants on him.Â  We dismiss Brownâ€™s appeal of the 
  issues raised in his motion to alter judgment and affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling 
  on the remaining issue. [1]   
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 25, 2000, Brown, an inmate in the custody 
  of the South Carolina Department of Corrections, brought a civil rights action 
  in the United States District Court against Sylvester R. Harper and the Charleston 
  Police Department, alleging, among other things, fraud and negligence.Â  On 
  October 31, 2000, United States Magistrate Judge Joseph R. McCrorey issued a 
  report recommending that the District Court dismiss Brownâ€™s complaint without 
  prejudice and without issuance and service of process. 
On December 27, 2000, Brown filed an action in 
  the Ninth Judicial Circuit Court of Common Pleas alleging among other things 
  that Harper, an officer with the Charleston Police Department, violated 
  Brownâ€™s civil rights during the course of an investigation concerning Brown. 
  [2] 
On February 2, 2001, Defendants notified Brown 
  the action was removed to the Charleston Division of United States District 
  Court for the District of South Carolina.Â  By order entered April 26, 
  2001, United States District Judge David C. Norton dismissed Brownâ€™s action 
  without prejudice and denied Brownâ€™s request to remand the case to the Charleston 
  County Court of Common Pleas, but also provided that Brown could refile in state 
  court if he wished. 
On June 15, 2001, Brown filed another 
  action against Harper and the Charleston Police Department in the Ninth Judicial 
  Circuit Court of Common Pleas.Â  Defendants moved to dismiss the action 
  on July 12, 2001.Â  On August 10, 2001, Brown filed a â€œCOMPLAINT OF JOINDERS 
  AS DEFENDANTSâ€ against Julie J. Armstrong and Sandra J. Senn â€œin there personal 
  capacitys and professional capacitys.â€ 
  [3] Â  Defendants then filed a motion to dismiss Brownâ€™s â€œcomplaint 
  of joindersâ€ and requested other relief, including sanctions against Brown, 
  a preliminary injunction on future cases, and the imposition of a â€œstrikeâ€ against 
  Brown.Â  In response, Brown moved to strike Defendantsâ€™ motion.
On May 1, 2002, Judge Young, sitting as 
  a special circuit judge, conducted a hearing on both motions.Â  At the 
  conclusion of the hearing, Brown sought and received an additional ten days 
  to file a supplemental memorandum of law and any other materials he felt necessary 
  to respond to Defendantsâ€™ arguments. 
By order dated and filed July 12, 2002, 
  Judge Young granted Defendantsâ€™ motion to dismiss the lawsuit and Brownâ€™s â€œcomplaint 
  of joinders.â€Â  The grounds for dismissal of the action were (1) the action 
  was time-barred, (2) Defendants were immune from suit, and (3) Brown could not 
  attack the validity of his conviction through a tort and civil rights action.Â  
  In the same order, Judge Young denied Defendantsâ€™ motion for sanctions; however, 
  he included a statement admonishing Brown that â€œfuture filings in either this 
  or any other frivolous matter will not be so kindly tolerated.â€
 On July 25, 2002, Brown filed a motion 
  under Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure to alter the 
  judgment, alleging that Defendants had â€œwaived all claimsâ€ under Rule 41(c) 
  of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Judge Young denied Brownâ€™s 
  motion by order dated August 12, 2002, and filed August 13, 2002.Â  Brown 
  received notice of the denial on August 21, 2002. 
OnÂ  August 20, 2002, Brown filed a â€œmotion 
  from relief from orderâ€ under Rule 60(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure arguing as grounds:Â  â€œSpecial circuit court judge, lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction over the parties, when the plaintiff made timely objection 
  upon the record and request jury trial on the matter, and the judgement should 
  be made void.â€Â  He further alleged this amounted to an improper deprivation 
  of his constitutional right to a jury trial under the seventh amendment of the 
  federal constitution, as well as a violation of his due process and equal protection 
  rights. 
By order dated and filed October 21, 2002, 
  Judge Young denied the motion, noting he â€œheard the motion not as Master-in-Equity 
  for Charleston County, but rather as Special Circuit Court Judge for Charleston 
  County under appointment of the Chief Justice.â€ 
Brownâ€™s notice of appeal in this case 
  is dated November 12, 2002.Â  In his appellantâ€™s brief, Brown argues (1) 
  Defendants were equitably estopped from raising the statute of limitations as 
  a bar to Brownâ€™s action, (2) the removal of this action to the federal district 
  court was improper, and (3) because he had demanded a jury trial, â€œthe â€œMaster-in-Equity 
  would lack subject matter jurisdiction over summary dismissal.â€
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Defendants argue Brownâ€™s appeal is untimely and should 
  be dismissed.Â  We agree with this argument insofar as it concerns the first 
  two issues Brown discusses in his brief.Â Â Â  
Brown does not deny that he received the order denying his 
  Rule 59(e) motion on August 21, 2002.Â  Because Brownâ€™s notice of appeal, 
  dated November 12, 2002, was filed and served more than thirty days after his 
  receipt of the order denying his initial post-trial motion, it was untimely 
  and this court lacks jurisdiction to review the matters raised in the appeal 
  that arise from the orders dismissing his lawsuit and denying his Rule 59(e) 
  motion. [4] Â  Contrary to what 
  Brown suggests in his reply brief, his later motion under Rule 60(b) did not 
  toll the time for him to file his notice of appeal. [5] 
2.Â  The third matter Brown discussed in his brief, i.e., his right to a jury 
  trial, however, was the gravamen of his Rule 60(b) motion; therefore, we hold 
  that inasmuch as his notice of appeal was filed within thirty days after he 
  had received the order denying that particular motion, we have jurisdiction 
  to entertain his discussion on that issue.Â  Nevertheless, assuming without deciding 
  that Brownâ€™s objection was properly raised in the trial court and adequately 
  briefed on appeal, we hold the special circuit judge had the authority to dismiss 
  this lawsuit, even if the effect of the dismissal was to prevent Brown from 
  obtaining a jury trial.Â  Contrary to what Brown has argued both to the special 
  circuit judge and to this court, the right to a jury trial â€œdoes not exist with 
  respect to a complaint or declaration as to which a dismissal or nonsuit is 
  proper.â€ [6] 
 AFFIRMED IN PART; APPEAL DISMISSED IN PART.
 GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  Brown later agreed with the allegations made against him and is 
    now serving a twelve-year sentence stemming from charges of lewd conduct and 
    criminal sexual conduct with a minor. 

 
   
    [3] Â  Armstrong is the Charleston County Clerk of Court and Senn represented 
    Harper and the Charleston Police Department.

 
   
    [4]  See Rule 203(b)(1) (requiring that a notice of appeal be served 
    on all respondents within thirty days after receipt of written notice of entry 
    of the order or judgment, but further providing thatâ€[w]hen a timely . . . 
    motion to alter or amend the judgment . . . has been made, the time for appeal 
    for all parties shall be stayed and shall run from receipt of written notice 
    of entry of the order granting or denying such motionâ€); Mears v. Mears, 
    287 S.C. 168, 337 S.E.2d 206 (1985) (holding timely service of the notice 
    of intent to appeal is a jurisdictional requirement, and this Court has no 
    authority to extend or expand the time in which the notice of intent to appeal 
    must be served).

 
   
    [5] Â  See Coward Hund Constr. Co. v. Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 
    1, 518 S.E.2d 56 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting that motions under Rule 60 have no 
    tolling effect on the right to appeal from a challenged judgment).

 
   
    [6] Â  47 Am. Jur. 2d Jury Â§ 16 at 724 (1995).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
City of Myrtle Beach,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Miss Kittyâ€™s, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-369
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William I. Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
James B. Van Osdell and Cynthia Graham Howe, both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The City of Myrtle Beach (the 
  City) brought this action seeking a declaration that it is not obligated to 
  provide sewer service to Miss Kittyâ€™s, Inc., a business located just outside 
  the Cityâ€™s corporate limits.Â  Miss Kittyâ€™s filed a counterclaim alleging the 
  City breached its contract to provide sewer service to the business with the 
  intent to violate Miss Kittyâ€™s freedom of speech and equal protection rights.Â  
  The circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of the City on all of Miss 
  Kittyâ€™s claims.Â  Miss Kittyâ€™s appeals, arguing summary judgment was premature 
  because it did not have a chance to finish discovery on the issue of whether 
  the Cityâ€™s alleged breach of contract violated Miss Kittyâ€™s constitutional free 
  speech and equal protection rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  HISTORY
This case arises from several 
  years of litigation concerning the Cityâ€™s authority over the property upon which 
  Miss Kittyâ€™s is located and the Cityâ€™s obligation to provide sewer service to 
  the property.Â  In 1996, the owner of the subject property, David Eliyahu, sought 
  sewer service for the property from the City.Â  Because Eliyahuâ€™s property was 
  outside the Cityâ€™s corporate limits, the City required Eliyahu to petition the 
  City for annexation of the property as a condition of the City providing sewer 
  service.Â  Eliyahu filed the petition and also paid the required sewer impact 
  fee.Â  Eliyahu later changed his mind, deciding he would rather not have his 
  property annexed.Â  The City, however, refused to allow Eliyahu to withdraw his 
  annexation petition because it had already connected sewer services to his property. 

Eliyahu subsequently brought an action against 
  the City seeking a court order invalidating the ordinance annexing his property.Â  
  The circuit court issued a temporary injunction ordering the City not to exercise 
  authority over Eliyahuâ€™s property pending a final determination.Â  The injunction 
  also provided the City did not have to provide municipal services to the property, 
  with the exception of water.
In late 1996, during the pendency of Eliyahuâ€™s 
  suit against the City, Miss Kittyâ€™s became Eliyahuâ€™s tenant on the property.Â  
  Miss Kittyâ€™s operated as an adult entertainment venue.Â  The City continued to 
  provide sewer service when Miss Kittyâ€™s opened its business on Eliyahuâ€™s property. [1] 
In October 2000, Eliyahu and the City settled the 
  suit after the City agreed with Eliyahuâ€™s demand to repeal the ordinance annexing 
  the property, essentially putting the parties in their pre-annexation positions.Â  
  This settlement included an understanding that the City would no longer provide 
  sewer service to the property as a result of the annexation being repealed.Â  
  Sewer service was disconnected on October 17, 2000.Â  The following day, Miss 
  Kittyâ€™s contacted the City and threatened a lawsuit if sewer services were not 
  restored immediately.Â  Miss Kittyâ€™s attorney later repeated the threat of a 
  lawsuit.Â  The City responded by filing the present action seeking a declaratory 
  judgment that it was not required to provide sewer services to Miss Kittyâ€™s 
  or other property not located within the Cityâ€™s corporate limits.Â  Miss Kittyâ€™s 
  counterclaimed, asserting causes of action for inverse condemnation and breach 
  of contract with intent to violate Miss Kittyâ€™s right to freedom of speech and 
  equal protection under the United States and South Carolina constitutions.
In June 2001, the City moved to dismiss Miss Kittyâ€™s 
  amended answer and counterclaim pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, for failure 
  to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  This motion, however, 
  was neither heard nor ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Several months later, 
  in November 2001, the City filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  That motion 
  was heard on March 7, 2002, and the circuit court issued its order granting 
  summary judgment to the City on May 15, 2002.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF 
  REVIEW
A trial court should grant a motion for summary 
  judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Fleming v. 
  Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  â€œIn determining whether 
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can 
  be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 
  332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  If triable issues of fact exist, 
  those issues must go to the jury.Â  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 
  333 S.C. 714, 717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
DISCUSSION
Miss Kittyâ€™s argues summary judgment was premature 
  because it did not have an opportunity to complete discovery on the issue of 
  whether the Cityâ€™s alleged breach of contract violated Miss Kittyâ€™s constitutional 
  free speech and equal protection rights.Â  We disagree.
As an initial matter, we note that the record 
  contains no indication that Miss Kittyâ€™s objected to the circuit courtâ€™s consideration 
  of the Cityâ€™s summary judgment motion on the grounds discovery was incomplete.Â  
  The only indication that Miss Kittyâ€™s desired to offer additional evidence was 
  its request at the conclusion of the summary judgment hearing that it be allowed 
  to submit additional affidavits after the hearing.Â  Neither during the five 
  months the motion for summary judgment was pending, nor during the hearing itself, 
  did Miss Kittyâ€™s request a continuance of the hearing or otherwise ask the circuit 
  court to hold consideration of the motion in abeyance to allow for additional 
  discovery.Â  As a threshold matter, therefore, Miss Kittyâ€™s argument on appeal 
  was not preserved for our review.Â  See Pryor v. Northwest Apartments, 
  Ltd., 321 S.C. 524, 529, 469 S.E.2d 630, 633 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding issue 
  of whether judge erred in granting summary judgment because discovery requests 
  were outstanding was not preserved when appellant did not ask for a continuance 
  to complete discovery).
Even had Miss Kittyâ€™s properly raised to the court 
  below its argument that further discovery was warranted, we find it was proper 
  for the circuit judge to consider the summary judgment motion.Â  Under Rule 56 
  of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, â€œ[a] party seeking to recover 
  upon a claim, counterclaim, or cross-claim or to obtain a declaratory judgment 
  may, at any time after the expiration of 30 days from the commencement of the 
  action . . . move . . . for a summary judgment in his favor upon all or any 
  part thereof.â€ Rule 56(a), SCRCP.Â Â  Summary judgment, however, is appropriate 
  only after the parties to the action have had a full and fair opportunity 
  to gather relevant facts and develop the record on the issue. Dawkins v. 
  Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 439 (2003); see also 
  Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & 
  Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 485, 523 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding 
  that summary judgment is mandated â€œafter adequate time for discovery against 
  a party who fails to make a showing sufficient to establish the existence of 
  an element essential to the partyâ€™s case and on which that party will bear the 
  burden of proof at trialâ€).Â  The decision to reopen the record to allow the 
  proffer of additional evidence at the summary judgment hearing is a matter within 
  the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Bessinger v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 329 
  S.C. 617, 620, 496 S.E.2d 33, 35 (Ct. App. 1998).
The timeline of events in the litigation of this case reveals 
  Miss Kittyâ€™s had ample opportunity to pursue discovery on all of the issues 
  related to its defenses and counterclaims.Â  The Cityâ€™s initial complaint in 
  this case was filed in October 2000.Â  Two months later Miss Kittyâ€™s moved to 
  amend its answer and counterclaim to include a defense that terminating its 
  sewer services violated its First Amendment rights and a counterclaim for breach 
  of contract with intent to violate its constitutional free speech and equal 
  protection rights.Â  By consent order, the circuit court granted Miss Kittyâ€™s 
  motion to amend in May 2001, and the City served a timely response in June 2001.Â  
  As previously noted, the City did not file its summary judgment motion until 
  November 2001, and that motion was not heard until March 2002.Â  Throughout this 
  time period, Miss Kittyâ€™s largely failed to conduct or participate in discovery.Â  
  In fact, in June 2001, the City was forced obtain an order from the trial court 
  compelling discovery responses from Miss Kittyâ€™s.Â  The City was even prompted 
  to move for sanctions when Miss Kittyâ€™s failed to respond as required by the 
  trial courtâ€™s order.
Miss Kittyâ€™s, therefore, squandered its opportunity 
  to discover material facts and develop the record in this case.Â  Beyond the 
  bare assertions contained in the pleadings, there are no facts in the record 
  before us which would indicate the Cityâ€™s decision to terminate sewer services 
  to the subject property was motivated by a desire to suppress Miss Kittyâ€™s constitutional 
  right to free expression or that the City otherwise handled the sewer service 
  dispute differently than it would have had Miss Kittyâ€™s not been engaged in 
  the adult entertainment business.Â  Indeed, the City was aware of the nature 
  of Miss Kittyâ€™s business and provided sewer service to the business for several 
  years prior to the settlement with the property owner, Eliyahu. Accordingly, 
  Miss Kittyâ€™s has failed to show that additional discovery would shed evidentiary 
  light on these allegations that have gone unsupported throughout the pendency 
  of this case.Â  See Dawkins, 354 S.C. at 69, 580 S.E.2d at 439 
  (holding that â€œthe nonmoving party must demonstrate the likelihood that further 
  discovery will uncover additional relevant evidence and that the party is â€˜not 
  merely engaged in a fishing expeditionâ€™â€) (quotingÂ  Baughman v. Am. Tel. 
  and Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 S.E.2d 537, 544 (1991)).
For these reasons, we find the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order granting the motion for summary judgment is 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
     
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Miss Kittyâ€™s requested additional sewer service for its operation 
    on the subject property for which it paid the City an increased sewer impact 
    fee.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Kenneth L. Thigpen, Employee/Claimant, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Baker Homes, Inc., Self-Insured Employer, through the S.C. Home Builders 
          SIF, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-370
  Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 15, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Kenneth L. Thigpen, Jr., Pro se, for Appellant. 
        John Steven Rodenberg and Kirsten Leslie Barr, both of Mt. Pleasant, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â Kenneth L. Thigpen appeals an order of the circuit court 
  affirming the decision of an appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission 
  denying his claim for compensation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Kenneth Thigpen was employed by Baker Homes on January 6, 2000, to disassemble 
  a house.Â  While on the site, a large overhead beam fell and Thigpen reacted 
  by attempting to catch or block the beam.Â  After seeing a chiropractor, he sought 
  the medical attention of Dr. James Aymond.Â  Dr. Aymond indicated Thigpen complained 
  of lower back pain and posterior thigh pain.Â  He recommended Thigpen undergo 
  an MRI, which later revealed a paracentral disc herniation.Â  Thigpen continued 
  to be seen for treatment of his lower back and underwent physical therapy.
On May 11, 2000, Dr. Aymond indicated that Thigpen was able to lift weights 
  up to 60 pounds and recommended he undergo a functional capacity evaluation.Â  
  At his next visit on May 25, 2000, Thigpen was found to be able to lift â€œwithin 
  a physical demand of medium.â€Â  He was placed on a weight restriction of 50 pounds.Â  
  Dr. Aymond also found Thigpen had reached Maximum Medical Improvement (MMI) 
  and assigned an 8% impairment rating to his spine. 
In April 2000, Thigpen was involved in a non work-related automobile accident.Â  
  In October 2000, he returned to Dr. Aymond, complaining of pain in his hip and 
  groin.Â  Thigpen was referred to Dr. McCrosson for evaluation.Â  After an MRI, 
  it was determined that Thigpen had right femoral head osteonecrosis. 
  [1] Â  The main treatment plan was to perform a core depression of the hip.Â  
  Following a delay in treatment, the femoral head collapsed, requiring Thigpen 
  to undergo a hip replacement.Â  
After filing for compensation benefits, the single commissioner found that 
  the spinal injury was compensable, that there was no compensable injury to Thigpenâ€™s 
  hip, and that Thigpen reached MMI on May 25, 2000.Â  In addition, the commissioner 
  found Thigpen was not entitled to temporary total disability benefits between 
  May 25 and September 8, 2000, and Baker Homes was entitled to a credit towards 
  the amount of permanent disability owed for the payments made to Thigpen between 
  May 25 and September 8, 2000.Â  
An Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission) affirmed 
  the commissionerâ€™s findings and awarded Thigpen $27,396.36 in permanent partial 
  disability for an 18% disability to his spine.Â  The amount was offset by the 
  payments made between May 25 and September 8, 2000.Â  The Commission reaffirmed 
  the finding that the femoral head osteonecrosis was not a compensable injury 
  related to the January 6, 2000 accident.Â  The circuit court affirmed and determined 
  there was substantial evidence to support the decision of the Commission.Â  This 
  appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard 
  of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission 
  as the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 
  130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere 
  scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, 
  when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach 
  the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 
  341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, 
  the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Id.Â  
In an appeal from the Commission, this court may not substitute 
  its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on 
  questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).Â  The appellate 
  court can reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s 
  substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by 
  an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, 
  and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id.Â Â  
DISCUSSION
Thigpen raises a total of ten issues in his pro se brief.Â  However 
  only three issues were properly presented to the circuit court.Â  Any issue raised 
  to this court must previously been raised to and ruled upon by the commission 
  and the circuit court. [2] Â  See Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 
  353 S.C. 339, 352, 577 S.E.2d 475, 481-82 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that an issue 
  cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to 
  and ruled upon by the trial court).Â Â Â  
Therefore, the only issues that are properly preserved 
  for our review are the three that were ruled upon by the Commission and presented 
  for appellate review to the circuit court.Â  See Rodney v. Michelin 
  Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 517, 466 S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996) (â€œArguments not 
  raised to the workersâ€™ compensation commission or to the circuit court are not 
  preserved for appeal.â€).Â  The three issues which are preserved for our review 
  include whether the Commission properly determined:Â  1) the femoral head osteonecrosis 
  was not causally related to the January 2000 accident; 2) Thigpen reached MMI 
  as to his spinal injury in May 2000 and is not entitled to any further medical 
  treatment for his hip or his spine; and 3) Thigpen was not entitled to temporary 
  total disability payments from May 25, 2000 through September 8, 2000, and Respondent 
  is entitled to a credit for these payments against the amount of permanent partial 
  disability it is required to pay.Â Â  
I.Â Â Coverage for the Hip Injury
Thigpen contends the Commission erred in finding he was not entitled to compensation 
  benefits for his alleged hip injury.Â  He maintains the evidence indicates the 
  injury was an injury by accident sustained during the course of his employment.Â  
  We find there is evidence in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s determination 
  that the hip injury was not causally related to the January 2000 accident.
Dr. Aymondâ€™s medical notes indicate Thigpen complained of lower back pain, 
  which radiated through his thighs.Â  Throughout several months of visits with 
  Dr. Aymond for follow-up and treatment, there is no mention in the medical records 
  of a complaint of hip pain.Â  Thigpen did not complain of pain in the hip or 
  the groin until October of 2000.Â  In a letter regarding his treatment of Thigpen, 
  Dr. Aymond explained:

  In my experience, avascular necrosis from trauma is only suspected after 
    a severe pelvic injury, such as a hip dislocation that disrupts the blood 
    supply to the femoral head.Â  There are other nontraumatic reasons for avascular 
    necrosis, but these by definition do not involve any trauma in my experience.
  Therefore, in my opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty, Mr. 
    Thigpenâ€™s avascular necrosis of his right hip is not related to his work-related 
    injury in January of 2000.Â  

Thigpen was referred to Dr. McCrosson for evaluation of the 
  hip.Â  Dr. McCrosson initially indicated the femoral head osteonecrosis might 
  have been related to Thigpenâ€™s work injury on January 6, 2000.Â  However, he 
  later indicated:Â  â€œAt this time I feel that there are too many factors confounding 
  the issue and that it is impossible to say with any medical certainty what the 
  cause of Mr. Thigpenâ€™s avascular necrosis is.â€Â  Dr. Rustin, who also saw Thigpen 
  for his hip injury, stated, â€œit is impossible for me to attribute the probability 
  of the cause of his avascular necrosis to his workerâ€™s comp event.â€Â  
We find that substantial evidence exists in the record to support the finding 
  of the Commission that Thigpenâ€™s injury is not the result of an injury by accident 
  arising out of and in the course of his employment. 
II.Â Entitlement to Benefits Beyond May 25, 2000
Thigpen asserts that he should be entitled to compensation and continued medical 
  care for his femoral head osteonecrosis.Â  As we have determined above, Thigpenâ€™s 
  hip injury is not causally related to the January 2000 accident.Â  Accordingly, 
  he is not entitled to continued medical care for his hip.
We construe a portion of Thigpenâ€™s argument as questioning the finding that 
  he reached maximum medical improvement (MMI) as to his compensable injury.Â  
  â€œMaximum medical improvement is a term used to indicate that a person has reached 
  such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care 
  or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.â€Â  Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse 
  Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 28, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The 
  Commission must make a factual determination of whether the claimant has reached 
  MMI.Â  See id.Â  This Court would only reverse the finding of the 
  Commission if it is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  See Shealy, 
  341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
In this case, Dr. Aymond indicated in a medical record dated May 25, 2000: 
  Â â€œI believe the patient has reached [MMI] and has an impairment of 8% impairment 
  of the spine.Â  We will plan to see him in follow-up as needed.â€Â  While Thigpen 
  does not specifically challenge the finding that he reached MMI as to his spinal 
  injury, the above documentation provides support for the Commissionâ€™s finding.Â  
  Accordingly, the determination that Thigpen reached MMI on May 25, 2000 and 
  is not entitled to further temporary total disability benefits is supported 
  by substantial evidence.Â  
III.Â Benefits Between May and September 2000
Thigpen contends the Commission erred in determining that he was not entitled 
  to benefits from May 25 to September 8, 2000.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œWorkersâ€™ compensation awards have generally provided 
  for temporary total disability benefits until maximum medical improvement, at 
  which point a claimant receives permanent partial disability if warranted.â€Â  
  Oâ€™Banner, 319 S.C. at 28, 459 S.E.2d at 326.Â  The Commission must make 
  a factual determination of whether the claimant has reached MMI, and therefore, 
  the employer would no longer be liable for temporary total disability compensation.
Dr. Aymond found Thigpen reached MMI on May 25, 2000, and assigned 8% impairment 
  to the spine.Â  Baker Homes continued to pay Thigpen temporary total disability 
  compensation until September 8, 2000, when the payments were stopped after Baker 
  Homes received videotaped evidence that Thigpen was able to work.Â  The surveillance 
  records detailing the videotape indicate that on September 8, 2000, Thigpen 
  was seen lifting vinyl siding, using tools, climbing a ladder, and bending over 
  while working at a job site.Â  
As we have determined the Commission correctly 
  found Thigpen reached MMI by May 25, 2000, it also correctly determined he was 
  then entitled to permanent partial disability and not temporary total disability.Â  
  The Commission awarded Thigpen 18% disability to the spine and required permanent 
  partial disability compensation of $27,396.36. 
We find the decision denying Thigpen temporary total disability benefits 
from May 25 to September 8, 2000 was supported by substantial evidence.Â  In addition, 
Baker Homes is entitled to a credit for the amount of temporary total disability 
payments made to Thigpen during this period of time.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Most of the issues raised by Thigpen attempt to relitigate issues which were 
  abandoned after an adverse decision by the single commissioner and later the 
  Commission.Â  Accordingly, these issues were not preserved for our review on 
  appeal.Â  We find there is substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s findings 
  that the femoral head osteonecrosis was not compensable, that Thigpen had reached 
  MMI on May 25, 2000 and was not entitled to additional temporary total disability 
  benefits, and that Baker Homes was entitled to a credit for benefits paid between 
  May 25 and September 8, 2000.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court 
  is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  

 
   [1]  This is also referred to in the record as avascular 
    necrosis or AVN.

 
   
    [2] Â  We note that Thigpen has failed to follow the South Carolina Appellate 
    Court Rules in his filings with this court.Â  His brief is conclusory and contains 
    no supporting authority for his positions.Â  See First Sav. Bank 
    v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994); Solomon v. 
    City Realty Co., 262 S.C. 198, 201, 203 S.E.2d 435, 436 (1974).Â Â
