title: Landmark et al. v. Pierce et al.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        Landmark 501(C)(9) Trust Agreement For The Landmark Group, by and through 
          its trustees, Michael P. Dunlap, Steven D. Hale, and Roger K. Meagher, 
          Appellants, 
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Pierce, Couch, Hendrickson, Baysinger & Green; H. Blanton Brown 
          & Associates, P.C.; Brown & Sanger, PC; and Young Clement Rivers 
          & Tisdale, LLP, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-371
  Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed June 17, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        A. Camden Lewis and Peter D. Protopapas, both of Columbia, for 
          Appellants.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
        
        Carl E. Pierce, II, Joseph C. Wilson, IV, M. Dawes Cooke, Jr., all 
          of Charleston; Susan P. McWilliams and Nikole Setzler Mergo, both of 
          Columbia, for Respondents.Â Â Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Landmark 501(C)(9) Trust Agreement 
  for the Landmark Group, by and through its trustees, Michael P. Dunlap, Steven 
  D. Hale, and Roger K. Meagher (â€œAppellantsâ€) brought this legal malpractice 
  action against Pierce, Couch, Hendrickson, Baysinger & Green; H. Blanton 
  Brown & Associates, P.C.; Brown & Sanger, P.C.; and Young Clement Rivers 
  & Tisdale, LLP (â€œRespondentsâ€). Appellants allege that Respondents were 
  negligent in pursuing a case that lacked legal merit, or in the alternative, 
  improperly handled the litigation. The trial judge granted Respondentsâ€™ motions 
  for summary judgment, finding the claims were barred by the statute of limitations, 
  collateral estoppel, and res judicata. We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS 
The Landmark group owned and managed golf resorts 
  across the country. In 1988, Landmarkâ€™s parent company, Clock Tower Place Investments, 
  Ltd., established a self-funded health and welfare plan for its employees called 
  the Landmark Group Insurance ProgramÂ  (â€œthe Planâ€). The Plan was set up as an 
  Employee Welfare Benefit Plan in accordance with ERISA.Â  In 1991, Landmark declared 
  bankruptcy and was soon controlled by the Resolution Trust Corporation (â€œRTCâ€).Â  
  RTC created the Landmark Trust (â€œthe Trustâ€) to oversee the Plan during the 
  bankruptcy and receivership.Â  In 1993, RTC hired Gloria Robinson as the Plan 
  administrator and appointed Michael Welch and V. Jackson Carney (â€œOriginal Trusteesâ€) 
  as the trustees of the Trust. Robinson eventually learned that Landmark had 
  paid more than one million dollars in benefits out of the Plan to certain unqualified, 
  independent contractors [2]  and 
  their dependents. 
In November of 1995, the Trust submitted 
  a case memorandum to RTC requesting the allocation of funds to Clock Tower to 
  repay the amount of the ineligible claims to the Trust.Â  RTC denied the claim.Â  
  The following month, Robinson and the Original Trustees hired Respondents and 
  filed an action (â€œRobinson Iâ€) against Landmark, Clock Tower, the FDIC, and 
  RTC seeking reimbursement for the payments to the ineligible independent contractors. 
  Clock Tower counterclaimed against the Original Trustees on behalf of the Trust, 
  alleging Robinson and the Original Trustees breached their fiduciary duty and 
  wasted the Trustâ€™s assets by hiring Respondents to pursue Robinson I.Â  On March 
  28, 1996, the trial court dismissed Robinsonâ€™sÂ  and the Original Trusteesâ€™ claims 
  for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Clock Tower continued to pursue its 
  counterclaims. [3] Â  On April 
  25, 1996, Clock Tower informed the Original Trustees they would be removed effective 
  May 26, 1996.Â  Clock Tower then replaced the Original Trustees with Michael 
  Dunlap, Steven Hale, and Roger Meagher (â€œAppellant Trusteesâ€).Â  Dunlap was appointed 
  on March 8, 1996, and Hale and Meagher on June 1, 1996.Â  The Appellant Trustees 
  are former employees of the FDIC.Â  
On June 13, 1996, Appellant Trustees 
  fired Respondents. In April of 1997, Clock Tower, acting on behalf of the Trust 
  and with assistance from the Appellant Trustees, moved to disgorge attorneysâ€™ 
  fees from the Original Trustees and Respondents.Â  The trial court granted the 
  motion in part and ordered Respondents to return all fees unused as of June 
  13, 1996.Â  On August 31, 1997, the Plan was terminated due to lack of employees 
  or Plan participants.Â  
Appellants filed the current action on May 28, 1999.Â  They alleged that Respondents 
  were negligent and performed unnecessary work. Appellants sought to disgorge 
  the fees paid to Respondents.Â  Respondents filed motions for summary judgment.Â  
  At the August 10, 2001 hearing, the trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motions, 
  deeming Appellantsâ€™ claim barred by the statute of limitations, collateral estoppel 
  and res judicata.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUES

  
    I.  
    Did the trial court err in finding that this action is barred 
      under the statute of limitations?
  
  
    II. 
    Did the trial court err in finding that this action is barred 
      under res judicata because of the previous action to disgorge payments?
  
  
    III. 
    Did the trial court err in finding this action is barred under 
      the settlement and release from the previous action?
  
  
    IV.
    Did the trial court ignore evidence of Appellantsâ€™ damages?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court 
  applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: 
  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Baril 
  v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 352 S.C. 271, 279, 573 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  â€œSummary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, answers 
  to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if 
  any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the 
  moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id. at 280, 
  573 S.E.2d at 835.
LAW/ANALYSISÂ  
Appellants argue that the trial court erred in finding that the 
  statute of limitations had expired prior to the commencement of this action.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
Under Rule 3(b), SCRCP, an action is commenced, and the statute of limitations 
  tolled, by filing and serving the summons and complaint.Â  The statute of limitations 
  â€œupon a contract, obligation, or liability, express or impliedâ€ expires after 
  three years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2003). The statute of limitations 
  on a negligence claim accrues at the time of the negligence or when facts and 
  circumstances would put a person of common knowledge on notice of a possible 
  claim against another party.Â  Â§ 15-3-535.Â  Under the discovery rule, an action 
  accrues when the injury is discovered or should have been discovered by reasonable 
  diligence.Â  Strong v. Univ. of S.C. Sch. of Med., 316 S.C. 189, 190, 
  465 S.E.2d 850, 852 (1994).Â  The injured party is not required to comprehend 
  the full extent of the damage or the exact nature of the wrong to start the 
  running of the statute.Â  Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 364, 468 
  S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).Â  All that is required is that the party have inquiry 
  notice of a possible claim.Â  Binkley v. Burry, 352 S.C. 286, 297, 573 
  S.E.2d 838, 844 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
The complaint in this action was served on Respondents on May 28, 1999, but 
  at least one trustee, Michael Dunlap, had constructive notice of a claim prior 
  to May 28, 1996 because Clock Towerâ€™s counterclaim was a matter of public record 
  as of February 1996. See Berry v. McLeod, 328 S.C. 435, 445, 492 
  S.E.2d 794, 799 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œAn individual on inquiry or constructive notice 
  is held to be on notice of the contents of documents filed in conformity with 
  applicable statutory law, which an inquiry would have revealed.â€). Therefore, 
  the trial judge was correct to rule that this action is barred by the statute 
  of limitations.
In addition to constructive notice, Dunlap also had actual notice. He had been 
  an FDIC employee from 1990 to February 1996 and became a trustee on March 8, 
  1996. He admits that he knew Robinson I was pending and could have obtained 
  the pleadings at any time. [4] Â  
  Moreover, Dunlap was copied with Clock Towerâ€™s letter terminating the Original 
  Trustees and barring them from making further payments to Respondents.Â  He was 
  also copied with the May 1, 1996 letter informing the Original Trustees they 
  would be held personally accountable for the payments to Respondents.Â  Additionally, 
  on May 23, 1996, Respondents actually provided Dunlap with a copy of Clock Towerâ€™s 
  Answer and Counterclaim.Â  On May 26, 1996, the Original Trustees were removed 
  and Dunlap became the sole trustee.Â  
We find that Dunlap, as a trustee, had the knowledge and ability to act against 
  Respondents prior to May 28, 1996. That knowledge is imputed to the other trustees. 
  See Dorman v. Campbell, 331 S.C. 179, 185, 500 S.E.2d 786, 789 
  (Ct. App. 1998) (affirming that â€œa principal is affected with . . . knowledge 
  of all [information] of which his agent receives notice while acting within 
  the scope of his authorityâ€) (citing Crystal Ice Co. of Columbia, Inc. v. 
  First Colonial Corp., 273 S.C. 306, 309, 257 S.E.2d 496, 497 (1979)). Therefore, 
  this action cannot lie.
As Appellantsâ€™ action is time-barred, we do not reach the remaining issues 
  on appeal. [5] 
CONCLUSIONÂ  
Based on the above, we find that the trial court properly granted Respondentsâ€™ 
  motions for summary judgment.Â  Accordingly, the decision isÂ  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The independent contractors were golf pros for 
    the resorts.

 
   [3]  On September 1, 2000, Clock Tower, 
    Appellants, and the Original Trustees entered into a settlement agreement 
    that released the Original Trustees from any liability in connection with 
    payments to Respondents and acknowledged that the Original Trustees fulfilled 
    their fiduciary obligations to the Trust and the Plan.Â  

 
   [4]  The trial court dismissed the Original Trusteesâ€™ 
    claims in Robinson I on March 28, 1996, but that was after Dunlap had become 
    a trustee.

 
   [5]  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 
    Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining that appellate 
    courts need not review remaining issues when the disposition of a prior issue 
    is dispositive).

title: State v. Starr
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED 
  OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Akera Felecia Starr, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
  Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-372
  Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 17, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, S.C. Dept. of Probation, of Columbia, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Akera Felecia Starr appeals 
  the revocation of her probation.Â  Starrâ€™s appellate attorney has petitioned 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating she has reviewed the record and has concluded 
  Starrâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  The issue briefed by counsel concerns whether 
  the trial court abused its discretion in Starrâ€™s probation.Â  Starr has not filed 
  any documents on her own behalf.
After a review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 
  U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 
  (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues that are arguable on 
  their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Starrâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition 
  to be relieved. [1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

title: State v. Morris
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED 
  OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Anthony Lamont Morris, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-373
  Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 17, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Anthony Lamont Morris appeals 
  his conviction for trafficking in cocaine.Â  Morrisâ€™s appellate counsel has petitioned 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating he has reviewed the record and has concluded 
  Morrisâ€™s appeal is without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  The 
  issue briefed by counsel concerns whether the trial court erred in refusing 
  to submit a lesser-included offense to the jury.Â  Morris has filed a brief on 
  his own behalf alleging, in addition to the issue briefed by counsel, evidentiary 
  errors and defects in subject matter jurisdiction. 
After a review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 
  U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 
  (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues in this case that are 
  arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Morrisâ€™s appeal and grant 
  counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
  [1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

title: State v. Orange
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Edward Orange, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
  Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-374
  Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 17, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Chief Appellate Defender Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          all of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Edward Orange pled guilty to armed robbery and 
  possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and the circuit 
  court sentenced him to fourteen years imprisonment for armed robbery and five 
  years imprisonment for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent 
  crime, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 
  386 U.S. 738 (1967), Orangeâ€™s counsel attached a petition to be relieved.Â  Orange 
  did not file a pro se response.
After review of the record pursuant to Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Orangeâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition 
  to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concurring.


 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving any issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

title: State v. Schilling
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Robert D. Schilling, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-375
  Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 17, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Chief Appellate Defender Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Robert D. Schilling pled guilty to bank fraud 
  and forgery and was sentenced to three years imprisonment on both charges, the 
  sentences to run concurrently.Â  Additionally, Schilling pled guilty to violation 
  of his probation for unrelated charges, and the circuit court revoked three 
  years of his probation and terminated it, the three years of revoked probation 
  to run concurrently with the previous sentences.Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 
  386 U.S. 738 (1967), Schillingâ€™s counsel attached a petition to be relieved.Â  
  Schilling did not file a pro se response.
After review of the record pursuant to Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Schillingâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s 
  petition to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concurring.

    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

title: Crawford v. Crawford
text:
<!--
.Normal
	{font-size:12.0pt;

	{text-align:justify;
	text-indent:.5in;
	font-size:15.0pt;

	color:black;}
-->


THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sylvia Crawford,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lawrence Crawford,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Rolly W. Jacobs, Family Court Judge 

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-381
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lawrence Crawford,Â  pro se.
William S. Tetterton, of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, the 
  appealed order (1) granted Sylvia Crawford, the wife, a divorce from Lawrence 
  Crawford, the husband, on the ground of a one-year separation, (2) granted both 
  parties sole and exclusive possession of the property in their respective possessions, 
  and (3) restored the wifeâ€™s maiden name.Â  The husband appeals.Â  We affirm. [1] 
1.Â  We find no merit to the husbandâ€™s argument 
  that the family court judge who heard the matter should have recused himself 
  because that same judge also presided in a matter involving the Department of 
  Social Services against the husband.Â  See Roper v. Dynamique Concepts, 
  Inc., 316 S.C. 131, 139, 147 S.E.2d 218, 223 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œA judge is 
  not required to recuse himself merely because he presided over other proceedings 
  on the same or related cases.â€); Payne v. Holiday Towers, Inc., 283 S.C. 
  210, 217, 321 S.E.2d 179, 183 (Ct. App.1984) (â€œWhen no evidence is presented 
  other than prior appearances by a party which resulted in â€˜adverseâ€™ rulings 
  by the judge, the judge is not required to recuse himself.â€).Â  Here, although 
  the husband appears to allege on appeal that the other proceeding resulted in 
  â€œcontinual bias actionsâ€ against him, he offered no evidence, by affidavit or 
  otherwise, to show the presiding family court judge could not be impartial in 
  this case.
2.Â  The family court ordered that the marital property 
  in the possession of each party be the sole and exclusive property of that party, 
  free from any claims of the other.Â Â  The husband alleges error in the family 
  courtâ€™s decision to confirm the wifeâ€™s right to the marital property in her 
  possession.Â  We find no error.Â  
The wife testified that she took clothes belonging 
  to herself and the children, the partiesâ€™ living room set, the washer and dryer, 
  and the refrigerator.Â  The husband alleges on appeal that the wife had taken 
  into possession other items that she did not mention at trial, including jewelry, 
  electronic equipment, credit cards, and social security benefits.Â  At the conclusion 
  of the hearing, the family court agreed to take the issue of equitable distribution 
  under advisement pending the husbandâ€™s provision of written information of â€œvaluation 
  of all of the items in the mobile home in addition to the items that [the 
  wife] hasâ€ (emphasis added).Â  The family court requested the husband to 
  â€œmark which items [the wife] has and which items . . . are still left in there.â€Â  
  Although the husband provided a statement alleging the wife owed him $24,700 
  in social security benefits and had taken other items of value, the record on 
  appeal does not contain, as the family court requested, a valuation of the items 
  to which the husband retained possession.Â  Moreover, the husband does not appear 
  to dispute the findings in the appealed order that he had retained possession 
  of the marital real estate, the remaining household furnishings, and two automobiles.Â  
  As the wife notes in her brief, the evidence could support a finding that the 
  value of the items that she took represented a very small portion of the total 
  assets of the marriage.Â  Under these circumstances, we find no abuse of discretion 
  in the family courtâ€™s decision to award the wife the marital property that she 
  agreed was in her possession.Â  See Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 
  85, 97, 561 S.E.2d 610, 616(Ct. App. 2002) (citing the principle that, absent 
  an abuse of discretion, the family courtâ€™s apportionment of marital property 
  will not be disturbed on appeal).
3.Â  The husband appears to raise several additional 
  matters on appeal; however, in his brief, he failed to present a concise and 
  direct statement for these issues, preferring to include discussion on them 
  within the arguments for which statements were provided.Â  As an appellate court, 
  we are not at liberty to consider these other matters because they have not 
  been preserved for appeal.Â  See Langehans v. Smith, 347 S.C. 348, 
  352, 554 S.E.2d 681, 683 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAn appellate brief must be divided 
  into as many parts as there are issues to be argued, and an issue is not preserved 
  for appeal if appellantâ€™s brief does not conform to these requirements. . . 
  . [I]t is error for the appellate court to consider issues not properly raised 
  to it.â€).
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gary Robinson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-390
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  21, 2004Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellant Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
PER CURIAM:Â  Robinson was convicted in December 
  1998 for armed robbery. He appealed the trial courtâ€™s ruling. On remand from 
  the Court of Appeals, the trial court ruled that Robinson was mentally competent 
  to stand trial in December 1998 on the charges of armed robbery and was competent 
  during the adversarial hearing in December 2002.Â  Robinson appeals.Â  We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State 
  v. Weik, 356 S.C. 76, 81, 587 S.E.2d 683, 685 (2002) (internal citation 
  omitted), adhered to on rehâ€™g State v. Weik, 356 S.C. 382, 581 
  S.E.2d 834 (2003) (â€œThe test for determining competency to stand trial is whether 
  the defendant has sufficient present ability to consult with his lawyer with 
  a reasonable degree of rational understanding and whether he has a rational 
  as well as a factual understanding of the proceedings against him.â€); State 
  v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 39, 503 S.E.2d 747, 749 (1998) (stating the defendant 
  bears the burden of proving his incompetence by a preponderance of the evidence); 
  State v. Nance, 320 S.C. 501, 504-505, 466 S.E.2d 349 (1996) (holding 
  the trial court's determination of competency will be upheld if it has evidentiary 
  support and is not against the preponderance of the evidence).
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: McDaniel v. SC Department of Motor Vehicles
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
<!--
.Normal
	{font-size:12.0pt;

	{tab-stops:center 3.0in right 6.0in;

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
William Robert McDaniel,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-391
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  21, 2004

REVERSED 


  
    
      
Senior Assistant General Counsel Patrick M. Teague, General 
  Counsel Frank L. Valenta; South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Timothy Clay Kulp, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â We reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling 
  reversing the administrative decision and ordering the South Carolina Department 
  of Motor Vehicles (DMV) to restore McDanielâ€™s driverâ€™s license.
FACTS
William McDaniel was arrested for driving under the influence of 
  alcohol.Â  After he was arrested, McDaniel was transported to the police station 
  where he was offered a DataMaster breath test. McDaniel refused to submit to 
  the breath test. As a result of refusing to take the breath test, McDanielâ€™s 
  driverâ€™s license was suspended for a period of 90 days pursuant to S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950. 
McDaniel requested an administrative 
  hearing through the DMV. After hearing the matter, the hearing officer sustained 
  the action taken by the DMV. McDaniel appealed the administrative decision to 
  the circuit court, which reversed the administrative hearing officerâ€™s decision 
  finding that evidence presented at the hearing did not establish that McDaniel 
  was advised in writing of his rights enumerated in section 56-5-2950. The DMV 
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.
ISSUE
Did the trial court err by substituting its judgment for 
  that of the administrative agency on a question of fact when substantial evidence 
  existed to support the administrative decision?
STANDARD OF 
  REVIEW
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed 
  correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence. Kearse 
  v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Comm'n, 318 S.C. 198, 199, 456 S.E.2d 
  892, 893 (1995).Â  Substantial evidence is defined as â€œsuch evidence as a reasonable 
  mind might accept as adequate to support a conclusion.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 
  276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981).Â  A court may not substitute its 
  judgment for that of an agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions 
  of fact unless the agency's findings are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, 
  probative and substantial evidence on the whole record. Rodney v. Michelin 
  Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The DMV asserts the trial court exceeded its scope 
  of review when the trial court substituted its judgment regarding a question 
  of fact when there was substantial evidence in the record to support administrative 
  agencyâ€™s findings.Â  We agree.Â  
Section 56-5-2950(a)(1) sets forth the procedures regarding 
  implied consent to testing for drugs or alcohol.Â  The statute mandates, in pertinent 
  part, that: 

No tests may be administered or samples obtained unless 
  the person has been informed in writing that:
â€¦
  1)    he does not have to take the test 
  or give the samples, but that his privilege to drive must be suspended or denied 
  for at least ninety days if he refuses to submit to the tests and that his refusal 
  may be used against him in court;
  2)    his privilege to drive must be suspended 
  for at least thirty days if he takes the tests or gives the samples and has 
  an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent or more;
  3)    he has the right to have a qualified 
  person of his own choosing conduct additional independent tests at his expense;
  4)    he has the right to request an administrative 
  hearing within thirty days of the issuance of the notice of suspension; and
  5)    if he does not request an administrative 
  hearing or if his suspension is upheld at the administrative hearing, he must 
  enroll in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003).
In reviewing Officer Usryâ€™s testimony, we believe 
  there was substantial evidence to support the administrative officerâ€™s ruling.Â  
  Officer Usry testified that she read the Implied Consent Rights form to McDaniel 
  and issued a copy of the rights to McDaniel prior to attempting to administer 
  the DataMaster test. Accordingly, McDaniel was advised, in writing of his rights 
  as they are enumerated in section 56-5-2950.Â  It is not required that the administrative 
  officer enumerate that each portion of the statute has been satisfied, only 
  that substantial evidence exist to support his decision.Â  Therefore, the trial 
  court erred in reversing the administrative officerâ€™s decision.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the circuit 
  court is
REVERSED. 
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 21, 2004

Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor RandolphÂ  Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Oâ€™Neal pled guilty 
  to kidnapping and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  He was 
  sentenced to concurrent sentences of 15 years for kidnapping, provided upon 
  the service of six years with the balance suspended upon four years probation, 
  and 10 years for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Oâ€™Neal 
  appeals, arguing his guilty plea did not comply with the mandates set forth 
  in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  On appeal, counsel for Oâ€™Neal 
  has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), 
  asserting that there were no meritorious grounds for appeal and requesting permission 
  to withdraw from further representation.Â  Oâ€™Neal has not filed a pro 
  se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant 
  to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 
  (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
  
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tracy Willard Daniels,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-394
Heard May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed June 22, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, 
  and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tracy Willard Daniels was charged 
  with murder following a shooting death at his home.Â  His testimony at trial, 
  that the shooting was accidental, differed significantly from his statements 
  given at the scene and at the police station.Â  The trial court submitted voluntary 
  manslaughter as a lesser-included offense to the jury over Danielsâ€™ objection 
  and the jury convicted him of that charge. Â He appeals.Â  We affirm.
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s decision 
  to submit voluntary manslaughter as a lesser-included offense of the indicted 
  offense of murder.Â  The statement Daniels gave at the police station, that the 
  shooting occurred immediately after the victim cut him, trying to cut off his 
  thumb, and threatened to turn his â€œinsides out,â€ was sufficient to support the 
  voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  See State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 
  352, 359, 535 S.E.2d 420, 424 (2000) (defining voluntary manslaughter as the 
  unlawful killing of another person in sudden heat of passion upon sufficient 
  legal provocation); State v. Lowry, 315 S.C. 396, 399, 434 S.E.2d 272, 
  274 (1993) (â€œTo warrant a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, it 
  should very clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce 
  the crime from murder to manslaughter.â€); Locklair, 341 S.C. at 360, 
  535 S.E.2d at 424 (explaining sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation 
  is such as would â€œrender the mind of an ordinary person incapable of cool reflectionâ€); 
  State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 549, 500 S.E.2d 489, 495 (1998) (noting 
  â€œfear can constitute a basis for voluntary manslaughterâ€ as the mind can be 
  rendered incapable of cool reflection by a number of strong emotions); State 
  v. Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 65, 508 S.E.2d 29, 31 (1998) (â€œAlthough words alone 
  may not constitute sufficient legal provocation, words accompanied by some overt, 
  threatening act may be sufficient.â€).Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in excluding testimony that the victimâ€™s medical condition and the substances 
  in his system might have made him agitated and affected his aggressiveness.Â  
  This evidence was speculative, might have confused the jury, and might have 
  unfairly prejudiced the jury against the victim.Â  See Rule 403, SCRE 
  (providing relevant evidence â€œmay be excluded if its probative value is substantially 
  outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading 
  the jury . . .â€); State v. Brown, 344 S.C. 302, 308, 543 S.E.2d 568, 
  571 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting rulings on the admissibility of evidence are left 
  to the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed absent clear 
  abuse of that discretion).
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  John Henry Backus appeals his 
  conviction for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR 
  and the following authorities:Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 99, 544

  raised for the first time on appeal.â€). 
AFFIRMED.

  concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jesse Terrell Epps,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lee County
Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-396
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  22, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jesse Terrell Epps was convicted 
  by a jury of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent 
  crime.Â  The circuit court sentenced him to thirty years imprisonment for murder 
  and five years imprisonment for possession of a firearm during the commission 
  of a violent crime, the sentences to run consecutively.Â  Pursuant to Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Eppsâ€™s counsel attached a petition to 
  be relieved.Â  Epps filed a pro se response.
After review of the record pursuant to Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Eppsâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition 
  to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED. 
  [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving any issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Tony Foster, Sr., and Belinda Keaton, as Personal Representatives of 
        the Estate of Tony Foster, Jr., (deceased),       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenville Memorial Hospital System,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-397
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Fletcher N. Smith, Jr., of Greenvill, for Appellants.
Sarah S. Purnell, G. Dewey Oxner, Jr., of Greenville, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The estate of Tony Foster, 
  Jr. (the Estate) filed a wrongful death claim against the Greenville Memorial 
  Hospital System (Greenville Memorial).Â  The trial court granted Greenville Memorialâ€™s 
  motion to dismiss, finding a prior judicial determination, that Greenville Memorial 
  was not negligent, barred the subsequent wrongful death claim.Â  The Estate appeals.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
 FACTS
   In January 1992, four-year-old Tony 
    Foster, Jr., was brought into the Greenville Memorial emergency room suffering 
    from dizziness, vomiting, and diarrhea.Â  Although a CT scan was ordered upon 
    Tonyâ€™s admittance to the hospital, a delay in obtaining the CT scan led to 
    a delay in diagnosing him with hydrocephalus.Â  Tony subsequently sustained 
    severe neurological injuries and thereafter remained in a vegetative state.Â Â  
    Tonyâ€™s mother, acting as his guardian ad litem, brought a medical 
    malpractice action in May 1993, arguing the doctors employed by Greenville 
    Memorial were negligent in failing to timely diagnose and treat Tonyâ€™s condition. 
    [2] Â  After the trial in November 1995, the jury returned a verdict for 
    Greenville Memorial.Â  This Court affirmed in Keaton v. Greenville Memâ€™l 
    Hosp., Op. No. 97-UP-379 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Aug. 28, 1997).Â  Our state 
    Supreme Court affirmed, as modified, this Courtâ€™s opinion and upheld the juryâ€™s 
    verdict for Greenville Memorial.Â  Keaton v. Greenville Memâ€™l Hosp., 
    334 S.C. 488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999).Â  

  
 Tony died November 28, 1999, as a result 
    of his injuries.Â  The Estate filed a wrongful death action against Greenville 
    Memorial in October 2001, alleging negligence by Greenville Memorialâ€™s employees 
    resulted in Tonyâ€™s injuries.Â  In its answer, Greenville Memorial denied the 
    allegations and affirmatively pled the defenses that the complaint failed 
    to state a cause of action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, and that the 
    case was barred by res judicata.Â  At the hearing on the motion to dismiss 
    pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, Greenville Memorial informed the trial court 
    that the negligence issues had already been determined in the prior personal 
    injury case.
  The trial court granted the motion based upon 
    several grounds.Â  The judge found the Estateâ€™s complaint failed to state facts 
    sufficient to constitute a cause of action because it did not allege: (1) 
    that Tony died; (2) the date Tony died; or (3) that Greenville Memorialâ€™s 
    negligence caused his death.Â  After considering information presented by Greenville 
    Memorial regarding the prior lawsuit, the trial court further found the instant 
    case was barred by both the wrongful death statute and the doctrine of collateral 
    estoppel.Â  The Estate appeals. 
   STANDARD OF REVIEW
     The Estate appeals the trial courtâ€™s 
      decision to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  However, 
      as in the present case, if the trial court considers matters outside the 
      complaint on a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, â€œthe 
      motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as provided 
      in Rule 56, and all parties shall be given reasonable opportunity to present 
      all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.â€Â  Rule 12(b), SCRCP; 
      Gilbert v. Miller, 356 S.C. 25, 27, 586 S.E.2d 861, 862 (Ct. App. 
      2003) (holding that where the trial court considers matters outside the 
      pleadings the motion to dismiss is converted to one for summary judgment). [3] 
     LAW/ANALYSIS          
      The Estate argues the trial court 
      erred in granting Greenville Memorialâ€™s motion because â€œa prior determination 
      in a tort action does not bind nor bar a subsequent action for wrongful 
      death.â€Â Â  We do not agree.
       Section 15-51-10 of the wrongful death statute 
        provides:

      Whenever the death of a person shall be caused by the wrongful 
        act, neglect or default of another and the act, neglect or default is 
        such as would, if death had not ensued, have entitled the party 
        injured to maintain an action and recover damages in respect thereof, 
        the person who would have been liable, if death had not ensued, 
        shall be liable to an action for damages. . . .

      S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-10 (1977) (emphasis 
        added).
      Section 15-51-60 of the wrongful 
        death statute addresses the effect of an action filed prior to the individualâ€™s 
        death.Â  This section states the wrongful death statute â€œshall not apply 
        to any case in which the person injured has, for such injury, brought 
        action, which has proceeded to trial and final judgment before his or 
        her death.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-60 (1977).Â  
      When interpreting these statutes, we must determine 
        the intent of the Legislature.Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 
        353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory 
        construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€).Â  
        If the terms of the statute are clear, this Court must apply the terms 
        according to their plain and ordinary meaning.Â  Paschal v. State Election 
        Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995).Â  
      Section 15-51-10 plainly states that a wrongful death 
        action may be filed on behalf of a deceased in cases where the deceased 
        would have been entitled to file a personal injury claim had he or she 
        not died.Â  Further, section 15-51-60 is clearly intended to prevent a 
        double recovery.Â  It excludes a right of action in the estate where the 
        deceased brought and tried an action to a final judgment during the deceasedâ€™s 
        lifetime.Â  As such, sections 10 and 60, when read together, stand for 
        the proposition that a judgment in a prior personal injury case extinguishes 
        the right to pursue a subsequent wrongful death claim.Â  Thus, as the Estate 
        would have been prohibited from retrying Tonyâ€™s personal injury case before 
        his death, it is prohibited from bringing such a suit at this time.Â  
      Even interpreting the facts in the present 
        case in the light most favorable to the Estate, the Estate is barred by 
        statute from bringing the wrongful death action because Tony pursued a 
        personal injury action to final judgment during his lifetime.Â  As such, 
        the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment in favor of Greenville 
        Memorial.
      The Estate, however, cites two 
        cases for the proposition that it was permitted to file both a personal 
        injury action and a wrongful death action.Â  In Bennett v. Spartanburg 
        Ry., Gas & Elec. Co., 97 S.C. 27, 81 S.E. 189 (1914), a husband 
        alleged two causes of action in his complaint: he brought a survival action 
        on both his behalf and the behalf of his children to recover for their 
        loss in the wrongful death of his wife; and an action to recover for wifeâ€™s 
        personal injuries and suffering.Â  Our state Supreme Court held the elements 
        of damages recoverable in the two causes of action were different, and 
        the cases should go forward in separate trials.Â  Bennett, 97 S.C. 
        at 30-31, 81 S.E. at 190.Â  
      The Estate also cites Deaton 
        v. Gray Trucking Co., 275 F. Supp. 750 (D.S.C. 1967).Â  In Deaton, 
        three women were killed in a car accident.Â  The estate of the first woman, 
        Pamela, brought a wrongful death action wherein a verdict was rendered 
        in favor of the trucking company.Â  Subsequently, an action was filed on 
        behalf of the estates of all the women against the trucking company alleging 
        a survival action for Pamela and wrongful death actions for the other 
        two women.Â  Citing Bennett, the District Court for the District 
        of South Carolina held Pamelaâ€™s wrongful death suit was separate and distinct 
        from a survival action, and thus the prior judgment did not bar the survival 
        action.Â  The court also held that the prior suit did not bar the wrongful 
        death actions of the other women because it had not been previously litigated.Â  
        The court denied the defendantâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Deaton, 
        275 F. Supp. at 753-56. 
      These cases do not support the 
        Estateâ€™s argument in the present case.Â  Bennett discussed whether 
        a claim for the death of the decedent and a survival claim could be brought 
        in the same action.Â  Deaton dealt with whether a judgment in favor 
        of the defendant in a wrongful death cause of action barred a subsequent 
        survival action or subsequent wrongful death actions on behalf of the 
        estates of different decedents.Â  Although Deaton dealt with the 
        question of whether res judicata or collateral estoppel barred the wrongful 
        death suits on behalf of the estates of the other two decedents, neither 
        Deaton nor Bennett discussed whether a personal injury case 
        filed and ultimately decided during the decedentâ€™s lifetime barred a subsequent 
        wrongful death claim for that same decedent.Â  Further, these cases were 
        decided prior to the enactment of the current version of the wrongful 
        death statute.Â  As such, the Estateâ€™s argument has no merit.  [4] Â  
      CONCLUSION
      Because section 15-51-10 read in conjunction 
        with section 15-51-60 mandates that a wrongful death action may not be 
        filed subsequent to the final determination of a personal injury action 
        filed during the decedentâ€™s lifetime, the trial court did not err in granting 
        summary judgment to Greenville Memorial.Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s order 
        granting summary judgment to Greenville Memorial Hospital System is

      
 AFFIRMED. [5] 
      HUFF and STILWELL, JJ. and CURETON, 
        AJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  The Estate subsequently filed an amended complaint in August 1994. 
  

 
   
    [3]  The Estate did not complain below and does not complain now on appeal 
    that the trial court improperly considered matters outside the complaint in 
    ruling on the motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.Â  

 
   
    [4]  We note the Estate also argued the trial court erred in finding the 
    Estateâ€™s complaint failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause 
    of action and in finding the cause of action was barred by collateral estoppel.Â  
    However, as this case is barred by the wrongful death statute, it is not necessary 
    to reach the issues raised concerning the adequacy of the pleadings or collateral 
    estoppel.

 
   
    [5]  Although the parties and the trial court did not take notice that 
    the trial courtâ€™s consideration of matters outside the complaint converted 
    the motion to dismiss into one for summary judgment, we may affirm the grant 
    of summary judgment based on the Record.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate 
    court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment based upon any ground(s) appearing 
    in the Record on Appeal.â€).

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Julius Blocker,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-398
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  22, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Julius Blocker appeals his 
  conviction for causing death by operating a vehicle while under the influence 
  of drugs or alcohol.Â  Blockerâ€™s appellate attorney has petitioned to be relieved 
  as counsel, stating he has reviewed the record and has concluded Blockerâ€™s appeal 
  is without merit.Â  The issue briefed by counsel concerns whether Blocker was 
  entitled to a directed verdict based on the alleged insufficiency of evidence 
  establishing the cause of the victimâ€™s death.Â  Blocker has not filed any documents 
  on his own behalf.
After a review of the record as required 
  by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable 
  issues that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Blockerâ€™s 
  appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
  [1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT 
  SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Patrick Guess,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-399
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed June 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Patrick Guess was convicted 
  of second-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and sentenced to 
  twelve years imprisonment.Â  Guessâ€™s appeal was originally filed pursuant to 
  Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  After reviewing the record 
  and briefs pursuant to Anders, this Court found the only issues of arguable 
  merit were whether assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) 
  was a lesser-included offense of second-degree CSC with a minor, and, if so, 
  whether the trial judge erred in failing to charge the jury on the lesser-included 
  offense.Â  The parties have re-briefed these issues, which are the only issues 
  considered on appeal.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
The State presented evidence at 
  trial that eighteen-year-old Guess lured his fourteen-year-old neighbor (Victim) 
  to an abandoned house and sexually assaulted her.Â  Victim testified that Guess 
  grabbed her wrist when he led her to the abandoned house, and there he penetrated 
  her vagina during the assault. Â Â Victim further testified that Guess repeatedly 
  inserted his penis into her vagina and subsequently ejaculated on the ground.Â  
  Semen collected from Victimâ€™s underwear was confirmed through DNA testing to 
  be a positive match to Guess.Â  However, a medical examination of Victim was 
  inconclusive as to penetration.Â Â  Guess did not testify at trial.Â  However, 
  in his statement to police and in a conversation with Victimâ€™s mother, Guess 
  denied sexually assaulting or even touching Victim.Â Â  
At the close of the evidence, Guess requested a 
  charge of ABHAN as a lesser-included offense of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  
  The court denied the request, and Guess was ultimately convicted of second-degree 
  CSC with a minor and sentenced to twelve years imprisonment.Â  Guess appeals.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
  Guess argues the trial court erred in failing 
    to charge the jury on the law of ABHAN because it is a lesser-included offense 
    of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  Even assuming ABHAN is a lesser-included 
    offense of second-degree CSC with a minor, the evidence did not support the 
    requested instruction.Â  See Moultrie v. State, 354 S.C. 646, 
    648, 583 S.E.2d 436, 437 (2003) (implicitly recognizing ABHAN as a lesser-included 
    offense of CSC with a minor).Â  Thus, we find no error.
  The law charged to the jury is determined by 
    the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Blurton, 352 S.C. 203, 207, 
    573 S.E.2d 802, 804 (2002).Â  With regard to lesser-included offenses, â€œ[t]he 
    trial judge is required to charge the jury on a lesser[-]included offense 
    if there is evidence from which it could be inferred that the defendant committed 
    the lesser rather than the greater offense.â€Â  State v. Murphy, 322 
    S.C. 321, 325, 471 S.E.2d 739, 741 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In other words, â€œwhere 
    there is no evidence to support a finding that the defendant was guilty of 
    the lesser offense, there can be no error in the failure to charge the lesser 
    offense.â€Â  State v. Gadsden, 314 S.C. 229, 232, 442 S.E.2d 594, 596-97 
    (1994).Â  This Court cannot reverse the trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested 
    jury instruction unless the refusal was both erroneous and prejudicial.Â  State 
    v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 263, 565 S.E.2d 298, 304 (2002); State v. 
    Harrison, 343 S.C. 165, 173, 539 S.E.2d 71, 75 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  Second-degree CSC with a minor is statutorily 
    defined as the sexual battery of a minor between the ages of eleven and fourteen 
    years old.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(2) (2003).Â  ABHAN, however, is an â€œunlawful 
    act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances of aggravation.â€Â  State 
    v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 274, 531 S.E.2d 512, 516 (2000).Â  â€œCircumstances 
    of aggravation include the use of a deadly weapon, the intent to commit a 
    felony, infliction of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or 
    physical conditions of the parties, a difference in gender, the purposeful 
    infliction of shame and disgrace, taking indecent liberties or familiarities 
    with a female, and resistance to lawful authority.â€Â  State v. Primus, 
    349 S.C. 576, 580-81, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105-06 (2002).Â  
  In the present case, there is nothing 
    in the record that could support a charge of ABHAN.Â  Guess not only verbally 
    denied touching Victim, but in his statement to police, he denied having sex 
    with her at all.Â  At trial, Guessâ€™s counsel contended, â€œit could be argued 
    that [Guess and Victim] were together, and there was no penetration but a 
    sexual battery.â€Â  Sexual battery, however, is an element of second-degree 
    CSC with a minor.Â  As the trial judge correctly stated, â€œeither sexual intercourse 
    occurred or it did not.â€Â Â  If no sexual battery occurred, Guess would simply 
    be found not guilty of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  The evidence does 
    not otherwise support a charge of ABHAN.
  Under the evidence presented at trial, we conclude 
    the jury could not have inferred Guess took indecent liberties or familiarities 
    with the female victim â€“ an aggravating circumstance that would support a 
    conviction for ABHAN â€“ without finding him guilty of second-degree CSC with 
    a minor.Â  See Moultrie, 354 S.C. at 648, 583 S.E.2d at 437 (â€œUnder 
    the evidence presented, respondent was guilty of a sexual battery or no battery 
    at all.Â  In such a case, the defendant is not entitled to a charge of ABHAN 
    as a lesser-included offense of CSCM.â€).Â  Because there was no evidence to 
    support ABHAN, the trial court did not err in declining to charge ABHAN.
    CONCLUSION
    Based upon the foregoing, Guessâ€™s 
      conviction and sentence are
     AFFIRMED.
    HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J. and 
      CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jamethy W. Graham,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-400
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  22, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, South Carolina 
  Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of 
  Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.

  pled guilty to pointing and presenting a firearm and failure to stop for a blue 
  light.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent terms of three years in prison on each

On appeal, counsel for Appellant has filed a final 
  brief along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Appellant has not filed 
  a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant

PER CURIAM:Â  Paul A. Smith was tried and 
  convicted of voluntary manslaughter.Â  He was sentenced to life without parole, 
  per the two strikes law.Â  Smith appeals, arguing the judge erred by instructing 
  the jury on voluntary manslaughter when Smithâ€™s testimony showed he was acting 
  in self-defense and there was no evidence that Smith killed the decedent in 
  the heat of passion upon a sufficient legal provocation.Â  On appeal, counsel 
  for Smith has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 
  738 (1967), asserting that there were no meritorious grounds for appeal and 
  requesting permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Smith filed

After a thorough review of the record pursuant

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Daniel Webster Williams, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-408
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed June 24, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HOWARD, 
  J.: Daniel Webster Williams was convicted of shoplifting and assault 
  of a high and aggravated nature (â€œAHANâ€).Â  The circuit court sentenced Williams 
  to nine years imprisonment for shoplifting and one year imprisonment for AHAN.Â  
  On appeal, Williams argues the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to convict and sentence him to nine years imprisonment for shoplifting because 
  the indictment against him alleged an incorrect subsection of the shoplifting 
  statute.Â  Williams also argues the circuit court erred by denying his request 
  to charge the jury on simple assault as a lesser-included offense of AHAN.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
K-martâ€™s loss prevention manager allegedly saw Williams 
  concealing childrenâ€™s clothing in the front of his pants and jacket.Â Â  According 
  to the loss prevention manager, he attempted to stop Williams as he exited the 
  store.Â  Williams proceeded into the K-Mart parking lot, and the loss prevention 
  manager grabbed Williamsâ€™ arm.Â  Williams then began swinging at him with a box 
  cutter.Â  
As a result of this incident, Williams was indicted 
  and tried for shoplifting and AHAN.Â  At trial, the defense requested a jury 
  charge on the offense of simple assault as a lesser-included offense of AHAN.Â  
  The circuit court denied the request.Â  Subsequently, Williams was convicted 
  and sentenced to nine years imprisonment for shoplifting and one year imprisonment 
  for AHAN.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Indictment
Williams argues the 
  circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to convict and sentence him 
  to nine years imprisonment for shoplifting because the indictment against him 
  alleged an incorrect subsection of the shoplifting statute.Â  We disagree.
â€œIssues related to subject matter 
  jurisdiction may be raised at any time.â€Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 
  362, 495 S.E.2d 773, 777 (1998). A circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction 
  if: â€œ(1) there has been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; 
  (2) there has been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser included 
  offense of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  Id.Â Â  â€œThe true test 
  of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether it could be made more definite 
  and certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended 
  to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared 
  to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 
  (1995).Â  
â€œThe caption of an 
  indictment is no part of the finding of the grand jury; instead, it is the body 
  of the indictment that is important.â€Â  Tate v. State, 345 S.C. 577, 581, 
  549 S.E.2d 601, 603 (2001).Â  If the body of an indictment specifically states 
  the essential elements of the crime and is otherwise free from defect, a defect 
  in the caption will not cause it to be invalid.Â  Id.
South Carolina Code 
  Ann. section 16-13-110(A) is the statute prohibiting the offense of shoplifting.Â  
  Section 16-13-110(B), delineating potential sentences based on the value of 
  the shoplifted merchandise, provides:

A person who violates the provisions 
  of this section is guilty of a:Â  (1) misdemeanor triable in magistrateâ€™s court 
  and, upon conviction, must be fined not more than five hundred dollars or imprisoned 
  not more than thirty days if the value of the shoplifted merchandise is one 
  thousand dollars or less; (2) felony and, upon conviction, must be fined 
  not more than one thousand dollars or imprisoned not more than five years, or 
  both, if the value of the shoplifted merchandise is more than one thousand dollars 
  but less than five thousand dollars; (3) felony and, upon conviction, must be 
  imprisoned not more than ten years if the value of the shoplifted merchandise 
  is five thousand dollars or more.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-110 (B) 
  (Cum. Supp. 1995) (emphasis added).Â  
Here, the body of 
  the indictment charges Williams with shopliftingÂ  â€œchildrenâ€™s clothing valued 
  at approximately Three Hundred Dollars and No Cents ($300.00) . . . in violation 
  of Â§ 16-13-110 (Cum. Supp. 1995).â€Â  Although the body of the indictment does 
  not specify a subsection, shoplifting $300 of merchandise is a violation of 
  subsection (B)(1).Â  However, the caption on the reverse side of the indictment 
  references subsection 16-13-110(B)(3), which carries a greater sentence.Â  Williams 
  argues the caption incorrectly charges him with violating section 16-13-110 
  (B)(3) even though the body of the indictment charges him with shoplifting merchandise 
  valued at three hundred dollars, and the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to 
  convict and sentence him under section 16-13-110(B)(3).Â  
We first note, the 
  circuit court did not sentence Williams under section 16-13-110(B)(3).Â  Rather, 
  Williams was charged and convicted under section 16-13-110(B)(1) for shoplifting 
  merchandise valued at three hundred ($300) dollars, but was sentenced as a third 
  or subsequent offender under S.C. Code Ann. section 16-1-57 (Supp.1995) because 
  he admittedly had three or more prior convictions for shoplifting.Â  â€œA person 
  convicted of an offense for which the term of imprisonment is contingent upon 
  the value of the property involved must, upon conviction for a third or subsequent 
  offense, be punished as prescribed for a Class E felony.â€Â  A person convicted 
  of a Class E felony may be imprisoned for up to ten years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  16-1-20(A)(5) (Supp. 1995); see also State v. Lewis, 325 S.C. 
  324, 327, 478 S.E.2d 696, 698 (Ct. App. 1996).
Furthermore, the body 
  of the indictment in this case contained â€œthe necessary elements of the offense 
  intended to be charged and sufficiently apprise[d] the defendantâ€ of the allegations 
  against him.Â  Browning, 320 S.C. at 368, 465 S.E.2d at 359.Â  The body 
  of the indictment charged Williams with shoplifting $300 of childrenâ€™s clothing 
  in violation of section 16-13-110 and did not mention a subsection.Â  As Williams 
  was apprised of the charged offense, the error in the caption of the indictment 
  did not render the indictment invalid.Â  Tate, 345 S.C. at 581, 549 S.E.2d 
  at 603.Â  
As this was Williamsâ€™ third or subsequent 
  conviction for shoplifting, the circuit court properly sentenced him under the 
  enhanced penalties of S.C. Code Ann. section 16-1-57 (Supp.1995).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Jury Charge
Williams argues the circuit court erred by denying 
  his request to charge the jury on simple assault as a lesser-included offense 
  of AHAN.Â  We agree.
â€œThe law to be charged is determined from the facts 
  presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Lewis, 328 S.C. 273, 278, 494 S.E.2d 115, 
  117 (1997).Â  An instruction on a lesser-included offense is required when the 
  evidence presented indicates the defendant may be guilty only of a lesser offense.Â  
  A requested charge is properly refused where there is no evidence tending to 
  show the defendant was guilty only of the lesser offense.Â  State v. Tyndall, 
  336 S.C. 8, 16, 518 S.E.2d 278, 282 (1999).Â  However, a circuit court commits 
  reversible error if it fails to give a requested charge if there is evidence 
  from which it could be inferred the defendant committed the lesser, rather than 
  the greater offense.Â  State v. Sprouse, 325 S.C. 275, 285, 478 
  S.E.2d 871, 877 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
In determining whether a circuit court 
  erred in refusing to give a requested charge, an appellate court must review 
  the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  State v. Gadsden, 314 S.C. 
  229, 232, 442 S.E.2d 594, 597 (1994); see State v. Caulder, 287 
  S.C. 507, 513, 339 S.E.2d 876, 880 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding when reviewing a 
  jury charge, an appellate court must consider the charge as a whole and in light 
  of the evidence and issues presented at trial).
â€œThe test for determining when a crime is a lesser 
  included offense is whether the greater of the two offenses includes all the 
  elements of the lesser offense.â€Â  Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 81, 84, 530 
  S.E.2d 887, 888 (2000).
Assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) â€œis an unlawful 
  act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances of aggravation.â€Â  State 
  v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 580, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002).Â  Circumstances 
  of aggravation include the use of a deadly weapon, the intent to commit a felony, 
  infliction of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or physical 
  conditions of the parties, a difference in gender, the purposeful infliction 
  of shame and disgrace, taking indecent liberties or familiarities with a female, 
  and resistance to lawful authority.Â  Id. at 580-81, 564 S.E.2d. at 105-06.Â  
  â€œ[A]ssault of a high and aggravated nature contains the same elements of ABHAN 
  with the exception of the element of touching the victim . . . .â€Â  State 
  v. Murphy, 322 S.C. 321, 325, 471 S.E.2d 739, 741 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Simple 
  assault is an attempted battery or â€œan unlawful attempt or offer to commit a 
  violent injury upon another person, coupled with the present ability to complete 
  the attempt or offer by a battery.â€Â  State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 397, 
  532 S.E.2d 283, 285 (2000).Â  Thus, assault of a high and aggravated nature contains 
  all of the elements of simple assault, plus the circumstance of aggravation.Â  
  Consequently, simple assault is a lesser-included offense of assault of a high 
  and aggravated nature.Â  
At trial, the victim testified Williams attempted 
  to strike him with a box cutter.Â  The State argued the use of a box cutter constituted 
  the aggravating circumstance.Â  In contrast, Williams testified he did not have 
  any weapons, and he swung at the victim two or three times with his fist when 
  the victim grabbed him without explanation in the parking lot. 
Williamsâ€™ testimony provides evidence from which 
  the jury could find there was no box cutter, and in a light most favorable to 
  Williams, no circumstance of aggravation.Â  Therefore, his testimony would support 
  a conclusion he was guilty of the lesser offense of simple assault.Â  See 
  Â State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 397, 532 S.E.2d 283, 285 (2000) (holding 
  simple assault is an attempted battery or â€œan unlawful attempt or offer to commit 
  a violent injury upon another person, coupled with the present ability to complete 
  the attempt or offer by a battery.â€).Â  Consequently, the circuit court erred 
  in refusing to charge the lesser-included offense of simple assault.Â  Sprouse, 
  325 S.C. at 285, 478 S.E.2d at 877.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Williamsâ€™ conviction for shoplifting is AFFIRMED.Â  
  Williamsâ€™ conviction for assault of a high and aggravated nature is REVERSED, 
  and the case is REMANDED for a new trial on the indictment for AHAN.Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED. [1] 
GOOLSBY and BEATTY, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving any issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

title: Shuler v. SC Department of Public Safety
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
<!--
.Normal
	{font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";}

	{tab-stops:center 3.0in right 6.0in;
