THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Michael Shuler,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Public Safety,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-411Â Â Â 
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 24, 2004 


REVERSED


  
    
      
Patrick M. Teague, SeniorÂ  Asst. General Counsel, Frank L. Valenta, Jr., General 
  Counsel, SC Dept. of Motor Vehicles, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Timothy Clay Kulp, of N. Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court reversed 
  the ruling of an administrative officer to suspend the license of James Schuler. 
  We reverse.
 
  FACTS
An officer for the Mount Pleasant Police Department 
  arrested Respondent James Schuler on June 15, 2002. A citizen observed a vehicle 
  driving erratically and called the officer; the officer made the same observation. 
  The officer stopped the car, approached the car, asked the driver for his license, 
  registration, and insurance. Respondent was the driver. The officer smelled 
  alcohol on Respondent. Respondent was unsteady and his speech was slurred. Respondent 
  admitted that he had drunk some alcohol that evening. 
The officer placed Respondent under arrest for 
  driving under the influence and transported him to the police department. There, 
  the officer asked Respondent to take a DataMaster test. The officer is a certified 
  DataMaster operator. The officer placed Respondent in the DataMaster room and 
  told Respondent he was being videotaped. The officer read and gave the 
  Advisement of Implied Consent Rights / Videotaping to Respondent. However, Respondent 
  refused to take the test and the machine registered a refusal. Accordingly, 
  Respondentâ€™s driving license was suspended. 
Respondent requested an administrative hearing. 
  The administrative officer sustained the suspension. Respondent appealed to 
  the circuit court. The circuit court reversed, finding that to simply read Respondentâ€™s 
  rights to him did not meet the statutory requirements under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  56-5-2950. SCDPS appeals.
ISSUEÂ  
Did the trial court err by reversing the ruling 
  of the administrative officer finding that there was no substantial evidence 
  to support it?Â  
LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed 
  correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence. Kearse 
  v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Comm'n, 318 S.C. 198, 199, 456 S.E.2d 
  892, 893 (1995).Â  Substantial evidence is defined as â€œsuch evidence as a reasonable 
  mind might accept as adequate to support a conclusion.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 
  276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981).Â  A court may not substitute its 
  judgment for that of an agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions 
  of fact unless the agency's findings are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, 
  probative and substantial evidence on the whole record. Rodney v. Michelin 
  Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).                 
SCDPS asserts the trial court exceeded its scope of review 
  when the trial court substituted its judgment regarding a question of fact when 
  there was substantial evidence in the record to support administrative agencyâ€™s 
  findings.Â  We agree.Â  
Section 56-5-2950(a)(1) sets forth the procedures regarding 
  implied consent to testing for drugs or alcohol.Â  The statute mandates, in pertinent 
  part, that: 

No tests may be administered or samples obtained unless 
  the person has been informed in writing that:
â€¦
  1)    He does not have to take the test 
  or give the samples, but that his privilege to drive must be suspended or denied 
  for at least ninety days if he refuses to submit to the tests and that his refusal 
  may be used against him in court;
  2)    His privilege to drive must be suspended 
  for at least thirty days if he takes the tests or gives the samples and has 
  an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent or more;
  3)    He has the right to have a qualified 
  person of his own choosing conduct additional independent tests at his expense;
  4)    He has the right to request an administrative 
  hearing within thirty days of the issuance of the notice of suspension; and
  5)    If he does not request an administrative 
  hearing or if his suspension is upheld at the administrative hearing, he must 
  enroll in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003).
In reviewing the record, we believe there was substantial 
  evidence to support the administrative officerâ€™s ruling.Â  The officer read the 
  Implied Consent Rights form to Respondent and gave a copy of the rights to Respondent 
  prior to attempting to administer the DataMaster test. Therefore, Respondent 
  was advised â€“ in writing â€“ of his rights as they are enumerated in section 56-5-2950.Â  
  It is not required that the administrative officer enumerate how each portion 
  of the statute has been satisfied, only that substantial evidence exist to support 
  his decision.Â  Therefore, the trial court erred in reversing the administrative 
  officerâ€™s decision.
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

  for Appellant.

  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Benjamin W. Gosnell appeals 
  his conviction for first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Gosnellâ€™s 
  appellate counsel has petitioned to be relieved as counsel, stating she has 
  reviewed the record and has concluded Gosnellâ€™s appeal is without legal merit 
  sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  The issue briefed by counsel concerns whether 
  the trial court erred in not granting Gosnellâ€™s motion for a directed verdict 
  of acquittal.Â  Gosnell did not file a brief with this court on his own behalf.
After a review of the record as required 
  by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold the trial court committed no error 
  in denying Gosnellâ€™s motion for a directed verdict of acquittal, the evidence 
  being sufficient to support his conviction and sentence.Â  We also hold there 
  are no directly appealable issues in this case that are arguable on their merits.Â  
  Accordingly, we dismiss Gosnellâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be 
  relieved. [1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Dansa Chisolm appeals from 
  an order revoking his community supervision and imposing a one-year term of 
  imprisonment. [1] Â  He claims the revoking judge failed to comply 
  with the community supervision statute when she revoked his community supervision 
  status and required him to serve a one-year term of incarceration for his willful 
  violation of the conditions of supervision.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), 
  SCACR and the following authority: See State v. Hamilton, 333 
  S.C. 642, 648, 511 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1999) (challenge to validity of probation 
  revocation must be raised to and ruled on by the revocation judge to be preserved 
  for appellate review).
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.

of a stolen vehicle, pled guilty, and was sentenc

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sammy Brian Diggs,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-417
Submitted April 21, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  25, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellant Defender Tara S. Taggart, Office of 
  Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne D. White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Sammy Brian Diggs was indicted 
  for and pled guilty to felony driving under the influence resulting in death.Â  
  Diggsâ€™ appellate counsel submitted a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating 
  she reviewed the record and concluded Diggsâ€™ appeal is without merit.Â  Diggs 
  did not file a pro se brief with the court.
After a review of the record as required by Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues 
  that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Diggsâ€™ appeal and 
  grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
  [1] 
 APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  
    Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, 
    we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 and 220(b)(2), 
    SCACR.

  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
    BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY 
    RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
  THE STATE OF SOUTH 
    CAROLINA
  In The Court of 
    Appeals
  
  
    
      
        
  CMI Contracting, Inc.,       
  Respondent,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
  Little River Lodging, LLC and Construction Design Associates, 
          Inc., Defendants,
  of whom Little River Lodging, LLC, is,       
  Appellant.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Horry 
    County
  J. Stanton Cross, 
    Jr., Master-In-Equity
  
  Unpublished Opinion 
    No. 2004-UP-421
  Submitted June 8, 
    2004 â€“ Filed June 30, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
  W. W. DesChamps, Jr., of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
  Reese R. Boyd III, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Little River 
    Lodging, LLC, appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting judgment in favor of 
    CMI Contracting, Inc., on a mechanicâ€™s lien in the amount of $73,620.75.Â  
    The order also awarded CMI $18,055.95 in prejudgment interest and $8,533.70 
    in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  As an alternative but superceded ground for recovery, 
    the trial court found Little River liable to CMI for the amount of the alleged 
    mechanicâ€™s lien on the basis of CMIâ€™s unjust enrichment claim.Â  We affirm. 
    [1] 
  FACTS
  Little River is the 
    owner of a parcel of real estate situated in Horry County, South Carolina 
    upon which it sought to construct a commercial hotel development.Â  Through 
    its owner and operator, Bhupendra Patel, Little River contacted co-defendant 
    Construction Design Associates, Inc., (â€œCDAâ€), a general contractor, in February 
    2000 and asked CDA to begin working on the project.Â  CDA and Little River 
    understood the first phase of this project to include clearing the parcel 
    and filling some wetlands on the property.Â  Due to a longstanding professional 
    relationship between CDA and Little River, CDA did not initially require a 
    written agreement with Little River.Â  
  Subsequent to 
    these discussions concerning the property, CDA entered a subcontract agreement 
    with CMI for the clearing and wetland work to be performed on the property.Â  
    The subcontract agreement included a cost estimate from CMI of approximately 
    $118,000.Â  CMI began performing the agreed upon work in early March and completed 
    the work on April 11, 2000.Â  CDA and Patel visited the work site during the 
    months CMI performed the work specified in the subcontract agreement.Â  
  Following the 
    workâ€™s completion, CMI submitted invoices to CDA for payment totaling $123,621.Â  
    CDA then submitted $50,000 in payment to CMI after receiving a check for the 
    same amount and purpose from Patel of Little River.Â  This was the only payment 
    CMI received for the work.Â  Although an internal CDA document recognized a 
    $61,259 balance due CMI on the subcontracting work, Patel later claimed he 
    understood the $50,000 payment to be the complete amount due CMI for the project.Â  
  
  Little River and CDA 
    did not memorialize their general contracting agreement for developing the 
    property until October 2000.Â  The contract states work shall not commence 
    until all of the following are accomplished: 1) financing is in place and 
    designated for the project; 2) a building permit is obtained; and 3) written 
    notice to proceed is received by CDA.Â  Because construction financing could 
    not be obtained, CDA never commenced contract performance.Â  No hotel or other 
    structure exists on the property today.
  In the meantime, 
    CMI served a summons, complaint, and notice and certificate of a mechanicâ€™s 
    lien on the property on Little River on July 18, 2000 and to CDA on August 
    11, 2000.Â  In addition to the mechanicâ€™s lien, CMI asserted a claim against 
    Little River for unjust enrichment.Â  The trial court awarded CMI a judgment 
    of $100,210.40, the lien plus interest and attorneyâ€™s fees, against Little 
    River.Â  The court order also stated CMI was entitled to $73,620.75 on its 
    claim for unjust enrichment, but explained this award was â€œsuperceded by CMIâ€™s 
    judgment on its mechanicâ€™s lien.â€Â  This appeal followed.
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  A proceeding to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien is 
    an action at law.Â  Seckinger v. Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 386, 
    483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In an action at law, on appeal of a 
    case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed 
    upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports 
    the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 
    81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
  LAW / ANALYSIS
  I. Subject Matter Jurisdiction
  Little River argues the mechanicâ€™s lien 
    foreclosure should be reversed because the trial court lacked subject matter 
    jurisdiction over the matter due to untimely service.Â  We disagree.
  South Carolina Code section 29-5-90 provides, 
    in pertinent part: 
  
  [A] lien shall be dissolved unless the person desiring 
    to avail himself thereof, within ninety days after he ceases to labor on or 
    furnish labor or material for such building or structure, serves upon the 
    owner . . . a statement of a just true account of the amount due him . . . 
    together with a description of the property intended to be covered by the 
    lien . . . with the name of the owner of the property, if known.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (Supp. 2003). [b1]  Â  It is undisputed that CMI served this required 
    notice and certificate of a mechanicâ€™s lien on Little River after the statutorily 
    mandated ninety-day period.Â  However, when questioned at trial regarding the 
    sufficiency of the lienâ€™s service, the following exchange occurred between 
    the trial court and counsel for Little River:
  
  THE COURT:Â  Is there an issue about the technical aspects 
    of the mechanicâ€™s lien such as the notice, the certificate was given, the 
    timing of the foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien? All the technical aspects, 
    is that an issue?
  LITTLE RIVER:Â  I think the mechanicâ€™s lien was served and 
    everything.
  THE COURT:Â  I donâ€™t have the roll up here.
  LITTLE RIVER:Â  Iâ€™ve got some other points to argue, but 
    itâ€™s not regarding service or whether the mechanicâ€™s lien was properly prepared.
  
  The sufficiency of the lienâ€™s service was never again discussed 
    or raised before the trial court.
  While Little River certainly could have 
    argued the timeliness of the mechanicâ€™s lienâ€™s service as valid grounds to 
    dismiss the initial foreclosure action, it failed to do so.Â  Generally, an 
    issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
    to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.Â  
    Wilder v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  However, 
    Little River argues the issue of timeliness of service is one of subject matter 
    jurisdiction and, as such, may be raised at any time, including for the first 
    time on appeal.Â  See Johnson v. State, 319 S.C. 62, 64, 459 
    S.E.2d 840, 841 (1995) (stating issues related to subject matter jurisdiction 
    can be raised at any time).
  Subject matter jurisdiction has been defined 
    as â€œthe power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the 
    proceedings in question belong.â€Â  McLendon v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways and 
    Pub. Transp., 313 S.C. 525, 525-26, 443 S.E.2d 539, 540 (1994).Â  In McLendon, 
    the supreme court determined that a statute of limitations defense does not 
    raise a question of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 525-26, 443 
    S.E.2d at 540. The supreme court extended this holding to the time limits 
    set by statutes of creation. [2]  Simpson v. Sanders, 314 
    S.C. 413, 415 n.1, 445 S.E.2d 93, 94 n.1 (1994).Â  As such, issues of timeliness 
    of service, even when they arise from the mandatory terms of statutes of creation, 
    do not give rise to concerns of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  Thus, as Little River failed to raise to the trial court 
    the issue of whether the mechanicâ€™s lien in this case was timely served, this 
    issue is not properly preserved for our review.
  II. Absence of a Structure on the Building Site
  Little River contends the trial court 
    erred in enforcing the mechanicâ€™s lien because the absence of a building or 
    structure on the tract of land in question precludes attachment of the lien 
    to the land.Â  We disagree.
  The South Carolina mechanicâ€™s lien statute provides: 
  
  
  A person to whom a debt is due for labor performed . . 
    .Â  in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon 
    real estate . . . by virtue of an agreement with, or by consent of, the owner 
    of the building or structure, or a person having authority from, or rightfully 
    acting for, the owner in procuring or furnishing the labor or materials shall 
    have a lien upon the building or structure and upon the interest of the owner 
    of the building or structure in the lot of land upon which it is situated 
    to secure the payment of the debt due to him.Â  
  . . .
  [L]abor performed . . . includes . . . the work making 
    the real estate suitable as a site for the building or structure.Â  The work 
    is considered to include, but not be limited to, the grading, bulldozing, 
    leveling, excavating, and filling of land . . .
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  Little River relies on Clo-Car Trucking Co., 
    Inc. v. Clifflure Estates of South Carolina, 282 S.C. 573, 320 S.E.2d 
    51 (Ct. App. 1984), for the proposition that if no structure is erected on 
    a tract of land, a mechanicâ€™s lien, by the plain language of the statute, 
    cannot attach to the land.Â  In Clo-Car Trucking, the contractor, pursuant 
    to its contract with the previous owner, cleared and graded land for the construction 
    of streets and roads.Â  Neither the contractor nor anyone else did anything 
    more to the land.Â  This court held that, under section 29-5-10, â€œa mechanicâ€™s 
    lien cannot attach to land or to an ownerâ€™s interest in land where the work 
    done is unconnected with and forms no integral part of the erection, alteration, 
    or repair of either a building or a structure of some description.â€Â  Clo-Car 
    Trucking Co., Inc., 282 S.C. at 578, 320 S.E.2d at 54.
  We find A.V.A. Construction Corporation v. Santee Wando 
    Construction, 303 S.C. 333, 400 S.E.2d 498 (Ct. App. 1990), more instructive 
    on this issue.Â  In A.V.A. Construction, the contractor had contracted 
    to construct the tennis court, provide drainage facilities, build roads with 
    curbs, and clear and grade land in anticipation of development of a subdivision.Â  
    At the time the action was commenced, no houses had been constructed on any 
    of the lots.Â  Noting the General Assemblyâ€™s recent liberalization of the mechanicâ€™s 
    lien statute, this court found the mechanicâ€™s lien attached to the land because 
    the work was â€œprovided in order to make [the land] usable for building structures,â€ 
    notwithstanding the fact that the buildings were â€œyet to come.â€ [3] Â  Id. Â at 335, 400 S.E.2d at 500.Â  In 
    reaching this decision, this court expressly distinguished Clo-Car Trucking 
    on the factual basis that, in the earlier case, no allegation was made that 
    the clearing and grading were done in connection with the construction or 
    erection of any building or structure.Â  Id.
  We find the facts before this court more analogous 
    to those in A.V.A. Construction.Â  While no structure currently exists 
    on Little Riverâ€™s property, the work performed by CMI was clearly performed 
    in anticipation of the construction of a hotel and was provided to Little 
    River in order to make the plot suitable for such.Â  We find the statute sufficiently 
    broad to encompass labor essential to the ownerâ€™s development of his property, 
    regardless of the subsequent progress of that development.Â  
  III. Owner Consent
  Little River argues the trial court erred 
    in enforcing the mechanicâ€™s lien because there was no agreement with or consent 
    from the owner of the land, Little River, for CMI to perform the labor on 
    the land.Â  We disagree.
  Little River bases its argument on the language 
    of the mechanicâ€™s lien statute which provides:
  
  A person to whom a debt is due for labor performed . . 
    . in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon real 
    estate . . . by virtue of an agreement with, or by consent of, the owner 
    of the building or structure, or a person having authority from, or rightfully 
    acting for, the owner in procuring or furnishing the labor or materials 
    shall have a lien upon the building or structure and upon the interest of 
    the owner of the building or structure in the lot of land upon which it is 
    situated to secure the payment of the debt due to him.Â  
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  
    Little River contends, because no contract existed directly between it and 
    CMI, no consent was given to CMI to perform the labor on the land.Â  
  The consent required by section 29-5-10 is â€œsomething 
    more than a mere acquiescence in a state of things already in existence.Â  
    It implies an agreement to that which, but for the consent, could not exist, 
    and which the party has a right to forbid.â€Â  F & D Elec. Contractors, 
    Inc. v. Powder Coaters, Inc., 350 S.C. 454, 459-60, 567 S.E.2d 842, 844 
    (2002).Â  This consent does not require an express contract, but must indicate 
    â€œan agreement that the owner of . . . the land shall be, or may be, liable 
    for the materials or labor.â€Â  F & D Elec. Contractors, 350 S.C. 
    at 460, 567 S.E.2d at 845 (quoting St. Catherineâ€™s Church Corp. of Riverside 
    v. Technical Planning Assocs., 9 Conn.App. 682, 520 A.2d 1298 (Conn. Ct. 
    App. 1987)).
   F & D Elec. Contractors involved the 
    issue of owner consent regarding a mechanicâ€™s lien in a landlord-tenant context.Â  
    In such a context, the landlord/owner or his agent must directly give the 
    tenant or materialman express or implied consent acknowledging his liability 
    for the work.Â  The reasoning behind this requirement is manifest in the landlord-tenant 
    relationship.Â  A landlord/owner should not be liable for repairs or improvements 
    undertaken at the sheer caprice of a tenant, even if the landlord is aware 
    of the improvements or grants the tenant general permission to undertake them.Â  
    We find the situation before us now, however, quite different from that arising 
    within the landlord-tenant context.
  The labor performed by CMI was commenced and 
    completed at the sole behest of Little River, through its general contractor 
    CDA.Â  But for the consent and impetus of Little River, the labor on the plot 
    of land would not exist.Â  The labor was performed for the sole benefit of 
    Little River.Â  Its owner and operator, Patel, visited the sight and expressed 
    his satisfaction with the work.Â  These visits constitute more than mere acquiescence 
    of a particular state of the land.Â  Rather they are evidence that the work 
    commenced under the direction of Little River.Â  The evidence in the record 
    demonstrates the understanding between Little River and CDA, who shared a 
    longstanding professional relationship, that the work being performed on the 
    site by CMI was within the agreed upon scope of the essential first stage 
    of the propertyâ€™s development.Â  For these reasons, we conclude the work performed 
    by CMI on the hotel sight was commenced by consent of Little River.Â  Thus, 
    the enforcement of the lien was proper.
  IV. Monies due CDA from Little River 
  Little River argues that because no monies were due CDA at the 
    time CMI served its notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien, Little River 
    owes CMI nothing on the lien.Â  As this issue was not conclusively raised at 
    trial or ruled upon by the trial court in its final order, it is not preserved 
    for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 
    497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised 
    for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon 
    by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
  V.Â  Award of in personam judgment 
  Little River argues 
    the trial court erred in awarding CMI a monetary in personam judgment against 
    Little River without ordering the sale of the property to pay the mechanicâ€™s 
    lien indebtedness.Â  It asserts this issue is one of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
    We disagree with this assertion.Â  As stated above, subject matter jurisdiction 
    concerns â€œthe power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which 
    the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  McLendon v. South Carolina Department 
    of Highways and Public Transportation, 313 S.C. 525, 525-26, 443 S.E.2d 
    539, 540 (1994).
  
  There is a wide difference between a want of jurisdiction 
    in which case the court has no power to adjudicate at all, and a mistake in 
    the exercise of undoubted jurisdiction in which case the action of the trial 
    court is not void although it may be subject to direct attack on appeal.Â  
    A judgment will not be vacated for a mere irregularity which does not affect 
    the justice of the case, and of which the party could have availed himself, 
    but did not do so until judgment was rendered against him.
  
  Thomas & Howard Co. v. 
    T.W. Graham and Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995) (citations 
    omitted).
  â€œWhen a court acts with proper subject matter jurisdiction 
    but takes some action outside of its authority, the party against whom the 
    act is done must object and directly appeal.â€Â  Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 
    342, 348, 588 S.E.2d 624, 627 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
  Here, the trial court certainly had the power to hear and 
    determine mechanicâ€™s lien cases.Â  Its failure to order the sale of the property 
    involved is, at the most, a mistake in the exercise of its undoubted jurisdiction.Â  
    As Little River failed to raise this omission to the trial court in a post-trial 
    motion, the issue is not properly before this court.Â  See Padgett 
    v. Mercado, 341 S.C. 229, 233, 533 S.E.2d 339, 341 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating 
    a post-trial motion must be made where there are errors or inconsistencies 
    in the trial courtâ€™s order).
    VI.          
  Amount of attorneyâ€™s fees 
     
  Little River argues the trial court erred in its award 
    of attorneyâ€™s fees to CMI as the court failed to make specific findings of 
    fact on the record for each of the six factors necessary for consideration 
    in determining such an award.Â  Little River, however, failed to raise to the 
    trial court its concern over a lack of consideration of these factors in the 
    form of a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP.Â  
    Accordingly, this issue is not properly before this court.Â  See Wilder 
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic 
    that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have 
    been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate 
    review.â€); Baker v. Wolfe, 333 S.C. 605, 614, 510 S.E.2d 726, 731 (Ct. 
    App. 1998) (noting where record did not indicate appellant objected to the 
    reasonableness of the hours or fees, either at the hearing or by way of a 
    motion to reconsider, the issue was not properly before the court).Â  Furthermore, 
    because the mechanicâ€™s lien was proper, we find the trial court properly granted 
    CMI attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  VII.Â  Unjust Enrichment
  Because we conclude the mechanicâ€™s lien 
    was properly enforced against Little River, we need not address Little Riverâ€™s 
    exceptions to the trial courtâ€™s ruling on CMIâ€™s unjust enrichment claim.Â  
    See Hodge v. First Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n, 267 S.C. 270, 
    275, 227 S.E.2d 310, 312 (1976) (stating that because the appellant had failed 
    to establish error in the enforcement of the mechanicâ€™s lien, the personal 
    judgment premised upon the contingency of the invalidity of the lien was academic).Â  
  
  CONCLUSION
  For the foregoing reasons, the order of the trial court 
    is
   AFFIRMED.
  ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  
    


 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Although similar in operation, a statute that creates a new liability 
    and affixes the time within which an action may be commenced is not a statute 
    of limitation but a statute of creation.Â  Simpson v. Sanders, 314 S.C. 
    413, 415, 445 S.E.2d 93, 94 (1994); Knight Pub. Co. v. University of South 
    Carolina, 295 S.C. 31, 33, 367 S.E.2d 20, 21 (1988) (overruled on other 
    grounds in Simpson v. Sanders, 314 S.C. 413, 445 S.E.2d 93 (1994)).

 
   
    [3]  Little River contends, in A.V.A Constr. Corp. v. Santee Wando 
    Constr., 303 S.C. 333, 400 S.E.2d 498 (Ct. App. 1990), the this court 
    determined the constructed tennis courts and roads to be â€œstructuresâ€ under 
    the act.Â  We find nothing in that opinion that would reflect this interpretation 
    by the court of the mechanicâ€™s lien statute or the facts of that case.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Celeste Durant,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-422
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of S.C. Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In April 2001, the Horry County 
  grand jury indicted Celeste Durant and Chad Smith for homicide by child abuse 
  and aiding and abetting homicide by child abuse in the death of Durantâ€™s twenty-month-old 
  daughter.Â  Following a jury trial, both Durant and Smith were convicted and 
  sentenced to twenty years on each count, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  
  In this appeal, Durant argues the trial court erred in (1) failing to direct 
  a verdict for her on both charges based on the insufficiency of evidence and 
  (2) by refusing to dismiss the charges against her based on the Stateâ€™s loss 
  of certain evidence and the Stateâ€™s refusal to stipulate as to the loss of the 
  evidence.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Issue 1:Â  State 
  v. Lindsey, 355 S.C. 15, 20, 583 S.E.2d 740, 742 (2003) (â€œOn an appeal from 
  the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the appellate court 
  may only reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial 
  courtâ€™s ruling.â€); State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 62, 502 S.E.2d 63, 69 
  (1998) (â€œIn reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the evidence 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the State, and if there is any 
  direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending 
  to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find that the case 
  was properly submitted to the jury.â€); State v. Smith, Op. No. 3804 (S.C. 
  Ct. App. filed June 1, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 23 at 36) (holding in the 
  co-defendantâ€™s case, given the evidence submitted by the State (1) on the severity 
  and number of injuries to the victim; (2) that both Smith and Durant were the 
  only two people with the child during the timeframe that she sustained her devastating 
  injuries; (3) that her impairment should have been obvious to these two adults; 
  and (4) that there was a possible cover-up, there was substantial circumstantial 
  evidence on both charges such that the case was properly submitted to the jury); 
  Issue 2:Â  State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 538-39, 552 S.E.2d 300, 
  307 (2001) (â€œThe State does not have an absolute duty to preserve potentially 
  useful evidence that might exonerate a defendant.Â  To establish a due process 
  violation, a defendant must demonstrate (1) that the State destroyed the evidence 
  in bad faith, or (2) that the evidence possessed an exculpatory value apparent 
  before the evidence was destroyed and the defendant cannot obtain other evidence 
  of comparable value by other means.â€).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] We 
    decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Brenda C. Gilmore, Teresa Ann Moore, Sena Austin Pearl, 
  Susan Marie Buksa, Sharon Williams Ford, Rolanda Patice Lewis, Mary Kate Green, 
  Kari Anne O'Keefe, Jan Lynn McWells, Deborah Ann Cooke, Robert James Phillips, 
  Joye Denise Rymar, Steven Michael Poth, Lisa Ann McIntyre, Robert Warham, Jennifer 
  Percy, Yvonne Cox, Caroline Carmichael, Michele Tholen, Paul Fulton, John Sparozic, 
  Peggy Graham, Regina Brandon, Stephanie Foresterio, Charalene Harris, Betty 
  Phillips Nichole Kathleen Lambert, Karen Rochelle Lee, Lisa Michelle Cox, Wilbert 
  Thomas Grissett, Tastonia Michelle Myatt, Michael Katen, Sondra L. Katen, Joann 
  Morris, Beth Fogle, and Michelle
Ventura,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Holiday Network Int., Inc., DEI Marketing, Holiday Network 
  Int. of GA, Inc., Dan McGeown, Susan McGeown, Scott McLaren and Dan Carmichael,Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Defendants,
Of whom Dan McGeown and Scott McLaren are the,       
Appellants.
Mary Thaggard, Dena Pearl, Dessie Coates, Julianna
Boundy, James E. Cameron, 
        Lisa J. Fera, Brad McCray, Ashley Rowell, Judy Carayiannis, Patricia
Hanick, 
        Frank Cross, Megan Weber, Jay Baker, Carol Shanks, Joanne Mianti, et al., 
        on behalf of themselves and all other similary situated,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Holiday Network Int., Inc., DEI Marketing, Holiday Network Int. of GA, 
        Inc., Dan McGeown, Susan McGeown, Scott McLaren, and Dan Carmichael,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Dan McGeown and Scott McLaren are the,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-423
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Fred B. Newby and C. Scott Masel, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellants.
Gene McCain Connell, Jr. and Norwood David DuRant, both of 
  Surfside Beach, and Richard S. Joye, of Murrells Inlet, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dan McGeown and Scott McLaren 
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s order holding them individually liable to employees 
  of a closed business for unpaid wages under the South Carolina Payment of Wages 
  Act and theory of promissory estoppel.Â Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part. [1]  Â Â  Â Â 
FACTS
This case arises after the sudden closing of Holiday Network 
  International, Inc.Â  McGeown was the president and owner of Holiday Network.Â  
  McGeown did not live in state, but would visit the Myrtle Beach office every 
  couple of months for approximately a weekâ€™s duration.Â  McGeown signed the payroll 
  checks and generally ran the business without regard to corporate formalities.Â  
  McLaren was the vice president, marketing director, and effectively acted as 
  the â€œbossâ€ at the Myrtle Beach location when McGeown was absent.Â  After the 
  close of Holiday Network, McLaren was transferred to a business owned by McGeown 
  in Florida.Â  
When Holiday Network suddenly closed, the employees 
  were left without payment for wages due.Â  These employees were to have been 
  paid the last day the business operated, a Friday.Â  However, McLaren explained 
  to them payment was late due to a delayed Federal Express delivery.Â  McLaren 
  told employees if any of them were in desperate need of money prior to Monday, 
  they could come to his house and he would sell his golf clubs to give them money 
  from the sale.Â  At least one employee testified he went to McLarenâ€™s house to 
  accept his offer, but McLaren did not answer the door.Â  
On Sunday, McGeown told the bookkeeper that he 
  would personally see that everyone was paid.Â  This same employee testified that 
  in her capacity as bookkeeper, she relayed this information to all of the employees 
  who called her home.Â  Many other employees also testified as to direct communication 
  between themselves and McGeown and his promise they would be paid.Â  Others testified 
  they tried to contact McGeown in Florida, but could never speak to him personally.Â  
  Holiday Network was closed that Monday.Â  
Left without wages they had earned, the employees 
  filed suit against the Holiday Network, McGeown, and McLaren.Â  The circuit court 
  granted the employees partial summary judgment, declaring that they were employees 
  of Holiday Network as a matter of law.Â  The case subsequently was referred to 
  the master-in-equity for trial.Â  The trial court held McGeown and McLaren liable 
  for the unpaid wages under a theory of promissory estoppel and pursuant to the 
  South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-10 et seq.Â  
  In addition, the court trebled the damages and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant 
  to the statute.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2003).
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When legal and equitable actions are maintained 
  in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes 
  of the applicable standard of review on appeal. Â Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 
  89, 485 S.E.2d 97 (1997). Â An action for promissory estoppel is equitable in 
  nature.Â  West v. Newberry Elec. Co-op., 357 S.C. 537, 542, 593 S.E.2d 
  500, 502 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Thus, in reviewing the action for promissory estoppel, 
  we may determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Jocoy v. Jocoy, 349 S.C. 441, 444, 562 S.E.2d 674, 
  675 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, we are not required to disregard the findings 
  of the trial court, which saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibiliy.Â  Id. Â In the action pursuant to the South 
  Carolina Payment of Wages Act, which is an action at law, this courtâ€™s scope 
  of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  See Evans 
  v. Taylor Made Sandwich Co. 337 S.C. 95, 101, 522 S.E.2d 350, 353 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (stating factual disputes under the Payment of Wages Act are to be determined 
  by a jury); Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 294, 592 S.E.2d 315, 318 (Ct. 
  App. 2003) (stating the standard of review for an action at law).Â  The factual 
  findings of the trial court will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review 
  of the record reveals there is no evidence which reasonably supports the courtâ€™s 
  findings.Â  Sims, at 294-95, 592 S.E.2d at 318.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  1.     Promissory Estoppel  
McGeown and McLaren argue the trial court erred 
  in finding liability against both of them based on a theory of promissory estoppel.Â  

A successful claim under promissory estoppel requires 
  four elements: (1) the presence of a promise unambiguous in its terms, (2) reasonable 
  reliance upon the promise by the party to whom the promise is made, (3) the 
  reliance is expected and foreseeable by the party who makes the promise, and 
  (4) the party to whom the promise is made must sustain injury in reliance on 
  the promise.Â  Satcher v. Satcher, 351 S.C. 477, 483-484, 570 S.E.2d 535, 
  538 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThe applicability of the doctrine [of promissory estoppel] 
  depends on whether the refusal to apply it â€˜would be virtually to sanction the 
  perpetration of a fraud or would result in other injustice.â€™â€Â  Id.Â  at 
  484, 570 S.E.2d at 538 (citation omitted).
McLaren was not the owner of Holiday Network; instead 
  he only managed the Myrtle Beach operation during McGeownâ€™s absence.Â  Although 
  he made representations to some of the other employees that they would be paid, 
  McLaren neither had control over the actual signing and sending of these paychecks 
  nor did he personally assume any obligation.Â  The employees place much emphasis 
  on McLarenâ€™s offer to sell his golf clubs and pay any employees that could not 
  wait for their paycheck.Â  However, it would be inequitable to use this offer 
  of charity to impose liability on McLaren personally.
As to the claims against McGeown, the employees 
  presented testimony that McGeown promised them that they would be paid.Â  According 
  to the bookkeeper, he assured her that he would personally see to everyone being 
  paid.Â  She then relayed this assurance to other employees.Â  Although the employees 
  presented this testimony as evidence of McGeownâ€™s promise to personally pay 
  them, they did not present any evidence of any injury caused by reliance on 
  this promise.Â  
According to the testimony, the earliest McGeown 
  made the promise to pay was the last day Holiday Network operated, a Friday.Â  
  There is no evidence any employee continued working in reliance on either McGeown 
  or McLarenâ€™s promises.Â  In fact, the next business day, a Monday, Holiday Network 
  was closed.Â  As the employees did not establish every element of promissory 
  estoppel, their cause of action based on this theory must fail.Â  
  2.     South Carolina Payment of Wages Act  

a.Â  Liability under the 
  South Carolina Payment of Wages Act

McGeown and McLaren argue 
  they were not employers who knowingly permitted the corporation to violate the 
  South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.Â  We affirm as to McGeown and reverse as 
  to McLaren.
The South Carolina Payment of Wages Act provides 
  â€œevery employer in the State shall pay wages due. . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-40(A) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  The statute further defines an â€œemployerâ€ as a â€œcorporation . 
  . . and any agent or officer of the above classes employing any person in this 
  State.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-10(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  As this court explained, 
  â€œthe legislature intended to impose individual liability on agents or officers 
  of a corporation who knowingly permit their corporation to violate the 
  Act.Â  To hold otherwise would require us to ignore the words â€˜and any agent 
  or officer of the above classes.â€™â€ Dumas v. Infosafe Corp., 320 S.C. 
  188, 195, 463 S.E.2d 641, 645 (Ct. App. 1995) (emphasis added).Â  In Dumas, 
  the court imposed individual liability under the Payment of Wages Act upon a 
  business president, who was also the sole shareholder.Â  
Under a plain reading of the actâ€™s definition of 
  â€œemployer,â€ both McGeown and McLaren may be considered employers.Â  They were 
  both â€œofficers,â€ president and vice president respectively, of a â€œcorporation,â€ 
  Holiday Network.Â  Dumas requires this court to determine whether McGeown 
  and McLaren â€œknowingly permittedâ€ the business to violate the Payment of Wages 
  Act.Â  McGeown was the owner, ran the business, directed the employees, signed 
  the payroll checks, and continually promised various employees that he would 
  pay them.Â  We find the evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s determination that 
  McGeown did knowingly permit the business to violate the act.
However, the trial court made no findings of fact 
  concerning McLarenâ€™s ability or power within the business as it related to the 
  payment of payroll.Â  Despite McLarenâ€™s title as vice president, it was not in 
  his power to pay the employees.Â  Instead, payment was in McGeownâ€™s power.Â  McLaren 
  could not knowingly permit the business to withhold wages, because there 
  is no indication that he had the authority or power to grant or withhold wages.Â  
  Therefore, we find the trial court erred in holding McLaren liable under the 
  South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.

b.Â  The law of the case

McGeown 
  [2]  argues a prior court order is the law of the case and holds he is not 
  an employer of any of the plaintiffs.Â Â  We disagree.
A prior circuit court order 
  stated it â€œgrants partial summary judgment to the Plaintiffs and finds, as a 
  matter of law, that they were employees of Defendant, Holiday Network Int., 
  Inc.â€Â  The order justifies its decision based on the fact that the employees 
  presented, among other things, payroll check stubs to them from the business.Â  
  It is important to note that this order was issued in the shadow of denials 
  to two sets of requests for admission from the employees asking Holiday Network 
  to admit it employed them and that they received paychecks from it.Â  
The definition of â€œemployerâ€ under the South Carolina 
  Payment of Wages Act clearly envisions the existence of multiple employers.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. 41-10-10(1); Dumas v. Infosafe Corp., 320 S.C. 
  188, 463 S.E.2d 641 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding both the company and its president 
  liable under the Act).Â  The circuit court order does not prohibit the existence 
  of other â€œemployers,â€ but merely declares that the employees were employees 
  of Holiday Network.Â  This definition neither actually nor by implication prohibits 
  the naming of other parties as being â€œemployers,â€ if such a determination is 
  legally and factually supported.Â  Therefore, we find this order does not limit 
  the application of the status as â€œemployerâ€ to Holiday Network exclusively.

c.Â  Treble damages

McGeown argues the damages should not be trebled 
  because he did not act intentionally or in bad faith.Â  
Section 41-10-80(C) of the South Carolina Wage 
  Payment Act provides in part:
In case of any failure to pay wages due to an employee as 
  required by Section 41-10-40 or 41-10-50 the employee may recover in a civil 
  action an amount equal to three times the full amount of the unpaid wages, plus 
  costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees as the court may allow.
S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2003).
The decision of whether to award treble damages 
  is within the discretion of the trial court.Â  Rice v. Multimedia, Inc., 
  318 S.C. 95, 98, 456 S.E.2d 381, 383 (1995).Â  In holding the award of treble 
  damages was discretionary, the court explained, â€œThis interpretation accords 
  with the purpose of the Wage Payment Act, to wit:Â  to protect employees from 
  the unjustified and wilful retention of wages by the employer.Â  The imposition 
  of treble damages in those cases where there is a bona fide dispute would be 
  unjust and harsh.â€Â  Id.Â Â  The court cautioned, â€œIf there is a dispute 
  over unpaid wages the employer acts at his peril and the court in its discretion 
  may award treble damages when the withholding was unreasonable and there was 
  no good faith wage dispute.â€Â  Id. Â at 99, 456 S.E.2d at 383.Â  In Rice, 
  pursuant to its handbook policy, the company refused to pay the employee commissions 
  on seven contracts following his termination.Â  Id. Â at 97, 456 S.E.2d 
  at 382.Â  The supreme court held the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in refusing to award treble damages because there was no evidence the employer 
  acted intentionally and in bad faith.Â  Id.Â  at 99-100, 456 S.E.2d at 
  384.
In the present case, it is undisputed that the 
  employees are entitled to the wages they seek.Â  McGeown was the president and 
  owner of Holiday Network, which suddenly closed its doors leaving its employees 
  without their wages.Â  We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in 
  trebling the employeesâ€™ damages.Â  

d.Â  Attorneyâ€™s fees

McGeown argues the trial court awarded attorneyâ€™s 
  fees without making the necessary findings pursuant to Baron Data Systems, 
  Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296 (1989) 
  [3] .Â  McGeown, however, failed to raise to the trial court his concern 
  over a lack of consideration of these factors in the form of a motion to alter 
  or amend the judgment.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  
  See Wilder v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) 
  (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, 
  but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved 
  for appellate review.â€); Padgett v. Mercado, 341 S.C. 229, 233, 533 S.E.2d 
  339, 341 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating any argument alleging an inaccuracy or inconsistency 
  in an order must be raised by a post-trial motion).Â  
  3.     Affidavits and absent employees  
McGeown argues the master-in-equity erred by admitting affidavits 
  and
evidence of absent employees.Â  We find these issues 
  are not properly before this court.
The trial court admitted the affidavits of employees 
  Regina Brandon and Robert Warham, who were not present at trial, in which the 
  two employees stated the amount of wages owed them.Â  At trial, McGeownâ€™s counsel 
  objected to the admission of the affidavits arguing:Â  â€œI will have to object 
  just because these individuals are not here and plaintiffs as a general rule 
  canâ€™t present their case by way of their own affidavit.â€Â  On appeal, however, 
  McGeown argues the affidavits were inadmissible because they were hearsay.Â  
  A party may not argue one ground for objection at trial and a different ground 
  on appeal.Â  Murray v. Bank of America, 354 S.C. 337, 347, 580 S.E.2d 
  194, 199 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Accordingly, this argument is not preserved.
McGeown also argues the trial court erred in awarding 
  judgments in favor of a number of employees who did not appear to testify at 
  trial.Â  Although the trial court ruled that these employees could present evidence 
  at a subsequent hearing, no such hearing ever occurred.Â  McGeown failed to raise 
  to the trial court his objection to the judgments in favor of these employees 
  either during the trial or in a post-trial motion.Â  Thus, this argument is not 
  preserved.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  731, 733 (1998)(â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge 
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 
  311 S.C. 56, 60, 427 S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993) (stating that although the appellant 
  learned for the first time upon receiving the order on a post-trial motion that 
  the respondent would be granted certain additional relief, the appellant must 
  move under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment to preserve the 
  issue).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the trial courtâ€™s judgment 
  in favor of the employees on their cause of action for promissory estoppel is 
  reversed as to both McGeown and McLaren.Â  The courtâ€™s imposition of individual 
  liability under the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act is reversed as to McLaren 
  and affirmed as to McGeown.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â  As we found above McLaren is not liable under 
    the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, we address the remaining issues as 
    they pertain to McGeown alone.

 
   [3] These factors are:Â  (1) the nature, extent and 
    difficulty of the legal services rendered; (2) the time and labor necessarily 
    devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency 
    of compensation; (5) the fee customarily charged in the locality for similar 
    legal services; and (6) the beneficial results obtained.Â  Baron, 297 
    S.C. at 384-85, 377 S.E.2d at 297.

title: Jacobsen v. American Agviation

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Val Jacobsen,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
American Agviation, Inc., and
Transland, Inc.,        Appellants,
      
    
  



  
    
      
Loretta W. Jacobsen,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
American Agviation, Inc., and
Transland, Inc.,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-424
Heard June 10, 2004 â€“ Filed June 30, 2004

VACATED


  
    
      
Celeste T. Jones and Benjamin E. Nicholson, V, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellants.
John E. Parker and Grahame E. Holmes, both of Walterboro, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Respondents, Val Jacobsen and 
  his wife Loretta, brought suits against appellants, American Agviation, Inc. 
  and Transland, Inc., seeking redress for injuries Val suffered in the crash 
  of his crop duster plane.Â  When both companies failed to appear for trial, the 
  court held a bench trial in their absence and awarded the Jacobsens over $12 
  million in damages.Â  Agviation and Transland then filed motions for a new trial 
  or, in the alternative, to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, amend 
  findings of fact, alter or amend the judgment, open judgment for additional 
  testimony, and/or for relief from judgment.Â  The court denied all their motions 
  and Agviation and Transland now appeal, asserting procedural errors and contending 
  the trial court lacked personal jurisdiction.Â  For the reasons set forth below, 
  we vacate the trial courtâ€™s order.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In August 1994, Val Jacobsen, a high school 
  teacher and part-time crop duster, telephoned American Agviation, an Arkansas 
  company, to request information on an aircraft the company was selling.Â  American 
  Agviation responded with a letter to Val describing the plane.Â  On August 19, 
  1994, after several telephone conversations with Agviationâ€™s president negotiating 
  the price and an overhaul to the plane, Jacobsen traveled to Arkansas and purchased 
  the used 1970 Grumman Ag-Cat airplane.Â  Val used the plane strictly for crop 
  dusting.Â  On the morning of July 14, 1996, Val was severely burned when the 
  aircraft crashed shortly after takeoff.Â  
On July 8, 1999, Val filed suit against 
  Agviation and Transland, Inc. in the Hampton County Court of Common Pleas for 
  injuries he received in the crash.Â  On July 9, 1999, Loretta filed a loss of 
  consortium action against the two companies.Â  The Jacobsens alleged the plane 
  caught fire shortly after Valâ€™s take-off, and when he attempted to dump his 
  load of chemicals in order to land safely, the defective design of the crop 
  dusting device prevented him from doing so causing him to crash into a tree.Â  
  As to Agviation, the Jacobsens claimed the company negligently sold Val an airplane 
  with defective exhaust stacks.Â  As to Transland, the Jacobsens claimed it negligently 
  designed the planeâ€™s dumping system in such a way that â€œthe system could unintentionally 
  be in a position to prevent emergency dumping,â€ thereby causing Valâ€™s injuries.Â  
  The Jacobsensâ€™ complaints contained a demand for a jury trial.Â  
The companies, upon receipt of the Jacobsensâ€™ 
  Summons and Complaint, each responded by writing a letter to the Jacobsensâ€™ 
  attorney, John Parker.Â  On July 9, 1999, Translandâ€™s president, Conrad Barlow, 
  replied with a letter sent by facsimile and certified mail, informing Parker 
  that Transland did not manufacture the dumping device on the airplane.Â  On August 
  4, 1999, Agviationâ€™s president, Frank Kelly, also responded through a letter 
  to Parker, raising factual defenses and asserting the South Carolina court did 
  not have jurisdiction over Agviation.Â  This letter contained the following carbon 
  copy information in its postscript:

STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
Office of Jim Miles, SECRETARY OF STATE
Court of Common Pleas/County of Hampton
P. O. Box 11350
Columbia, S.C. 29211

Transland also sent a copy of its responsive letter 
  to the above address on August 9, 1999.Â  
Transland maintained it received six separate notices 
  of roster meetings in the matter.Â  Agviation indicated it received eight such 
  notices.Â  After receiving one of the notices from the Hampton County Clerk of 
  Court, Translandâ€™s president, Barlow, sent a letter to the Jacobsensâ€™ attorney 
  on September 4, 2001, noting the roster included his name under American Agviation 
  and insisting he had no affiliation to Agviation.Â  After receiving a roster 
  meeting notice in January 2002, Transland sent another letter dated February 
  11, 2002, this one to The Hampton County Clerk of Court, expressing confusion 
  over the matter, enclosing correspondence with the Jacobsensâ€™ attorney, and 
  requesting it be removed from the lawsuit.Â  
On December 17, 2001, the Hampton County Clerk 
  of Court mailed a roster of cases for the January 28, 2002 term of court to 
  Agviation and Transland.Â  The notice was addressed to â€œAttorneys At Lawâ€ and 
  stated as follows:

There will be a term of Common Pleas Court on JANUARY 28, 2002 
  beginning at 9:30 a.m.Â  The Honorable Rodney A. Peeples will be the presiding 
  judge.Â  The jury will report at 2:00 p.m.
 Enclosed you will find a copy of the roster and a Pre-Trial Brief.Â  
  Please fill out a Brief for each case you have on this roster.Â  Bring three 
  (3) copies to the Roster Meeting January 28, 2002.Â  If you have any questions, 
  please contact the Administrative Judgeâ€™s office at (843) 549-7878.Â  Please 
  follow all telephone calls to the Judge or Clerkâ€™s office with a faxed or mailed 
  letter.

The notice also gave the name, address, and phone and fax numbers for the 
  Administrative Judge.Â  The Jacobsensâ€™ two suits against Agviation and Transland 
  were placed as cases 9 and 10 on the roster of 108 cases.Â  Their case listings 
  included the names of John Parker under the Jacobsens and Conrad Barlow under 
  American Agviation, and indicated â€œPRE-TRIAL DATE:Â  00/00/0000.â€Â  
On January 28, 2002 when the cases were called 
  to trial, neither Transland nor Agviation appeared before the court to defend 
  against the Jacobsensâ€™ claims.Â  At that time, the Jacobsens proceeded with a 
  bench trial and their attorney presented a full case on the merits, eliciting 
  testimony and introducing evidence to substantiate the Jacobsensâ€™ claims.Â  By 
  order filed February 14, 2002, the court determined its exercise of personal 
  jurisdiction over Agviation and Transland was proper, and found both companies 
  liable for Jacobsenâ€™s injuries and his wifeâ€™s loss of consortium, awarding them 
  over $12 million in damages.Â  Thereafter, Agviation and Transland retained legal 
  counsel and filed timely motions for a new trial or, in the alternative, to 
  dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, amend findings of fact, alter or 
  amend the judgment, open judgment for additional testimony, and/or for relief 
  from judgment.Â  In these motions, Agviation and Transland asserted various grounds 
  for the court to set aside the judgment or grant a new trial, including but 
  not limited to the following: (1) they were not given notice the case was transferred 
  to the non-jury roster and they did not consent to such transfer; (2) they were 
  not given adequate notice of the trial; (3) they were not given a hearing on 
  their motion to dismiss; (4) they were not given notice that, as a party, they 
  were required to attend the roster meeting; and (5) the court lacked personal 
  jurisdiction over them.Â  Following a hearing, the court denied each of their 
  motions.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS



 
 On appeal, Agviation and Transland contend 
  the trial court erred in sua sponte transferring their cases to 
  the non-jury docket.Â  We agree.
Rule 38, SCRCP governs the right to trial by jury 
  and provides in pertinent part:

(a) Right Preserved.Â  The right of trial by jury as declared 
  by the Constitution or as given by a statute of South Carolina shall be preserved 
  to the parties inviolate.Â  Issues of fact in an action for the recovery of 
  money only or of specific real or personal property must be tried by 
  a jury, unless a jury trial be waived.
(d) Waiver.Â  The failure of a party to serve a 
  demand as required by this rule and to file it as required by Rule 5(d) 
  constitutes a waiver by him of trial by jury.Â  A demand for trial 
  by jury made as herein provided may not be withdrawn without the consent of 
  the parties, except where an opposing party is in default under Rule 55(a).

Rule 38 (a) and (d), SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  Further, Rule 
  39 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, provides in pertinent part 
  as follows:

When trial by jury has been demanded as provided in Rule 
  38, the action shall be designated upon the calendar and the clerkâ€™s filebook 
  as a jury action.Â  The trial of all issues so demanded shall be by 
  jury, unless (1) the parties or their attorneys of record, by written 
  stipulation filed with the court or by an oral stipulation made in open court 
  and entered in the record, consent to trial by the court sitting without a jury 
  or (2) the court upon motion or its own initiative finds that a right of trial 
  by jury of some or all of those issues does not exist.

Rule 39(a), SCRCP (emphasis added).
In their motions before the trial court, Appellants 
  requested the court set aside the judgment or grant them a new trial on the 
  ground that they were not given proper notice that the cases were transferred 
  from the jury roster to the non-jury roster, and they did not consent to such 
  a transfer.Â  In denying the motion on this basis, the trial court indicated 
  it considered Appellants to technically be in default for failing to properly 
  answer within the time prescribed under the rules [1] .Â  However, it noted that the Jacobsens never 
  moved pursuant to Rule 55(a) to have the defaults entered upon the calendar, 
  [2]  and therefore Appellants â€œdid not waive their right to a trial by jury 
  pursuant to Rule 38(d).â€Â  The court further recognized the constraints of Rule 
  39(a), SCRCP, requiring consent of all parties before issues in which a jury 
  trial is demanded can be heard non-jury, unless the right to trial by jury does 
  not exist for some or all of the issues.Â  Nonetheless, it denied the motion 
  finding â€œany problems arising in these actions are the direct result of [Agviationâ€™s 
  and Translandâ€™s] own neglectâ€ in failing to monitor the progress in these cases.Â  
  We find this ruling to be in error.
This action is indisputably one for the recovery 
  of money for which a jury trial may properly be demanded.Â  Rule 38(a), SCRCP.Â  
  It is equally clear that the Jacobsens demanded in their complaints that these 
  cases be tried by a jury.Â  Agviation and Transland were entitled to rely on 
  the Jacobsensâ€™ demand for trial by jury and need not make their own demand.Â  
  See Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co, 298 S.C. 127, 129, 378 
  S.E.2d 599, 600 (1989) (â€œUnder Rule 38, a defendant may rely on a plaintiffâ€™s 
  demand for a jury trial.â€)Â  Because a demand for jury trial was properly made, 
  such demand could not be withdrawn â€œwithout the consent of the parties,â€ unless 
  the opposing party is in default.Â  Rule 38(d), SCRCP.Â  Further, the parties 
  or their attorneys did not â€œby written stipulation filed with the court or by 
  an oral stipulation made in open court and entered in the record, consent to 
  trial by the court sitting without a juryâ€ pursuant to Rule 39(a), SCRCP.Â  
Thus, the rules of civil procedure are clear, that 
  where a jury trial is properly demanded, such demand may not thereafter be withdrawn 
  without the consent of all parties, unless the party from whom consent 
  is not obtained has been held in default pursuant to Rule 55(a), SCRCP.Â  As 
  noted by the trial court, the Jacobsens never moved pursuant to Rule 55(a) to 
  have any defaults entered upon the calendar. [3] Â  Rather, they proceeded to trial, 
  presenting evidence on both liability and damages.Â  We therefore hold the trial 
  court erred in transferring the cases to the non-jury docket and hearing them 
  in a bench trial.Â  Where the consent of all parties is not obtained, there is 
  no provision in the rules allowing the transfer of a case from the jury docket 
  based upon a partyâ€™s failure to appear for trial, unless default has been entered 
  against that party.Â  Here, the fact that Appellants were not present when the 
  case was called for trial is irrelevant, as there had been no entry of their 
  default.
For the foregoing reason, the judgments against 
  Agviation and Transland are vacated. 
  [4] 
VACATED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] The court relied in part on Renaissance Enters., Inc. v. Summit 
    Teleservices, Inc., 334 S.C. 649, 651, 515 S.E.2d 257, 258 (1999), holding 
    a non-lawyer cannot represent a corporation in either the circuit or appellate 
    courts of this state. 

 
   
    [2] See Rule 55(a), SCRCP (â€œWhen a party against whom a judgment 
    for affirmative relief is sought has failed to plead or otherwise defend as 
    provided by these rules and that fact is made to appear by affidavit or otherwise, 
    the clerk shall enter his default upon the calendar (file book).â€)

 
   
    [3] Indeed, there is no indication that the Jacobsens, by affidavit or 
    otherwise, asserted the appellants failed to plead or otherwise defend such 
    that they would have been entitled to entry of default against the appellants 
    pursuant to Rule 55(a).Â  

 
   
    [4] Because our decision on this issue renders Appellantsâ€™ other arguments 
    moot, we need not address them in this appeal.

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alan J. Dalrymple,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-425
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Henry Morris Anderson, Jr., of Florence, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Alan J. Dalrymple was convicted 
  of assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK) and possession of a knife 
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court 
  erred in refusing to charge defense of others to the jury and failing to direct 
  a verdict on the ABIK charge.Â  We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities.Â  As 
  to Issue I:Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003) 
  (â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€); 
  State v. Starnes, 340 S.C. 312, 322-23, 531 S.E.2d 907, 913 (2000) (â€œUnder 
  the theory of defense of others, one is not guilty of taking the life of an 
  assailant who assaults a friend, relative, or bystander if that friend, relative, 
  or bystander would likewise have the right to take the life of the assailant 
  in self-defense.â€); State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 416, 535 S.E.2d 431, 
  434 (2000) (holding self-defense is established where the evidence shows the defendant (1) the defendant was without 
  fault in bringing on the difficulty, (2) the defendant was in imminent danger of losing 
  his life or sustaining serious bodily injury or reasonably believed he was in 
  such danger, that (3) if based on a belief of imminent danger, an ordinary reasonable 
  person in his the defendantâ€™s position would strike the fatal 
  blow, and (43) 
  the defendant had 
  no means of avoiding the danger).Â  As to Issue II:Â  State v. Lindsey, 
  355 S.C. 15, 20, 583 S.E.2d 740, 742 (2003) (holding on appeal from the denial 
  of a directed verdict the court must view the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the State); State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 
  172 (2003) (â€œIf there 
  is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending 
  to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted 
  to the jury.â€), cert. 
  denied, 124 S. Ct. 101 (2003); Hill v. State, 350 S.C. 465, 
  472, 567 S.E.2d 847, 851 (2002) (â€œABIK is an unlawful act of a violent nature 
  to the person of another with malice aforethought, either express or implied.â€); 
  State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 2697, 276, 584 S.E.2d 138, 141-42 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (defining malice as the wrongful intent to injure another indicating a depraved 
  spirit intent on doing wrong); State v. Ballington, 346 S.C. 262, 
  272, 551 S.E.2d 280, 285 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding malice may be implied by use 
  of a deadly weapon).
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and
CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.
