THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Melvin McNeil,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-426
Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A Richland County jury convicted 
  Melvin McNeil of assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  He appeals, asserting 
  the trial court erred by (1) improperly admitting evidence of a prior bad act 
  allegedly committed by McNeil, and (2) refusing to grant a mistrial following 
  the solicitorâ€™s inappropriate reference to the prior bad act evidence during 
  closing arguments.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On the evening of January 2, 2001, Levette 
  Goodwin, Tyrone Rivers, and Mary Wooden were walking together along Flamingo 
  Road in the Bluff Estates neighborhood of Columbia.Â  As they continued down 
  the road, a vehicle drove slowly past the group and stopped a short distance 
  in front of them.Â  McNeil emerged from the driverâ€™s side of the car holding 
  a handgun.Â  Seeing this, Goodwin began running away.Â  McNeil fired the handgun 
  a couple of times, hitting Goodwin in his leg with one bullet.Â  
McNeil was subsequently arrested and charged 
  with assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK).Â  At trial, the solicitor 
  introduced evidence that McNeil shot Goodwin in another incident that occurred 
  on November 12, 2000, some 50 days before the January 2, 2001 shooting.Â  Over 
  defense counselâ€™s objection, the trial court admitted the evidence as proof 
  of McNeilâ€™s intent when he shot Goodwin on January 2, 2001.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Admission of Prior Bad Act Evidence
McNeil first claims the trial court erred 
  by admitting testimony that he allegedly shot the victim several weeks prior 
  to the incident charged.Â  We disagree.
Goodwin testified that he had known McNeil all 
  his life, but that hostilities developed between them sometime in late 2000 
  after they had been â€œslap boxingâ€ at the home of Goodwinâ€™s cousin: 

I was messing around and grabbed 
  [McNeil] by his leg and fell on top of him, and we was just playing, kidding 
  around.Â  Ever since that day [McNeil] just took it serious and he had like a 
  vendetta against me. . . . Every time he saw me it was like Iâ€™m going to get 
  you, and he was like pulling out guns and wanting to fight, you know. 

Goodwin further testified that subsequent to the 
  wrestling incident, on November 12, 2000, McNeil shot him while he was walking 
  through the Bluff Estates neighborhood:

I was going to my cousinâ€™s house 
  earlier that morning, and I was coming through the cut and Mr. McNeil was sitting 
  in the chair on the side of the house and he had a shotgun in his hand.
. . . .
I turned around and I jumped 
  the gate. Then he ran behind me with the shotgun and started shooting, right. 
  I was running. I was behind the lady that stays next to my cousin.Â  I hid behind 
  her car.Â  When I tried to jump the gate, thatâ€™s when he got to shooting some 
  more and thatâ€™s when the buck shots hit the gate and one hit me right here in 
  my arm. 

McNeil argues the admission of this testimony regarding 
  the prior shooting was unfairly prejudicial to his defense, only serving to 
  foster in the jurorsâ€™ minds a presumption of guilt for the crime charged.
While evidence of prior crimes or misconduct is 
  inadmissible to prove the specific crime charged, it may be admitted if it tends 
  to establish:Â  (1) motive; (2) intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; 
  (4) a common scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so 
  related to each other that proof of one tends to establish the others; or (5) 
  the identity of the person charged with the present crime.Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE; 
  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 416, 118 S.E. 803, 807 (1923).Â  If not the 
  subject of a conviction, a prior bad act must first be established by clear 
  and convincing evidence.Â  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 135, 536 S.E.2d 
  679, 683 (2000).Â  The decision on whether to admit evidence of other bad acts 
  is entrusted to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and that decision will 
  not be disturbed by the appellate court if there is any evidence to support 
  the admission.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).
In the present case, the trial court admitted 
  the evidence concerning McNeilâ€™s prior assault on Goodwin as probative of McNeilâ€™s 
  intent when he committed the shooting for which he was charged.Â  However, evidence 
  of other crimes, even if logically relevant to prove intent, is inadmissible 
  if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice 
  to the defendant.Â  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Brooks, 341 S.C. 57, 62-63, 
  533 S.E.2d 325, 328 (2000).Â  The determination of prejudice must be based on 
  the entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case.Â  
  Id.Â  at 62, 533 S.E.2d at 328.Â  Evidence is unfairly prejudicial if it 
  has an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis.Â  State 
  v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 666, 552 S.E.2d 745, 760 (2001).
Based on our review of the record before 
  us, we conclude the evidence of McNeilâ€™s prior shooting of Goodwin bears sufficient 
  logical relevance to the ABIK charge in this case.Â  Both incidents occurred 
  close in time and under similar circumstances involving the same victim.Â  Evidence 
  of the November 12, 2000 shooting was, therefore, significantly probative of 
  McNeilâ€™s intent when he shot Goodwin on January 2, 2001.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Mistrial
McNeil next argues the trial court erred 
  by denying his motion for mistrial following the solicitorâ€™s reference to the 
  November 12, 2000 shooting in his closing statement.Â  We disagree.
The portion of the solicitorâ€™s closing 
  argument at issue was transcribed as follows:

SOLICITOR: One thing in 
  [defense counselâ€™s] opening statement that he seemed to harp on a lot was the 
  fact that it was just a leg wound.Â  [Goodwin] was just shot in the lower leg.Â  
  I submit to you, ladies and gentlemen, ask yourselves, how many times does that 
  young man have to be shot, and â€“
DEFENSE COUNSEL:Â  Your 
  Honor, I object to that argument.
TRIAL JUDGE:Â  I think 
  so.
DEFENSE COUNSEL:Â  And 
  I have a matter of law to take up whenever the court wishes.
TRIAL JUDGE:Â  All right, 
  sir.Â  Just move on please, sir.
SOLICITOR:Â  Yes, sir.
Shot two times, is that not enough 
  to find malice? Is that not enough for there to be malice, ladies and gentlemen?
DEFENSE COUNSEL: I continue 
  the objection, sir. 

The trial judge then convened a bench conference 
  with counsel out of the hearing of the jury.Â  
At the conclusion of closing arguments, 
  defense counsel moved the trial court for a declaration of mistrial on the grounds 
  that the portion of the solicitorâ€™s closing argument quoted above made reference 
  to the evidence of McNeilâ€™s prior bad act in a manner beyond the scope of the 
  limited purpose for which it was admitted.Â  Defense counsel argued that, instead 
  of being used to show McNeilâ€™s intent at the time he committed the act for which 
  he was charged, the solicitor was attempting to appeal to the passion and prejudice 
  of the jury.Â  
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within 
  the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State 
  v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 S.E.2d 626, 627-28 (2000).Â  â€œA mistrial 
  should only be granted when absolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant must show 
  both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  Id. 
  at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 628; see also State v. Beckham, 334 
  S.C. 302, 310, 513 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999) (â€œThe granting of a motion for a mistrial 
  is an extreme measure which should be taken only where an incident is so grievous 
  that prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way.â€).
In this case, we do not discern any error or prejudice 
  resulting from the content of the solicitorâ€™s closing statement.Â  The reference 
  to the two shootings and the question, â€œhow many times does that young man have 
  to be shot,â€ while no doubt intended to capture the jurorsâ€™ attention, did not 
  necessarily suggest that the evidence of McNeilâ€™s alleged prior bad act be considered 
  for any purpose other than to determine McNeilâ€™s intent when he committed the 
  crime charged.Â  Indeed, one of the avenues pursued by McNeilâ€™s attorney in his 
  defense was to suggest, even if McNeil did shoot Goodwin, he did not have the 
  necessary intent for the jury to find him guilty of ABIK.Â  The solicitorâ€™s statement 
  can be reasonably interpreted as merely emphasizing the fact that the prior 
  alleged shooting tends to prove the intent with which McNeil acted when he shot 
  Goodwin on January 2, 2001.Â  That the jury would draw this conclusion from the 
  solicitorâ€™s argument is all the more likely when considering the manner in which 
  the solicitor qualified his statement after defense counselâ€™s initial objection, 
  adding: â€œShot two times, is that not enough to find malice? Is that not enough 
  for there to be malice, ladies and gentlemen?â€Â  The solicitor therefore made 
  clear that he was focusing the juryâ€™s attention on McNeilâ€™s intent when he shot 
  Goodwin on January 2, 2001.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons above, we find the trial court 
  did not abuse its discretion in admitting evidence of McNeilâ€™s prior bad act, 
  nor did the trial court abuse its discretion in denying McNeilâ€™s motion for 
  a mistrial based on the solicitorâ€™s closing argument.Â  Finding no error, the 
  rulings of the trial court are therefore
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.
